text: Bomber, 2017 vintage. Tart green apple aroma with notes of cherry, plum, oak and caramel. Pours reddish-brown with a thin tan head that has some retention and excellent lacing. Starts with cherry, plum and caramel flavors that has a lively mouthfeel. Finishes dry with tart green apple and some oak flavors. Complex and delicious, a very nice sour.
Bottle. Dark mahogany reddish brown color, white head. Nice aroma, cherries, plums, oak notes. Nice taste has sour notes, oak, cherries, plums, balanced and complex.

Magic sour cherry happy juice! üçí 
Has a fruity and almost syrupy aroma, with a dark red appearance and smooth palate. The taste is sharp and tangy in the cheeks, with a nice, fruity finish. One of the very best sours I¬íve ever had- not too light on the sour, but doesn¬ít ignore the fruit either. Good for hoarding to yourself when you¬íre supposed to share it with your boo boo at the arcade that just got pinball machines, and/or reminiscing the day after while digesting spicy wings.
Dark brown, no head. Light sour nose. Big malty base hives way to a sharp sour. Bam. It lingers too.
on tap pours auburn with thin beige head aroma is cherry and apple taste is same with a tart finish

Very complex. Starts out with some dry cherry, the with a sharp tartness in the middle that fades into a dry, oaky taste with maybe a hint of bitter chocolate. Ginger and spices hit with the sourness. Excellent.
2009 bottle thanks to Bill pours ruby red with no head. Cherry nose, battery, medium sourness. Light body. No carbonation.

2017 bottle from Brewtopia, drank last night. Reddish dark brown with lasting beige head and lace. Sour cherry woody earthy aroma. Mild ripe cherry plum sweetness with woody earthy light bitterness in very dry woody spice finish. Medium light body, nice fine internal carbo. TOTALLY FUCKING EXCELLENT. Up there with the best Flanders reds.

2016, 22 oz. Pours deep red/brown, one finger head dissipates quickly leaving a bit of lacing. Fruit and wine on the nose. Raspberry, fig with a nice sour funk. Beautiful balanced finish.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

22 ounce bottle. (2016 vintage). Pours a ruby red, brown color. Small creamy light tan head. Nose is earthy, leathery with sour plum notes. Big puckering sour fruit notes upfront. Notes of sour apple, sour cherry and oak. As the beer warms, the character becomes smoother and the sour notes are less assertive. The finish is lightly tart with a chewy mouthfeel. Very good.
Draft Taproom (Charlottesville) as La Folie (Lips of Faith) (2017). Flavor is tart but smooth lemon, grasses, fruit.

650ml bottle. (2016 vintage) Pours a clear deep ruby with some sediment floating around and a medium, short lived, beige head that leaves spotty lacing. Sour aroma of dark malt, prunes, cherry, apple cider vinegar, red wine and oak. Sweet flavour of green apple, cherry, raspberries, vinegar and oak with a dry, sour, acidic finish. Medium body with an oily texture and soft carbonation. Excellent, the pucker power was over hyped but still very enjoyable.

UPDATED: APR 2, 2017 Draft at Khyber Pass. Translucent dark ruby brown pour with just a thin fizzy ring. Clean complex sour red/brown. Tart, earthy and malty. Sour cherries. Cocoa beans. Plums. Dates. Brazil nuts. Raspberries. Toffee. Apple cider vinegar. Sassafras. Molasses. Pomegranate. Broadens nicely as it warms. More interesting with every sip.

2014 bottles back in November ¬í14 and now in March 2017. Aroma is quite strong -- oak, dark fruit, red wine, sour funk. Taste follows aroma along with some cofee, cola, raisins and dates. Complex beer. Sweetness increased and sourness decreased over time, as well as the oak/wine flavors dominating the aftertaste (it was more smooth back in ¬í14). IMO was markedly better back in ¬í14 but still really good three years on.
on tap at New Belgian on a blustery Colorado day. Wow this is a good one. Some fruit, malt and a bit of sour vinaigrette in it. Damn fine beer
user_location: The World of Beer, Texas, USA

text: Bottle; pours brown with some tint and thin tan head; light tart aroma of red fruits, wood, malt, and hints of apples; taste is tart red fruits, apples, wood, and malt notes; tart, dry finish; very good
Pours light reddish brown with a small head. Aroma is malty. Flavour is malty and sour and musty in s great way.

650 ml bottle shared by Werckmeister, thanks! Aroma with wood, acid, dark malts, some roastiness, vinegar. Dark brown color, brownish head. Flavor is dark malts, candy, hints of barrels, molasses, berries, leather.

Bottle. Thanks to Werkmeister. Dark brown reddish body with tan head. Aroma is nice roasted malts dried fruits hints of sourness. Taste is sour roasted malts coffee some fruits maybe some leather . Aftertaste is sour roasted malts.

650 ml bottle shared by Werckmeister, thanks!
Deep ruby body, with a medium, creamy, beige head. 
Aroma of overripe fruits, leather, dried fruits, some wood, some cocoa. 
Tastes quite similar, with even more leather notes. 
Medium, a bit oily mouthfeel, with an average carbonation. 
Finishes moderate sour, leathery, a bit wooden, fruity. 

Very nice. Interesting, with lots of leathery notes, that aren¬ít too intensive though. Drinks quite easy, with a not too strong sourness. Not outstanding, but well drinkable.

0,66l bottle at Linz Tasting shared by me from trade with fabiand, bit thanks for this one. Vintage 2015. brown cloudy color, small off-white head. smells of honey, light acidic, bit citric, nutty, marzipan, bit dusty, some fruity notes. nice smell sourness not noticable at all though. full body, soft carbonation, slick mouthfeel. tastes citric, berry notes, light cherries, resin, bit acidic, lightly vinegarish, some sweetness, bit herbal, rather leathery. finishes light to medium sour with notes of citrus, berry notes and rather leathery. not bad, but lacks a bit balance, did expect a bit more of this one.

Our tour guide at the brewery suggested that you have to date (or taste) a sour three times to really warm up to it. I like that, and I¬ím going to borrow it. This one is pretty tasty, definitely some acidic funk that isn¬ít for the faint of heart, but also not the most complex of sours. Nicely balanced.

Thanks to Hertie for sharing this 2013 bottle. Pours a hazy brown with orange highlights and a tan head. It smells a bit infected. Wood, cherry, some tartness and some fruit. The taste is fairly punchy fruit - cherry, wood ending super dry. Very active carbonation...not so smooth.

22 ounce bottle. 2015 vintage. Very unique beer You can taste the burnt wood and the sour, which is not very overwhelming. You can smell the sour with wood. Dark brown in color and smooth when drinking When poured you get some head. Overall this is a really nice sour. Happy New Year!
Delicious and brown with complex cherry and dried cherry and some sweet spice notes. This was the 2014 offering and was quite good and tart with balance.
On tap at HopCat. Pours brown with little to no head. Aroma of green apple and cherry. Taste is tart and pleasant.

22 oz bottle. Vintage 2012. (New Belgium Brewing Co) Ft Collins, CO.
Halloween rooftop rating session in the dark. Chicago, IL. 
Dark red brown color with a small tan head. Looks really nice. 
Sourness, red berries, wood, mold, sweetness, cherry and malt in the aroma. Complex. 
The flavor is sourness, tartness, red berries, cherry and woody dryness. 
Very nice. Balanced and enjoyable.

Bomber vintage 2014 d√©gust√©e en compagnie de C√©drick. Robe rouge pourpre et profonde sur laquelle une franche mousse demeure longuement assise. Une quantit√© presque outrageante de fruits fonc√©s. De la prune confite, de la pelure de figue, du raisin noir. Une bi√®re qui m¬íinspire un √©trange croisement entre une bi√®re s√ªre et une quadrupel. Le bois occupe une place importante et contribue √† une importante acidit√© dans laquelle je retrouve du jus de pommes fra√Æchement press√©es. Tr√®s intense, je crois adorer une gorg√©e sur deux de cette bi√®re hors normes.

My introduction to the family of New Belgium¬ís sour beers. Not the expected golden brown nor are there any obvious references to cannibalism. A dramatic clear deep re with a beige head that¬ís soon a coat. Aroma of prunes, cherries, leather, strawberry vinegar, raw apples. Lowish carbonation. Couldn¬ít quite decide whether just a little more body would have worked better. Quite sour, noticeably acetic. Faint note of boot polish. Lots of fruit, leather, twigs, cherry stones/ almonds, oak. Perhaps sacrifices refreshment for intrigue a little more than my ideal, but a very fine beer indeed.

Pours ruby-tinted copper with a small head.
Nose shows cherries, strawberry jam, soft balsamic notes and a peppery character.
Flavours include nutty and toasty malt, cherries and an assertive acidity.

Bouteille vintage 2015. Robe brune trouble avec de petits reflets rouge√¢tres surmont√© d¬íun l√©ger col de mousse blanch√¢tre. Ar√¥mes de malt caram√©lis√©, cerise, jus de baies, levures sauvages, sucre brun, l√©g√®re acidit√© ac√©tique, bois de ch√™ne. En bouche, m√©lange d¬íacidit√© citrique et ac√©tique, jeunes cerises, levures sauvages, ch√™ne mouill√©, baies rouges. Finale bois√©e avec touche citronn√©e et de cerise. Texture huileuse et corps mince √† moyen. Tr√®s belle bi√®re.

On tap at St. Augustine¬ís during New Belgium 25th anniversary celebration. Pours a hazy copper with no head. Aroma is cherry notes, slightly woody. Same character sour, tart taste with caramel and bready notes. Pleasant, but I wish it more sweet.
Bottle. Wow. Pours a dark brown reddish color with little fuzz bubbles. Taste is tart and sweet but very well balanced. The rodenbach brewmaster would be proud

Bottle: (2016) Copper red with a light haze. Certainly sour although clean. No VA or undesirable aromas. Light caramel aromas along with a flinty mineral note. Palate is clean, sour and tight. There is some citrus zest and moderate bitterness. Lots of fruit. 
Lovely beer. Note sure whether sour reds should be this clean or have a little more funk and personality.

Sour, woody on the nose with some fruit (green apple?) notes. Pours dark amber / orange with thin white foam. The flavor is sour and complex. The malts are well balanced against the yeasty notes. The apple comes through as does the oak. Medium body and slightly slick. A good sour, but feels a little thin.
Sampled at Big Pour 2015.
Bottle, december 18th 2016. Dark red body with a tanned head. Aroma of tart fruit, herbs, funk. Sour fruit atste with leather and berries, quite dry palate. Funky and fruity finish. Good one!

(bottle, 66cl) Slightly hazy, ruby brown colour with a short and off-white foamy layer. Slightly toasted malty aroma with notes of candied fruits, cherries, prunes and an oaky touch. Acidic and delicately tart flavour, medium bodied with a soft carbonation. Initially dry and acidic taste with fruity notes of cherries, plums, hints of vinegar, backed by oaky, woody notes and a tinge of caramel; dry and acidic cherry-/morello-fruity and plummy finish with mildly funky notes in the backyard. Great. 24.VI.16

Bouteille: Red-brown, unclear, small and stable off-white head,; prunes, cherries and almonds, vinegar and wood ( french oak ) as well; solid sour flavour, some residual sweetness detectable; lingering sour and woody and fruity finish. Yes, yes...

650ml bottle, 2015 vintage. Deep red-brown with small beige film. Fairly acidic aroma of tart red fruits, plum, apple, vinegar, wood, light vanilla and faint black olives. Taste is acidic with tart red fruits, plums, tart apples, wood, light vanilla, light black olives, red fruit pits and some cherry. Quite filling mouthfeel, medium carbonation and dry tart aftertaste with lingering acidity.
Pours muddy Ruby red. Thin white head that quickly dissolves. Tart and mellow with hints of cherry and Brett.

Dark copper color, non transparent. Tiny off-white head. Strange it¬ís that dark for a sour. Aroma is mind blowing. Dry fruity wine, raspberry, cherry, tart nose. Gorgeous. Beautiful. It¬ís also sweet, chocolaty in some way. Taste is almost even - sweet and sour. It¬ís tart, sour, chocolaty, harsh, pinching, itching. Long sour, ¬íannoying¬í aftertaste. And in the same time it¬ís fruity sweet and pleasant. It¬ís sick!

2014 vintage bottle from Growlr Grlz (Durham), shared with Tim in Pittsburgh. Pours deep reddish-brown with a small white head. Sour fruit aroma hits you hard. Taste is incredibly tart; mouth-puckeringly (is that a word?) so. Very dry finish. Not much of the oak barrel comes through here. Palate is average but not a detriment in any capacity. This is ridiculously amazing sour beer, no matter the vintage. If you are ambivalent about sours this one will change your mind.
Pours a dark brown/redish body with a thin head. Odd but interesting aroma. Nice fruity sour taste with a very nice finish.

This beer is awesome, full bodied, perfect sourness, caramelly to the right extent. Toronado SF.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

At TourdeFat. Medium copper brown, no head because pretty poured.Aroma is intense, winey, dark fruit, sourness. Taste has raisins, other dark fruit, espresso, and a rich elusive almost lemon candy sourness. Maybe some cola notes. Complex, a lot to taste.

Drunk in the foeder room on the tour of New Belgium, it sure as hell doesn¬ít get much cooler than that. A reddish brown with a tart plum and cherry aroma. Tart lightly oaky flavor of acidic berries with some lactic acid in the finish. A top quality tart & sour beer that drinks easily.
On tap at Hopcat. Pours a very deep red with no see through. Sour aroma with mildly disappearing mouthfeel. Lovely.

Aroma: oak, sour fruit, vinous
Appearance: hazy amber with a thin off-white head
Taste: heavily sour, medium sweetness, 
Palate: light-medium body, slick feel, soft carbonation, long finish

Tasty sour

Aroma is stone fruit, some oak. Pours a dark brown, with little head that dissipates quickly. Taste is cherry, sour apple, and oaky dryness. Finishes sour but very clean. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Poured from a bottle into a snifter
 Appearance ¬ñ The beer pours a deep mahogany color with a tiny fizzy white head. The head fades very fast, leaving just some hints of foamy lace on the sides of the glass.
 Smell ¬ñ The aroma of the brew is big of a sour green apple smell mixed with a good deal of sour cherry. The sour fruity smells are accompanied by some aromas of oak and a strong apple cider vinegar and slightly hay-like aroma.
 Taste ¬ñ The taste begins with a rather sour green apple flavor mixed with a little bit of cherry. The cherry grows slightly stronger as the taste advances with a sour flavor of apple cider vinegar coming to the tongue. Along with these developing flavors comes strong flavors of hay and some yeast. A light level of cherry sweetness develops toward the middle, with it only fading again more toward the end of the taste. At the very end, a decent showing of oak and even more tart green apple and sour tastes come to the tongue, leaving one with a cherry and apple fruited sour taste to linger on the tongue.
 Mouthfeel ¬ñ The body of the brew is rather thin with a carbonation level that is moderate. The thin body is fantastic for the sour flavors and with the medium carbonation it makes for an easier drinker in light of its very sour and bitter nature.
 Overall- A somewhat fruity, but still rather dry and quite sour brew. A pretty good example of a Flanders Oud Bruin and one to at least give a try too.

Pours ruby with medium tan head. Sour slightly smoky aroma. Flavor very complex with hints of caramel, sour cherry, smoke barely breaking through the sour palette. Intense but didn¬ít quite work as hoped.
Draft. Dark ruby red in color with an off-white lace ring. The aroma is dark stone fruits. Very sour.
Pours a reddish brown color. Aromas of dark fruit, yeast, and a touch of wood. Flavor is sour cherries, yeast, wood, and a couple of sweet tarts.

22 oz bottle shared by ebone1988. 2016 vintage. The pour is a reddish brown color with a bubbly light cream colored ring of head that leaves a pretty soapy lace all around. The aroma is surprisingly boozy for the style. There is a lot of malts here that are really preventing a sourness from establishing itself. The maltiness is really strange. The flavor is equally disappointing. The malts are really sweet up front and there is a decent profile to it. There is a light vinegar and  just no sour at all. For a beer that has the word sour on the label, this is horse shit. The mouth feel is watery and thin with a sweet metallic aftertaste. This one is not great at all, but it's drinkable at least.

Bottle shared with koleminer20 and Gus. Aroma is tart, funky, barrel, sweet and decent. Appearance is red brown, light tan head, somewhat clear. Taste is somewhat tart, funky, skins, barrel, malt, meh. Mouthfeel is medium body, light carbonation, malty aftertaste. Overall, this one is incredibly disappointing.
Pours hazy brown with a small white head. Aroma is earthy, green apple and woody. Taste is tart and sour. Medium bodied with some residual stickiness. Crisp and dry finish. Excellent.

Pour from bottle in San Antonio. This is a great sour that pours dark with tan, lasting head. You can taste the barrel aging, and it has a crisp finish.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bottle from Systembolaget. Tart smell with wood and some fruits. Similar taste. Very nice!
Tap at Austin Ale House, Austin, TX. Pours deep Burgundy, slightly tan head. Aroma is sour funk, caramel, cinnamon, dark fruit. Flavor is sour funk, dark fruit. Man, really good.

Poured from a bottle. Medium brown color, short lived small off white head. Medium body with a slight tart flavor with q nice finish. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
A sour bretinomyces aroma, pours a clear reddish brown color with a short lasting tan head. A tart fruit taste with a medium body and a mildly sour finish.

Bottle shared. Hazy brown with a medium tan head. Aroma of tart red fruits, oak, tart ripe dark fruit, vinegar and caramel. Flavour is light moderate sweet and sour. Medium bodied with soft carbonation.

Bottle courtesy of and shared with Kermis.
Thin creamy off white head, Hazy amber pour. Subtle tartness. Well done.
Fantastic. Hazy brown. Initially a strong sour pucker but muted by toasty malt and wood/cedar notes.
Bottle @ Super Bowl L. Dirty, hazy brownish pour with reddish hues. Tons of red berries, cranberries and cherries in particular. Light balsamico, some caramel and vanilla as well. Super good!

Bottle. Aroma is oak, caramel, nuts and socks. Flavor has a nutty caramel and sour taste. Nice body and the source lingers for a while. I think the extra dryness may hurt this from me liking as much as others.
On tap at 7 Monks. Pours a hazy deep brown with a small white head. Aroma and taste of dark malt and sour fruit. Dry, pleasant finish.
Aroma was great as the bottle poured but dissipated quickly. Appearance is quite hazy and a deep red/brown. Taste is excellent; so refreshing and tart. Wonderful brew, I wish I had more of it!

Draft at the black bird during sfbw. Reddy amber onion skin coloured pour with a small off white head. Aroma is nice tart sour, blackberry, cranberry, hints of wood and cherry. Flavour is composed of semi sweet, and sour tart cranberry and cherry fruit, wood tannin. Nice complexity. Palate is medium bodied. Semi sweet and sour, highish carbonation, semi drying finish. Cherry bakewell.
Holy shit this was good. The right mix of sour and tart. Beautiful nose just really good all the way around.

Nice clear amber, soft spotted filmed head. Nose is soft sweetness, woody caramel and no hint of the sour. Initial taste is gripping berry tart. Carbonation is middling and clean tart break on the mouthfeel. Finishes a long reaching sourness and lingers a good brassy red berry tart. Bottle, Two Kay Tasting de la Comely Bankers Draught
Bottle. Clear amber. Nose is sour, wood, cherries, light sweetness. Taste is sour cherry, wooden notes, long sour finish.
Slightly cloudy dark red in colour. Red fruits and woody notes on the nose. Very smooth on the palate despite the sourness. Very nice indeed.
Bottle thanks to those guys. A tangy fruity woody aroma. More if the same. Style nailed.
Bottle at appellation. Pours deep amber, nose is funky, grapes, vanilla, taste is hugely sour, dry, funky, fruity, cherry.

Bottle Appellation Wines, Comely Bankers Draught tasting. Pours clear red-brown with a thin beige head. Aromas of sour cherry, light sweet. Taste is sweet and sour cherry, sour finish. Oaky at the end.

Bottle shared, thanks Will! Lovely sour cherry character with a gentle tart edge, lingering herbal notes, umeboshi, oak, fairly smooth on the finish. Maybe not as complex as some Belgian classics but a very enjoyable and drinkable sour.

Bottle shared at Antenna America. Deep cherry wood color with 2 fingers of soapy foam that lingers. Loads of oak on the nose with cherry and blackberry undertones, almond, light balsamic vinegar and dark fruit. Dry on the palate and leathery with a slight creaminess that comes out on the finish. Good tartness on the palate with lots of wood coming through and more of sherry-like finish. Very nice, or at least it was at this point in the night.

(2015 650ml bottle from Systembolaget) Pours a clear deep mahogany with a moderate head of dark cream froth that lingers with lots of lace. Aroma fairly sour with sour cherry, balsamic, lots of wet oak and earthy forest notes, a bit of toast to the malt, a hint of sweet caramel for balance. Rather acetic overall. Palate is much less sour, very woody with lots of wet oak and even basement notes, a bit of cherry and raisin, slightly acidic vinous notes but more lactic than acetic, even a bit of lemon juice. Some sweetish caramel, and lightly toasted malts showing up towards the finish with lightly bitter leathery oak. Lightish body with moderate, mouth-filling carbonation. Not a bad Flemish brown, but it doesn¬ít really touch the best in style. Seems like the new incarnation isn¬ít quite a match for the old.

Aroma nuts, cherries, 
Appearance amber, brown, clear, minimal head, white foam, 
Taste medium sweetness, medium sourness, 
Palate medium body, lively, fizzy, 
Overall I¬ím new to sour beers so I can only go off of what I have had up to this point. This sour is really nice to me. Very easy to drink and not overly tart. I would suggest this beer to a friend.

Deep, enticingly fruity nose with Concord grapes, wood, lime juice, balsamic vinegar, cacao, earth, and calvados caramel; shift your lungs into third gear and you¬íll delve into the grainier, drier notes, with some panko crumbs. Underneath it all there¬ís a very slight funk. The mouthfeel is fizzy, with lively carbonation that dissolves the medium body into foam as you press it against your palate. I would have wished for something slightly less intrusive, as so much fizz gets in the way of such a beautiful beer. The beer is bright on the tongue, very acidic with residual sugary sweetness and a dry, grainy backbone. An extremely pleasant aftertaste of Concord grapes and Trolli gummies lingers. Outstanding, delicious, and super interesting.
Bottled from Giant. Red brown pour. Malts, sour patch kids and some body. Bit of wood. Pretty nice.
Poured in a Spiegelau wit glass at home. Served chilled. Not as good as i remembering it being. This is my second bottle today. Slightly watery. Hint of barrels. Will try a warmer bottle next time.
Cherry juice and oaky aromas. Taste is nice lightly roasted malts and oak, then a tart sourness of cherries and balsamic vinegar kicks in the back.

Orangeish amber colour with a small white head. Aroma is kind of sour wood along with some mild slight sour fruity notes. Flavour is very similar. This feels rather hyped to me, and don¬ít get me wrong. It¬ís a beautifully balanced sour beer. But it lacks the depth of lambic, Rodenbach or most other "classics" in the sour/wild category. So adding something that¬íll give depth to it would help it out from going from very nice to marvellous. I had vintage 2015 now on this very date (and have stored the bottled in constant temp and dark since I got it in Spring 2015).

Bottled 650ml (AIH53, from SB)
Dark ruby color, small beige head. Nose has cherry, lactose overall fruity aroma. Medium-bodied. Flavor has acidic cherry, tartness and overall fruity flavor. Somewhat watery finish. Simple. Some wooden notes. It¬ís good and it¬ís tart but something is missing here to qualify 100 percentile.

Rating #1303 25.10.2014 On tap @revolutionyeg - Pours a deep reddish brown with a bubbly head that disapparates rather quickly. Aroma is wild cherries, sour plum tartness - rich, fruity texture. Palate is well balanced - lots of tart cherry, sweetness from the barrel component - lovely sour/bruin.

En bouteille. Couleur brune, translucide, l√©g√®re mousse. Ar√¥mes tr√®s bois√©, surette avec un peu de pruneau. En bouche belle acidit√©, pas mal plus fruit√© qu¬í√† l¬íodorat, pommes vertes, un peu de cerises, mais aussi beaucoup de ch√™ne en fin de bouche.  √áa enveloppe bien la bouche, tr√®s rond.  Finale sec avec un peu d¬íacidit√© r√©siduelle style vinaigre balsamique. Excellent compte tenu du prix et de la disponibilit√©, par contre rien pour virer fou.

Bottle from Bianchini¬ís Market in San Carlos, CA. Aroma is cherries, plums, some wood. Taste is tart and crisp with loads of wood to mellow the sour. This is good but I think I was expecting something bigger / bolder. Still great.
Bottle, sb. Brown clear. Brown malty, brown hay malty, ripe figs, dark fruits soft sourish oak on nose. Med bodied, tarty, intense. Nice oak, brown hay. Flavourful, excellent drink.-- bb
Lots of foam. Lots of lacing. Smells sour. Tart. Tasted at Elijah Ps Monsters of Beer festival.

Deep plum color with a soft creamy off white head .... Aroma of green apples, cherries and plums .... Sour and tart .... Taste is of sour green apples, tart cherries, berry notes and dark fruity (plums) yeast and dry oak .... Mouthfeel is soft and a little creamy ..... Finish is dry and tart with a lingering dry oak and sour cherry

October 9, 2015. Bottle, 2015 vintage. 
Murky reddish brown with a small dirty yellowish tan head.
Aroma is sweet plums, caramel, dried fruits, hints of cherries, oak, lemon, apple skins and a touch of red wine vinegar. Taste is light to medium sweet, tart dry oak and cherry notes. Finish is light sweet dark fruits and caramel, sour lemon, red wine vinegar and lemon with s touch of cocoa. Light to medium bodied, average carbonation with a dry mouthfeel.

Poured from a 2015 Bomber bottle. Medium rusty brown in color with a thin tan head. Aroma has some wood, spice, and a hint of sour fruit but not too strong. Taste is very tart and tangy with a little carbonation but not too sour. There is an earthy woody flavor but not much spice or fruit. The tartness hits the tip of the tongue then quickly disappears. Pretty one dimensional and not too complex. Could have been better if the fruit flavor or tartness lingered longer. The oak flavor was not prominent. Pretty good but not great.

Flaska fr√•n SB. Massor av plommon, k√∂rsb√§r och fat. Tydlig syra men √§nd√• len och mjuk i munnen. I eftersmaken kommer s√∂tsyrliga gula russin, vanilj, s√∂t tabok och fat fram tydligare. Komplex och riktigt snygg smakbild. Ett av de b√§sta r√∂d√∂l jag druckigt. S√• fantastiskt gott.

Bottle from sysembolaget, Sweden.
No head. Clear brown color.
Nice lactic aroma blended with oaky aromas.
Crisp acid and no residual sweetness.
Really sour with a little metallic on tap at whole foods. Light brown and not much head. Some cherries

La Folie 2014. Merci Alex, √† ta sant√© mec! √áa fait un bout que La Folie est dans mon top 5 √† essayer... Au nez : my god, √ßa sent bon! Le c√¥t√© "rouge des Flandres", avec un accent mis sur les baies sauvages (cerises noires) et les bonbons s√ªres. C¬íest complexe et intrigeant. √Ä la fois caverneux et sombre, mais √©galement sucr√©/bonbon. Bien vivante en bouche. C¬íest tr√®s s√ªre mais pas over the top, √ßa demeure dans la zone agr√©able pour un amateur du style. Je laisse r√©chauffer un peu, question de laisser les saveurs ressortir davantage.... Des notes de pommes vertes, de ch√™ne, de prunes. L¬íalcool se fait totalement oublier par les saveurs et l¬íacidit√©. This was a 750ml bottle I purchased in 2008. The bottle # written on the label is ¬í08 6528. I cellared this sour for seven years and opened it today in honour of the seventh anniversary of a beer camping trip with some of my dearest friends. This beer did not disappoint! Colour...very cloudy brown with no head, and tiny yeasty chunks floating about. Nose...this beer is so fruity and acetic, that the glands in the back of my mouth started to gleek just from the smell! Palate...oh man!! This beer is so freaking sour, my salivary glands are on sensory overload!! Whoa!! Massive waves of acetic, sour goodness fill the entire palate and are laced with exquisite flavours of tart Gravenstein apple skins, mashed Italian plums, macerated Royal Anne cherries, under ripe persimmons and tannic oak. The sourness never ceases, nor does the fruit, as it carries all the way through the finish and down the gullet. Even after this beer has headed down the esophagus, the sour lingers on and on. This is most certainly one of the finest beers of this style that I¬íve ever had, especially one made in the good ol¬í USA!

Always one of my favs and not sure why I never rated. Pours a deep reddish brown with almost no head. Aroma is sour cherries, red grapes, earthy leather, and plums. The taste is so smooth with the blend of sour fruits making it complex. The foeder aging really takes the edge off but the sourness is still "In your face." Light body, light carb. Finish is fruity and tart.
Yeasty sweet and sour aroma. Pours dark murky brown with a light tan fizzy head. Very tart but smooth with a clean finish. Sour fruit and yeast.
Pours a dark amber with a thin white head. Aroma is sour berries and wood. Flavor is moderately sour, a nice smooth undernote of berries, and some wood. Excellent.

2015 bottle. Pours a clear, reddish amber with a tiny, fizzy head. Aroma is tart, vinous with grapes, oak, toasted malty sweetness. Taste is sour, oaky, fruity, has cherries, vanilla and a very dry finish. High carb, light body.

Dark ruby pour, big beige head that sticks around. Aroma is sour cherries, red fruit, red wine, wood, some sugary sweetness. Taste follows though a little more sour / acidic. Full body with strong carbonation, dry finish with a long lasting taste.
Garnet red. Light light carbonation. Hazy with some yeast inside. Grass and sour tart some sour prune and cherries. Sweeter finish and tinge of wine cellar
Bottle. Red in colour, clear with pinky very small head. Aroma and flavour of tart and sweet cherries, berries and citrus. Small oaky notes. The beer is bery sour, dry and tart finish. Nice.

Pours a clear blood red with little to no head. Aroma is sour cherries and sweet dark plum marmalade. Taste is cherries, burned wood and tangerines. Sourness is well balanced and there¬ís a slight nice bitterness with plum and cinnamon in the after taste that lingers in the mouth.

Bottle from Elmanana. Many thanks! Red colour, white foam. Medium carbonation. Aroma of red berries, balsamico, vinegar, lemon. bitter earthy notes. Refreshing, but not very well balanced. I like Rodenbach Vintage much better!
Dark red pour from draft at Beef and Barley. White sticky head. Sweet cherry and tart aroma. Strawberry and fruit punch. Fantastic beer.
Red-brown color, beige head. Red berries nose, wood, caramel. Berries taste, strawberries, sour notes, wood, hints of cherry pits, caramel malt and caramel. Medium body, average carbonation.

Classic "New Belgian oud bruin" so to speak, a standard in the style as far as American beers are concerned. Yellowish white, loose head, hazy coppery red brown colour. Aroma indeed of ¬íoud bruin¬í Rodenbach style: sour cherries, passion fruit, yoghurt, strong redcurrant, some caramel, wood, hint of lemon; sweet and sour taste, very fruity and estery, cherries, passion fruit and red berries; smooth caramelly malt backbone, bready, dryingly sourish finish with just a tad of leafy hops for balance and structure as well as some woody dryness. Perfectly fine example of the style, though it seems to lack some body, finesse and depth in comparison with, for example, Rodenbach Vintage.

Taster glass at Churchkey, Washington, DC. Pours clear red-brown with a tan head. Nose is sour vinegar, sour cherry, and green apple. Notes of earth and spice. Flavour is tart green apple, sour cherry, grape skin, oak, and earth. Awesome sour!

Tap at brews. Pours dark dark red hue with a small light brown head. Aroma is light wood, tart cherry, traces of vanilla, the aroma is actually faint overall. Taste is dark fruit, cherry, vanilla and wood, then a nice acidic and tart finish. Pretty damn good.

Pours hazy reddish brown with a finger of frothy light tan head. Aroma of cherries, apples, almond icing, barrel wood. Taste is rich tart - green apples, grass, slightly citrusy. Rich sour finish with just a hint of balancing sweetness. Crisp, light body with soft to average carbonation.

I'll grab a few more bottles to lay down.

Very sour. Slightly salty with some oak taste. Very good.
Really nice sour red/brown. Sour caramel and some cherry, cedar and maple wood character really came through nicely. Great tart overtones with rewky nice lively carbonation.

Appearance: dark purplish brown with a short, fizzy light tan head quickly fading. Aroma: pretty typical sour red, with balsamic, cherry, and wood notes over some leather. Bottle. Pours a dark reddish brown with a super thin layer of tan head. Aroma of tart and funk. Taste is the same but lasts longer than most. Definitely a top notch beer.

Bomber at the Bluebonnet Brew-Off. Poured a reddish amber color with a beige head and nice lacing. Taste of sour apple, plum, wood, funk, and sweet cherries. High fizzy carbonation, medium body. Highly complex. Best beer I sampled at the festival!

Transparent mahogany red/amber with a pinkish head and modest lace. Aromas of tart apple, melon, and oak. Big Granny Smith tartness, yeast funk, rich ripe cherry sweetness and apricot, plum and raisin. Full body, assertive carbonation, smooth mouthfeel and a dry finish. Wonderful compexity.

2015 edition. Bottle at home while visiting Jacksonville. Nice custardy, lemon, light dark berry aroma. Light to medium body, medium carbonation. Cherry, lemon, light sponge cake and custard, raspberry jam... Really smooth and tasty with a great sour kick. Nice.
22 oz bottle 2015 edition. Aroma is wood, cherries, funk.  Flavor is tart cherries, raspberries, oak, earth. Light oak tannins in the finish. Paired well with some hard salami and smoked Gouda.

Reasonably clear rusty brown with a good beige head. Aroma is caramel, sour plum, cherry, red currants. Medium-light bodied, lightly sticky mouthfeel, tart on the palate. Taste is sour plum, cherry, red currants.

It pours a ruby red with a reddish brown head. There are aromas of sour fruit. notes of apples, a bit of wood for the finish. It has a sour, tart taste with fruit and earthen elements and wood flavoring. The carbonation adds a lively pop to it on the palate.

Tap: The first true "sour" beer I¬íve ever had. Deep copper, ruby-red hybrid color with a mild haze. Khaki head with decent retention leaves minimal lacing behind. Aroma full of tart apples, cherry, strawberry, lemon, sweet-tarts, wet-wood, light critter funk, & some mild vinegar. Very tart & sour up front on the tongue; puckering. Full of under-ripe strawberry, green apple, sour cherries, vinegar, & other tart berries. Wild yeast, almost a touch of yogurt in the back-end with moderate acidity & some acetic burn. Dry, sour & woody oak finish. Ever since I had this on tap years ago, I buy bottles every year it comes out. Great beer to have around. La Folie is a classic.

Bottle, deep amber, light brown head, great lacing. Aroma green apples, caramel, oak. Taste green apple, kombucha, black currants, astringent oak. Palate light, carbonation kinda subdued. This is quite sour and astringent.

UPDATED: MAR 17, 2015 No doubt about it, this shit is SOUR. The aroma of citric acid, overripe fruit, and faint vinegar clues you into the liquid Warhead you¬íre about to taste. First, let¬ís talk about the appearance. La Folie is more on the brown side of mahogany. The body is effervescent and the head is fizzy. Now, we can dive into the taste. Holy hell. La Folie¬ís sourness somehow manages to be complex and intense, Yet, it¬ís so damn intriguing that you have no choice but to come back for more. Pungent vinegar, tart berry (raspberry and cranberry), tangy apple, vinous notes, lemon zest, and an earthy sourness from the yeast. For the uninitiated, La Folie will be beguiling. For folks who love sour, funky brews, La Folie is a wonder.

Bottle.
