A- Reddish brown color, clear dark liquid, off white head.

T- Very sour, tart, slightly sweet, lemon juice, cherries, vinegar.

P- Light body, average texture, medium high carbonation, sour finish.

O- Wow. This beer smells sour and tart and tastes crazy sour and tart. You start to get used to it but by that time it¬ís almost gone. Lots of lemon juice and vinegar with subtle notes of cherries and oak. Glad to have tried this when I did. I don¬ít think I would¬íve liked it early on in my beer drinking days.

pours unclear amber . 
Smell is sour , swaety . oak , bit of glue . Taste is sour, oak , intense, bit glue-aspect . very intense on the sour side . Rather dry .

2014 bomber. This beer comes at you in waves. Tart, cherry nose with malt in the background. Seriously sour as the bottle says. Cherry tart gives way to wheat bread sweetness, which in turn fades quietly into dry acidity.
2013 Growler pour at home, thank you Andrew for sharing. Dark copper color, sour fruit aroma. Slight wood oak in the taste.

In the glass this is a cloudy looking dark rust brown colored one. It also has a nice slowly fading beige lacing head on the top. It has this surprisingly fruity nose this! Almost a little sweet, but still tart. Yeah, this is one good smelling nose. Lots of berries, blackberries, grass, some brown sugar and hints of lingon berries. Really nice! Tastes even better. It¬ís definitely sour, slightly woody. Lemon stingy, lots of red berries. Wonderful in the mouth with a near smooth mouthfeel and a just above average carbonation level. Zingy without being to much. Well balanced. Almost a little okay in a way. Sorrel and lemons. This is superbly drinkable. A wonderful beverage.

Half pour at Thirsty Monk Biltmore Park. Seriously loved it. So, so good. New Belgium didn¬ít hold back on this one. Pours a reddish brown with a beautiful thick off-white head. Mouth was watering before first sip- sour apple, oak and earth on the nose. Taste follows with addition of tart cherries and stonefruit. Great acidity and balance. Sweetness is there, but sour notes prevail. Beautifully complex and mysterious. Feel like I didn¬ít quite get in all on the first go. Will be having this again.

10oz on draft, pours dark brown with a hint of red, small amount of haziness. On the nose grape and stonefruit with a hint of sour. Mouth is some caramel malt, mouth puckeringly sour, zingy citrus in the tail. Great beer

A very well made sour from New Belgium. The nose here is massively enticing - puckers your nose before your tongue. Tart cherry and macerated cherries come through here with a great balance on the acidity. Big fan of this one.

BOD 2014. Beautiful clear dark ruby pour. Held to light, it is a deep garnet. Good head volume and retention for the style. Lacing is quite good. The outstanding complex nose is light sweet red fruit - raspberries and cherries - with hints of apples and peaches, over a slightly tart and sour background. Light medium bodied with a surprisingly creamy texture given it¬ís carbonation. Well carbonated with explosive effervescence throughout. The flavor profile is simply World Class ( very intense amazingly complex and masterfully balanced ). It begins with an assault of the flavors of the nose. Tart fruits, with a slight sour note, slowly allow separation into their components (raspberry, cherry, tart apple) as the tart and sour mild puckering effect sets in. The middle is where the masterful balance and complexity become evident as every flavor just ebbs and flows like a tidal action. The finish is a slightly sweet flavor fade into a tart dry pucker that has crisp elements and hints of vinegar. A 12 oz. format would be ideal, as a bomber is a bit much for such a tart ale.
Dark reddish brown appearance, nice sour malt aroma. Intensely sour taste with apple and red fruit, very good.
I was lucky enough to get a oz. sample of this very fine Sour ale last night.

Bottle. Almost clear deep brown liquid with ruby hue and small to medium off-white head. Aroma of light vinegar, cherries, light strawberries, lemon, apple skin and light dried fruit. Taste is dry and medium sour with notes of lemon, red berries, light wood and light vinegar. Medium bodied with medium carbonation. Pretty nice.
2013 bomber from my brother. Pours dark brown with minimal head. Strong tart apple and cherry smell with some lacto. Taste the same with nice slight pucker finish. Really delicious!

Keg at the Green Dragon, PDX, 11/11/14.
Rich burgundy to chestnut brown with a decent beige covering.
Nose is tarte cherries, musty, dank semi rotting woody notes, earthy, light fruit balsam tunes.
Taste comprises rich oak, tarte red grape, dank, musty tones, funk, tangy and bitter red berry notes, apple core, farmyard.
Medium bodied, fine carbonation, red berry rinse and semi puckerings at the close.
Solid stuff.
user_location: Hazlemere, the lower Xhitlerns, Buckinghamshire, ENGLAND

text:
Hazy brown thin tan head. Aroma is woody, sour, grapes. Taste starts sour then is effervescent and like a barrel age wine. Tart finish. Nicely done. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

2014 edition. Reddish brown with a thin bubbly head. So very sour smelling. Lemon, wood, mild funk, and purple grape really shows up in the aroma. Taste is the same but better. Really dig the grape. So very suck your face in sour....... Tart is an under statement. Pretty simple taste. Cherry?? The oak is very noticeable. like this for the style........... why do I like this style now? Why?
Bottle. Pours clear reddish brown. Nose is wine sourness. Taste is similar with nice dry aftertaste.

On tap at Ray¬ís Place, Kent, OH. Dark translucent brown color with thin off-white head and no lacing. Aroma and flavor are sweet with raisins, light fruits, and minimal caramel malts. Good, but simple. It¬ís a nice sour, but cannot compare to the best. This is like the Bud Light of Sours, it¬ís just meh. Overpriced in the bottles, but much cheaper per glass at Ray¬ís, so worth the try.

Pours a murky reddish brown with a one finger off white head with decent lacing. Aroma is of sour apples, vinegar, wood, cherries, light dark bread, and lacto. Taste is Sour apple and cherries, woody notes, vinegar, sour lacto, wet hay, toasted dark bread, and light earth grass. Has a medium-full body with a creamy mouthfeel and a almost bone dry, pretty sour, medium-long finish. Overall, a very tasty, complex sour brown.

What one expects in a sour ale is present in aroma and taste with both being dominated by earthy bright sourness reminiscent of tart lemonade with various outdoor sour notes. Looks decent and the palate while thin and what you¬íd expect is nice. However I could not finish this beer. It was boring and one-note. Sour dominates leaving no hint of grain or vestiges of the base beer. It¬ís simply one note that¬ís to loud, too strong, it¬ís the only thing you get from this beer. It is an orchestra dedicated to playing one note, all together continuously, loudly, obnoxiously. I think it would be great as a blend with other brews. Seriously disappointed with this ¬ílegendary¬í 100 pt brew. One of the less pleasing beer experiences I¬íve had.

On tap at The Tap Room -- poured into an English pint glass. Almost no head on top of a dark ruby colored beer. Smell of lacto, cherry, hint of wood. Flavor is a cherry fruit, followed by heavy lacto sourness. Not quite so sour you tingle in the cheeks, but almost. This is a great sour.

On draft (2014?) at Chuck¬ís bottle shop. Orange brown color, with a medium amount of white head. Slightly cloudy. Lace lingers a bit. Aroma of caramel, very little hops, fallen leaves, cranberry, cherry. Starts sour, and then sweet, with a sour finish. Medium body, soft carbonation, slightly oily texture, a little metal with a fairly long finish. Nice beer!

650 mL bomber dated 2014. Crystal clear garnet with a short lived head of off white foam. Very nice to look at. Malt forward on the nose with dark bread, light caramel, subtle toastiness, some dark fruit as well. Malty-sweet at first and quickly cut by a bracing lactic sourness, no hints of acetic yet. Finishes with a rounded Dutch cocoa tone. Dry and very tart with moderate plus carbonation. Very good, could certainly withstand a half a decade of aging to round it out.

Julie says yuck.  She gives a 1. C. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

08.10.2014, 0,65l bottle (2013) sampled @ BBGTC tasting:
Nice slightly bubbly mediumlasting head. Aroma is slightly sour-ish fruity, strawberry, sugar, oak, soda powder, grass, vinegar, dried fruits, hay. Taste is dry and fresh sour, sorrel, soda powder, vinegar, grass, oak, raw rhubarb, sour unripe berries, lemon, minerals, weeds. Medium bitterness, dry sour-ish mouthfeel. Very nice.

Dark coppery small head. Aroma of wood/oak and tartness. Taste is a nice blend of the sweet and sour. More of the sour tho and that is quite beneficial. A very good and pleasant beer. Typical flanders red/bruin. Fairly dry with close to high mevels of co2.

0.65l bottle shared with The Tasting Crew, from trade with ig88b. Huge thanks man! In the glass this is a cloudy looking dark rust brown colored one. It also has a nice slowly fading beige lacing head on the top. It has this surprisingly fruity nose this! Almost a little sweet, but still tart. Yeah, this is one good smelling nose. Lots of berries, blackberries, grass, some brown sugar and hints of lingon berries. Really nice! Tastes even better. It¬ís definitely sour, slightly woody. Lemon stingy, lots of red berries. Wonderful in the mouth with a near smooth mouthfeel and a just above average carbonation level. Zingy without being to much. Well balanced. Almost a little okay in a way. Sorrel and lemons. This is superbly drinkable. A wonderful beverage. 08.10.2014

UPDATED: FEB 8, 2016 "2006-the brett has taken over! this was the sourest of them all. prickly carbonation , and a touch lighter in color than the 08, which seems to be more mass produced. super acidic, sour apples. intense. 2007-the opposite happens with these beers...they get funkier/more sour as the brett takes hold as they age. the 07 is more what i expected. tart, even sour, but not quite bracingly so. the aroma of all 3 was complex and wonderful. apples and cider vinegar. closer to the 06 than the 08 in color, flavor, and aroma. 2008-wood please?! this one is darker, tamer, smoother, better (arguably). heavy oak flavor and nose, almost to the detrement of the sour complexity, but man is it smooth. I¬ím torn between the 07 and 08. 06-4.0 07-4.3 08-4.3 got this one off ebay and it was worth every penny... Not as intense ever since it became a more mainstream lips of faith beer. Bigger batches = less wild? Either way, our next 3 year vertical was 2010,11,12 and it just didn¬ít stack up. Lots of wood, more sweet than sour, less complexity. On their own, only the 2012 would have got a 4. This brew has definitely slipped. Still good, but I¬íve been skipping it in favor of other sours at $13-14
2015 continues to not be worth what it costs.  Definitely not a 100th percentile brew anymore.

Draft at Tour de Fat in Tempe. Unclear Reddish brown with a creamy lasting khaki head. Fantastic example of the style in my opinion. Superbly sour. Fruity. A little funky. Woody. Really enjoyed this. Why did I put off trying this for so long?

Bottle at home with friends. C&C Vintage 2009 side by side with a 2010. Pour is clear brown with a small tan head and good lacing. Big cherry pit, caramel, some spice, vanilla, toffee, raspberries, tangy and tannins in the aroma. Taste is tangy, some red wine vinegar, oaky, some spice, tannic, wine-like, dark berries, and fruity with a big acidic sour finish. Medium body with high carbonation. This one ages beautifully and much better than the capped version.
Wow! World class sour beer from a world class American brewery always pushing the limits. Sour nose, puckering taste in a dark liquid package. Try this!

UPDATED: JUN 10, 2016 A more subdued, woody, earthy version of Le Terroir. Murky brown with a skin of creamy head that clings to the glass. Aroma more of darker dried fruits and milder tartness . Excellent companion to Le Terroir . Ying and yang. ¬í14 and ¬í16 rated.
Even-toned brown with almost no head. Very Flanders aroma, and taste is an intensely sour cherry. $12/5

OH SO GOOD, great super sour aroma tartness and oak character. Flavor of sour apple prune and a great blue cheese background with tartness to round out brew. Finishes fairly dry, leavin you wanting more of this complex brew

From a tap. Pours a dark amber red with a Coca-Cola tan head which dissipates quickly. Not much lacing left on the glass. Dark fruits, brown sugar and some funk comes through on the aroma. Taste is slightly sweet, some tartness, leather, dark fruits, and sour apples. The sourness stays on the palate for some time, not overpowering. Great beer!

On tap at Redlight Redlight in Orlando. Pours a dark red brown with a tan head and very sweet, tart fruity aroma. Taste is sour and tart, lots of apple and fruit notes coming through with oak and funk into the sour finish. Delicious wild ale

At Redlight Redlight in Orlando on Brandon¬ís birthday with A and Z , pours a dark brown color with no head. Nose is a deep sour and tart malt, and deliciously so. Taste is fruity and sweet up front followed by a strong tartness and sourness. Finish is sour and tart and mouth puckering. Great sour !
Quaff Score 8 / 100

UPDATED: SEP 19, 2015 Draught at BBB. Rerate, love the sourness and the balance.

Old rating: Bottle at Sweet & Sour, S√§tila, 2014-08-30. Hazy amber/brown beer with a small offwhite head. Sourish aroma, caramel, vinegar, licorice, raisins, figs, citrus, solvent notes, barnyard, some dades. Sour vinegar flavor, licorice, raisins, solvent, barnyard, tart notes.

Bomber courtesy of tkrjukoff. Pours hazy amberish brown with a frothy brownish beige head that leaves some sticky lacing on the glass while dissipating. Smell is sweet, sour, slightly malty and tiny fruity with sweet dark bread, caramel, lemon juice, grape juice, moist wood, moist hay, raisins, red wine vinegar, barnyard and lemon zest. Taste is sour and tiny malty with dark bread, toasted cereal, lemon juice, red wine vinegar, moist soil, leather, barnyard, raisins, cocoa powder and lemon zest. Mouthfeel is slightly dry, tart, slightly mouth-puckering and medium. Finish is sour and tiny malty with dark bread, lemon juice, red wine vinegar, moist hay, moist soil, leather, barnyard and lemon zest. Solid sour brown.

Great beer, but I was expecting a little more. For the price tag and the hipe, I struggle to rate this much higher than the standard Rodenbach. Still a great beer worth hunting down, but given the option I¬íd have a Rodenbach grand cru, or pretty much any other Belgian oud brune. In a vertical tasting the new Belgium offering is harsher, and a little more sour. Overall a little thin and less balanced than the Rodenbach.
Amazing smell! Can¬ít be better...sour taste that is just right on strength....wish it finished slightly sweet

Ruby brown murky pour with little beige head. Funky strong scent, port wine but extra tart, pert sour, lighter fruits. Soft carbonation, extreme sour mouthfeel, almost gritty finish it¬ís so dry and sour. Bright sour apple and berry tart, a bit of chardonnay, also some nutty brown ale flavor with a bit of cocoa. Really great in your face sour but probably would add complexity with aging (more creaminess, deeper flavor palate).
I am not really into sours and this was the first I believe. Very sour and tart. Different and unique beer for sure. I¬íll have to try a few more.

A bottle that has been sitting in my basement for 2 or 3 years (for no good reason). Brown reddish pour with a slight tan head. Cherry, raspberry, oak and a hint of vinegar in the nose. Bright sourness in the taste. Cherry, dark fruit, acetic and lactic acid, sharp with a nice finish. Lightly acidic finish that sticks way back in my throat for a while after each sip.

2014 bottle. Poured into a glass. Very dark reddish brown. Little head. Aroma is very complex, rasins, leather, vinegar, cherries. Smells tart. Taste is tart initially, slight vinegar. Fruitiness with cherries and slightly tart raspberry flavors. Finishes with rasins and leather. Nice! Palate is pretty light in body, medium carbonation. Very good, very complex. This one will age nicely.
Mahogany brown and a tan foam. Brett character is very pleasant. Sour, tart, but without too much sweetness. Red apple finishes this off.

Taster at Strong Beer Fest. 2012 vintage. Pours mahogany brown with a bit of white head. Aroma is slightly spicy, sour cherry, acetic. Smells really good. You know what, this is really delicious! Sour cherry, for sure. acetic too. Theres something else that I can only relate to green tomato. I dunno, it¬ís tasty. Candy sugar and more dark cherry in the finish. I could drink a lot of this!

Appearance: pours with a large and dense light tan head, the beer is a beautiful maroon color, appears to be clear
Aroma: sour, tart, creamy, love that aroma even if it¬ís simple
Taste: very sour and very tart, the wood barrels shows itself
Palate: average carbonation, very dry, leaves a sour aftertaste
Overall: I love this beer, incredibly sour, not very complex, it is what it is, if you like sours you will like this, reminds me a lot of Petrie aged pale

I think this one is overrated. It is sweet and sour. Has a reddish brown color and a tan head. Ha at horse thief hollow. Watch out gettin here, rough neighborhoods around it. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Flaske: R√∏dbrun klar √∏l med et fint skumhoved. Duften er sur med en del kirseb√¶r, Smagen er meget t√∏r og meget sur. Ville nok have v√¶ret endnu bedre hvis den ikke blev drukket direkte efter Consecration og Supplication men s√•dan g√•r det jo nogle gange. Fin √∏l ellers.

22 ounce bottle into signature globe glass; 2013 vintage, bottled 12/2/2012. Pours crystal clear dark ruby red color with a 1-2 finger dense khaki head with good retention, that reduces to a thin cap that lingers. Light spotty soapy lacing clings on the glass, with a fair amount of streaming carbonation. Aromas of big sour cherry, cranberry, green apple, raisin, plum, red wine vinegar, caramel, brown bread, hay, straw, grass, leather, toasted oak, musty funk, and yeast earthiness. Fantastic aromas with great complexity and balance of fruity/funky/lactic yeast, dark malt, and oak notes; with good strength. Taste of sour cherry, green apple, cranberry, raisin, plum, red wine vinegar, caramel, brown bread, hay, straw, grass, leather, toasted oak, musty funk, and yeast earthiness. Good amount of fruity/earthy tartness on the finish; with lingering notes of sour cherry, green apple, cranberry, raisin, plum, red wine vinegar, hay, straw, grass, leather, toasted oak, musty funk, and yeast earthiness on the finish for a while. Fantastic complexity and balance of fruity/funky/lactic yeast, dark malt, and oak barrel flavors; with an awesome malt/acidity balance and zero cloying flavors after the finish. Medium carbonation and body; with a very smooth, crisp, and moderately acidic mouthfeel that is great. Alcohol is well hidden with only a slight warming present after the finish. Overall this is an outstanding Flanders brown ale. All around awesome complexity and balance of fruity/funky/lactic yeast, dark malt, and oak barrel flavors; and very smooth and crisp to drink even with the moderate acidity. A highly enjoyable offering.
what a wonderful sour! Beautiful amber color, mild sour and fruity aroma, and a somewhat strong malty sour taste. One of my favorites from New Belgium for sure.

I had this at Global Brew. Pours reddish brown with a off white head. Taste sour, fruity, cherries. I thought this was great. I would definitely drink this again.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
On tap at local pub. Very nice fruit & sour aroma followed by a strong, but not overwhelming sour & malt flavors. An approachable & enjoyable sour.

I was lucky to find this at a local store. Last of a case that somehow didn¬ít sell out. This was a great example of a sour brown style, and I looked it so much that I will be looking for more of this style.

The last La Folie on tap at Whole Foods. Two bottles in storage.
When I heard of this beer long before the Lips of Faith incarnation & having lived in Belgium 30 years ago, I spent a long time to tracking it down.
My first and only "Big Bomber" took me 5 years to find, and another 5 to age.
Since than I have had it as I often as I can, now that NB is here in the deep South.
Having drank sours most of my mature beer life, I can tell for us here Stateside, this beer is near perfection.
The aroma is typical and to character - if you can¬ít stand the funk, funking get out of the kitch.
The pour is perfect, color head and retention.
There¬ís a great satisfaction of the first sip and the slight pucker before the full on tart hits your tongue.
It¬ís all smiles after that. I have been drinking this style awhile, and only wish I can get the other examples more often. Here¬ís to more sour in a sweet life. What¬ís wrong with some more balance?
This is near perfection.
user_location: Armpit of the Panhandle, Florida, USA

text: I really enjoyed this beer, very tart with some sweetness of vanilla from the barrel aging, there is some sourness with some earthy notes as well. A very different and unique beer
It's smells like a funky wet sock. But the flavor is outstanding! Has a nice sweet candy flavor that has a great tartness to it.

The 2014. Smells atrocious, but the flavor is pretty awesome. Sour apple, some cherry. Really pretty awesome. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bottle. Dark red with an off white head. Aroma is tart dark fruit and funk. Taste adds some tart cherry and cherry skins. Medium sticky mouthfeel and light carb. Very nice.

Bottle. Dark ruby. Sour bite on the aroma with a cherry funk. The taste adds oak barrel and sweet sour malts. Bitter bite on the mouthfeel. Love this one. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Vibrant red. sour cherry that kicks you from start to finish. Not overwhelming but definitely tart. Delicious

22oz bottle - pours a vibrant red . Sour apple aroma . Taste is super tart , sour cherry . Very tasty . 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

C&C shared by mcbackus. Aroma is a tart hair raising sour. Pour is brownish red. Taste is initially puckering and tart. Then after a few sips it is much more drinkable. Sourbess stays through out but shows off some amazing malt sweetness. Really good balance of malt and sour.

Bottle share thanks to Mcbackus.  Corked and caged, no NB logo on bottle  - 2005 or 2006 vintage .  Mostly clear, amber color, no head.  Big tart aroma, sour, cherry, semisweet, malty, more tartness in aroma.  Extremely sour and tart, cherry, very acidic, fruit juice...so good.

Bottle. Pours a dark red brown with light had and minimal lacing. Aroma is nice and sour, with hints of sweetness. Palate is moderate, thinner than I expected. Taste is immediately sour and intense with a crisp, sweetly sour finish. 7% ABV. Really good sour ale.
Glass from Red Hot. Reddish brown minimal fizz. Aroma of cherries and oak. Very tart and acidic. Great sour!

Draught at Backcountry Pizza. Dark ruby color, pink head. Sour taste with cherries, tart, acidic notes, toast, apples and earthy notes. Sour finish with cherries, acidic notes and tart. Excellent sour.

A sweet tart aroma from this deep deep red slightly hazy brew with a tanish head. Heavy on the tart with sweetness bouncing back and forth through out. Medium bodied and good carb. Its very refreshing and pallet clensing. A great brew. Very complex yet so good.
Dark brown pour with off white head. Aroma is tart sour and a little sweet. Taste is tart and sourm finishes dry.

Appearance - muddish brown

Aroma - can't smell much

Mouth - med high carb 

Taste - sour and dry. More dry than grand cru. More tart than sour. Fruity but bot as champagne like as others. 

Overall - really good. I like it. It's more dry than my favorite grand cru. Still very good. Not as in your face.

UPDATED: JUN 28, 2014 Bottleshare thanks to mcbacus. Pours a cloudy brown with white head. Aroma is tart, sour, a tad malty. taste is tart up front, a bit sour, then the sweetness cleans the palate. Good ass old beer.

Red-amber with small off-white head. Red wine vinegar aroma. Taste- tart berry, red wine, rhubarb, vinegar and slight oak.  Very sour with long sour berry finish. One of the more sour Sours I¬íve had. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Better pucker up for this beer, it's a sour brown!! Love new Belgium, just not this one.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours a red/brown. Aroma of brown sugar, cherry, apple, and some oak and vanilla. Taste is sour cherry, granny smith apples, oak, and maybe a little rotten plum. Medium body, medium tartness, and a bit dry. I enjoyed this one.

Draught at St. Augustine¬ís, VancouverDark amber color, hazy, with compact head. The aroma is a bit sour and fruity, but nice. The mouthfeel is dry and violently acidic, lemony, with traces of red grapes, raspberry, vinegar.Too much sourness, and I can¬ít find elegance in this one.
Incredible! Great fruity smell that has a wine like quality. Also looks like a brown/red wine more than a beer. Only bitch is the tartness, but I kinda like that too...

Bottle to tulip
Aroma of sour cherry, oak, brown sugar, apple. It¬ís a reddish brown with a very creamy, long lasting, 3mm off white head with no lacing. Taste is sour cherry, raisins, and vinegar. I¬ím really enjoying this.
Reddish brown of color iwth a beige head. An aroma of prunes, raisins, sweets and sugar. A flavor of sugar, raisins, prunes and weak sour.
I¬íve never really been in to sours, until now. I love the complexity and the apple aftertaste. La Folie opened up a new genre of beers for me.
Tap. Definitely sour. Can¬ít say I nit ant "brown" flavor but it is a hazy mahogany. Very sweet aroma. Considering its rating, I expected more.

650 ml bottle. Pours a very dark mahogany with very little head. Aromas of wet wood, sugary raisins, tobacco, and vinegar. Flavors of sour cherries, brown sugar, balsamic vinegar, and citrus. Quite smooth for a sour though more of an Oud Bruin than a standard Rodenbach.
I had the 2013 La Folie. This is a great brown/red sour. Reminds me of Wicked Weed¬ís Oblivion. I really pick up the sour apples and has a perfect finish.
Mahogany pour with a creamy white head. Aroma of wheat, tart cherries, tart apple and booty hole funk. Taste is tart cherry pie, armpit cheese and hella funky toe jam citrus.

This is a situation where the whole is greater than the sum of the parts. The aroma is vinous, grapey and sour. The beer itself is very sour, earthy, medium sweet with some tongue-curling astringency. Cood carbo, twangy. Unripe fruit and tannic notes. On tap, Baby Proof.
On tap. Dark brown with ruby hint. Smells like grape juice. Tart taste and sour cherries. Not my favorite style, but good.

A nice sour, but tremendously overhyped. The sourness predominates, with the medium body being held up by a good malt base. I find it is lacking some of the funk complexity that I enjoy in wild ales, particularly a lack of barnyard and brett/lactobacylus character that pierces through. Like most of New Belgium¬ís stuff, I find it a tad plain and even bland.
Very Distinct taste. Definatly had a sour tinge. Aftertaste was actually really good. I would be good for one pint of this in an evening, not any more than that.
On tap at Tap House Grill. Sour and very dry with notes of immature apples and vinegar. A bit of basement aromas as well. Not for the sweet toothed ...

Amazing. Pours a red brown color with a small tan head. Medium lgiht body. Aroma of caramel, vanilla, slight oak. Sour cherry. Taste is sour cherry, green apple, slight vanilla, oak, maybe another non descript dark fruit. Finish is dry, sour, tart and goes on for miles.....excellent!
On tap at Harry¬ís Hofbrau. Sour cherry and earthen aromas. Clear reddish brown with a light tan head and moderate low lacing. Head remains only as a collar. Crisp, sour cherry. Puckering dryness.

5/23/2014. 22 oz. bottle. Dark brown with a tan head. Funky aromas, oak, dried fruit, yeast. Bitter right off the first sip, fruity flavors with spice and earthy notes. Very balanced and complex once it opens up.

Pours deep brown with a full ephemeral head into a snifter. Nose is sour, winey, oaky. Faint smoke. Smells great. Taste is green apple, molasses notes, oak, apple cider vinegar, sour cherry. Effervescent carbonation, medium to light mouthfeel. Funky. Thirst quenching and delicious. Finish is dry and lingering. Really well done.

Pours a clear medium brown with one finger of creamy tan head receding slightly to a dense cap, heavy lacing. Nose is apple cider vinegar, sour cherries, and a sweet toasty maltiness, with hints of leather and musty oak as it warms. Taste follows suit but is less sweet than suggested by the nose, with a building sour aftertaste. Mouth feel is medium-bodied and prickly sour, with a dry finish.

Wow - this is a stupendous Flanders brown. . There¬ís not a single negative thing I can say about this: nice depth to the flavour, with a bold yet not overwhelming sourness that¬ís tempered perfectly by a toasted malt sweetness that never becomes cloying; the persistent carbonation keeps the mouth feel crisp without being fizzy; and there¬ís a pleasantly dry finish despite the lingering sour aftertaste. The ABV is high enough to deliver a decent kick yet be completely absent from the nose or tongue. Even the appearance is perfect.

2014 bottle. Surprised I didn¬ít rate last years version. I sure drank enough of it. I also preferred it to this one -- I thought it was more balanced and more complex. It¬ís a little harsh on the finish. This is still a nice sour beer. You can do better but maybe not on a given trip the the liquor store, depending on time and place. They¬íre still pasteurizing these, right? Woulda been fun to see how it develops. I think it could use a little more complexity. But for a relatively big-production sour, it¬ís very good.

2014 draft pour. Pours ruddy brown, slight cream head. Slightly fruity aroma, but of funk. Taste is a great big fruity tart upfront hit. That fades to pleasant dark fruits, wood, wine grapes,a but of vanilla. Overall balanced and a great beer.

This is an awesome Rodenbachish sour that in many ways excels versus its Belgian cousin. Hugely sour at the onset this finishes with a complex fruity sweetness that puts you right in to Nirvana. This is addicting and makes me sad that there are so many DIPAs out there and so few sour rockstars like this.
user_location: People¬ís Republic of Bloomington, Indiana, USA

text: Bottle. Poured dark red with a weak white head. Big sour cherry aroma. Big time funky sour cherry flavor with a really dry finish. Damn!
Ruby tinted dark brown pour. Small off white head that quickly falls and leaves a little lacing. Caramel aroma with a slight acetic note. Taste is tart acetic malt. Pleasant.

Aroma is funkiness, earthiness, some cherry and slight vinegar presence. Taste is a slightly smooth sour body. The sour characteristics finish well. The body is a clear amber with a pearl white head that retains fairly well.

Bomber at binkies. Another year of the funk. Love this beer. Not as funky as last year, but I think it is better. Wineagerish, finish lingers which is nice. I will age a few, but enjoy a few more. Cheers!

14-MAY-2014, draft @Churchkey Washington DC.
Almost clear mahogany with lasting, lacing tan head.
Aroma is winegar, nail polish remover, fruit, oak, tartness. Taste is sour, vinegar, more fruity than aroma, oak. Medium body, high carbonation. Long, long sour but still quite mellow aftertaste. Lovely.
2014 bottle. Good sour funk and a decent amount of body. Darker in color and interesting

Tallahassee, Fl - Whole Foods - 22 oz bomber picked up from the shelf- consumed at the bar (great concept!). Dark brown pour with rusty tinges, soft off-white head. Aroma is strong with some fresh roasty notes. Flavor has a strong sour profile with plenty of sweet tart candy notes, with a nice roasted burnt essence to it. Nice, thick mouthfeel. As with most sours, difficult for me to place appropriate descriptors to describe the sourness appropriately, but this one sits right, .

I bought this beer for $8.99 at the Breeze In, valley location, Juneau Alaska.
I poured this into a tulip.
The appearance was a nice dark brown color with some ever so slight ruby to red edges. The head was less than a half a finger with a solid clingy white lacing sticking mighty finely to the sides of the glass.
The smell was a decent sour to tart fruity aroma indicating amounts of apples and peaches with a decent woody edge to it. There is a nice earthiness coming out as well.
The taste is sour leading with the peaches and apples taking over a nice tart background. The aftertaste is soured peaches and apples to end up leading into a dry sour and tart finish.
On the palate, it sits about a medium on the body. The quality of sessionability is somewhat there as I see its a 7% beer noted on the bottle. The carbonation for this one, hmmm....well, its actually somewhat smooth and crisp.
Overall, Flanders Oud Bruin, well, this sure is according to style. I get it for the most part however, I¬ím still not sold on this style. Its nice to review because I finally understand this style but still consider it a bit over rated. To me, I most likely wouldn¬ít have this again, but if you like that mouth puckering sourness that wishes to suck your lips off of your face, I say go for this.

2013 Very dark ruby red, light head that dissipates. Nose is heavy oak, cherry, cranberry. Flavor is same plus lemon acidity, sourdough, granny smith, and hints of currants. Medium bodied, moderate tannins, very dry.
Aroma is cherries, slight nuttiness, malts and mild mustiness. The flavor is cherries, fruit, earthy notes, malts and a long mix of brett/tart in the finish.

UPDATED: MAY 13, 2014 22oz bottle, thanks to Dan for sharing. 2014 vintage. Man, this is fan-tastic! The hype is deserved, from the first sip and first smell. A lot going on in the nose. Cherry, vanilla, big oak. Light spice. Good bigger sour taste, big tannin. Medium-plus body, light nice slickness in the finish for the sour cherry vanilla oak flavor to linger on. Seeing the light earthiness; a very light spiciness. Fantastic, flavorful, and bold beer for sure. Unlike the Arctic Soiree I just tried before this, this is not a bottle I could chief all on my own, it was a great one to share 2 ways. Despite being a tad bit lighter in ABV than the arctic soiree, this beer has a much more bold flavor. The light lingering slick texture in the finish also impedes drinkability a bit. This is not supposed to be an easy-drinking smooth downable beer, though. It¬ís a potent, flavorful bold beer that is made for sharing and worth every bit of the $19. A very special, satisfying sour brown to sip on. Reminds me of Rodenbach quite a bit... Any Rodenbach fan should give this a try.

650ml bottle from Healthy Spirits, San Francisco, CA

Pours dark reddish brown with a small white head. Aroma of tart berries, wood, oak, yeast and lactic notes. Taste is sour, yeasty and lactic with notes of tart berries, wood and oak. Finish is yeasty and tartish with notes of berries, sourness and wood. Quite balanced and complex.

2014. I actually liked the Love: Felix a little better. Pours reddish hue with great head and lacing. Sour plum and funkiness a la Rodenbach. Finishes fizzy sour with good body. Some citrus and light fruit, nice. Tap at Churchkey.

650ml bottle pours amber color with a 2 finger white head that dissipates quite quickly leaving some spotty lacing behind. Aroma is yeast and barnyard. Taste is a lemon sourness with a granny smith apple tartness followed with an underlying malty sweetness and earthy notes. Medium bodied with lots of carbonation. A decent sour ale.

Draft (2014) at ChurchKey, thanks solidfunk! Pours dark reddish brown with off-white head. Aromas of vinegar, tart fruit. Tasting notes of tart notes, vinegar, dark fruit. Medium body with a dry finish. Possibly my favorite from New Belgium.

Deep brown color but still clarity. Aromas of sour, lemons, cinnamon, cardamom, and gin botanicals. Taste is big Lacto and sour up front but still restrained. Nice tannins and a wine like finish. Really good.

2014 bomber from Tipples. Pours deep dark ruby red with a small off white to light khaki head. Aroma of black cherry, sour cherry, vinegar, other sweet dark fruits. Flavor is massively puckering sour apple up front, some dark cherries, some dry oak and hint of oaky vanilla. Lingering dry and sweet and sour on the palate. Medium high carbonation and medium body. On the sweeter side but a nice little sour.

UPDATED: MAR 14, 2015 2015 edition bottle. Pours a dark red color with a lively head. Aroma is sweet, cranberry, raspberry, maybe a slightly darker plum note as well, maybe strawberry, and a backbone of some maltiness to carry it all. Taste is very sour, cranberry on the forefront, some tart raspberry, and a great maltiness for the aftertaste. Overall a great beer again, extremely drinkable, great sour that makes you pucker, a slightly more sour version of the benchmark Rodenbach.

New Belgium Lips of Faith 2014 bottle. Pours a nice dark ruby red with a brown head. Aroma is a little acidic with notes of raspberries and cranberries, and a slight bit of sweetness. Taste is pretty big. Notes of cranberries, raspberries, green sour apple, strawberries. The French oak in this mellows this beer out very nicely. Decently sour with lots of flavor. One of the best sours I have had.

UPDATED: MAY 6, 2014 2014 La Folie - Lips of Faith bottle. Orange brown, low golden head. Berry, light leather, orange peel, vanilla aroma. Lactic sour, and not in a elegant way. Fruity notes behind that, barn, leather, sour green apples. medium body, puckering dry. Unbalanced, lacks some fruitiness to stand up against the battery acid. I love sour beers, but this one became undrinkable after a while, could not finish the bottle.
Pearlescent brown with a light head. Tart light grainy smell. Nice full mouth feel but still light and refreshing. A mild grain taste with a perfect sour with citrus lemon spikes.
22oz bottle shared with friends. Pours a dark reddish brown with lots of carbonation. Tart apple aroma. Super sour and awesome. Wish I could have gotten

Poured brown hue with reddish tint. White fizzy head that dissipated to a white slick. Aroma is floral, acetic, cherry, blackberry, lactic, honey. Mouthfeel is fantastic with a medium light body and nice carbonation. Taste is dry throughout with a sourness following and a dry acidic ethanol finish. Overall this is a great Flanders brown! I could drink this pretty much anywhere & anytime of the year.
Funky, monkey smell, light brown color, the taste is of sour fruit, very tangy and bitter. After the swallow the sour/tangy taste lingers but not very strong, which is perfect.

UPDATED: OCT 1, 2015 Draft pour at Special Brews.  Pours a dark cloudy brown color with a foaming tan head.  Sour dark fruit aroma, so off to a great start. Very sour up front with a lot of cherry and dark fruit. It¬ís just about everything I look for in a sour dark beer. Love it.  Update:  Had this a few times since and it¬ís still a great beer.  Filled a growler of the 2013 version.  Dark ruby pour.  A bit of a woody flavor I don¬ít quite remember but for the most part, this is a fantastic beer.  Great stuff.
Update again:  2015, 22 oz bottle, poured into my New Belgium glass acquired at the brewery.  I¬íd like to think I¬ím using it properly.  Dark brown pour with a swirling tan head.  Dry, oaky dark fruit aroma.  Fruit sweet, and oak flavor up front, with a pucker heavy, sour palate finish.  Gets more and more sour as you go.  Vintages are always fun, but I absolutely love this beer fresh.  One of the original sour beers that I ever loved, and still to this day it¬ís amazing.  Awesome beer.

Aroma is sour like apples. Dark brown pour with nice tan head pretty good retention for a sour. Puckering upon first taste but let's go towards the middle blending to a nice Malt body caramel maybe dark fruit it finishes to a nice oak flavor. Only thing I might say is it has a little too many tannins for me but still a very good sour. Similar to rodenbach in many ways

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
2013 bottle. Deep brown with red tints and a bit of a tan head. Aroma is very tart up front with some red fruits to follow. Flavor is great, tart red fruit with a solid malt backbone. Great stuff.

~Tart aroma, leather, apple, prune, and raisin.
~Pours a reddish brown color with quickly disappearing white head.
~Tart flavor of apple, hay, leather, woodsy, and earthy.
~medium light bodied, medium co2, long lasting tart finish.
~This is a delicious beer, but overrated in my opinion and too expensive.

On tap 4 oz. sample at the Lost Dog Cafe in Merrifield, VA. 

Clear, mahogany with a small off-white head and a modicum of lacing. 

Aroma of tart dark fruit, cranberry and roasted malt. 

Taste of tart dark fruit, strawberries, roasted malt, vinegar and cranberries. 

Medium body and medium/low carbonization.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle to glass. Pours a mostly clear ruby color with hints of brown and a small brownish head. Aroma is dry, touches of wood, mild tart. Flavor packs a sour punch, with some amber malt sweetness. Light to medium in body with a strong lingering sour character. Fantastic beer!

Tart sour fruit smells, apples, cranberries kind of. Slightly oaky aromas as well as taste. Super sour and tart fruit feeling and mouthwatering. Not very funky. Oh. My. God. If I could only drink this forever I would not complain.
Aroma is nutty, sourness, caramel. Taste, sour, sour, sour, nuts, caramel, some sweetness. Interesting.
On tap at new Belgium. Pours slightly muddy amber brown. Smell is amazing, green apples and cranberries. No foot smell that some sours get. Taste incredibly sour fruity.

2013 bottle. Nice fruity aroma with slight oak taste. Very sour taste but enjoyable. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Hands down. Best beer I have had from New Belgium. 32 oz growler for $7.99. Yes please. Pours a just hazy red brown with white head. Scent is a touch of body odor mixed with sour grapes. In that good way. Sour with a just there sweet finish. Lively fun on the tongue. Draft - My Friends Growler Shop - Atlanta, GA
Nice sour with a bit of pumpkin or pearfeeling aroma. Darker amber in color with a tan head. Tart start with a cola kinda after taste. Very enjoyable.

On tap at Hunahpu day. Murky red brown. Classic Flanders red sour acidity on the aroma. Taste is the same yet kind of thin for a non-fruity sour. Finish is thin with a lingering acidity. Good Flanders Red but I think it needs more of the malt body for added complexity.

650ml bottle. Reddish brown shade with light tan foam. Aroma is nicely complex: cherry, red grape, apple fruitiness. Smokier, dark malt presence too. Pretty sour but as not much as I expected; much oakier on the other hand. Lactic yoghurt influence. Fairly high carb. Quite delicious.
Bottle - decent amount of fruit with sour and vinegar notes. Not as vinous as others but still better than decent.
Pours clear brown ruby small beigish head. Aromatic vinous sour vinegar fruity.
Deep red black color with little head. Instantly rich red wine flavor, blackberries, and a ton of lip puckering sour. Very good beer.

Great sample pour from draft. Deep raspberry color, no head. Aroma comes in with raspberry and darker fruit. Vinegar notes. Flavor follows suit, citric notes, sharp, balsamic and raspberry vinegar. Clean and nice. I definitely I dig this one.

I credit this beer for getting me to start trying sours. I do not, however, want to give krompt any credit for getting me into sours even though he shared this bottle with me but he did redeem himself with this. Mainly because he started me with a sour previous to this that tasted like straight vinegar thinking I was man enough to appreciate but it humbled me because clearly I wasn¬ít quite as good a beer snob as I thought I was.

Thanks to Bytemesis for the intro to sour beers. Bomber pours like a fizzy cola with a small, quickly dissipating head. Aromas of, caramel, nuts, tart dark cherries, and oaky wood. Flavor is a slap in the face sour cherry ball. It¬ís growing on me. Pretty tasty.

Just a great beer regardless of style. Real sour taste from the beginning that mellows out as your taste buds melt. Brown ale behind it that is full of flavor and makes you want to drink more. Awesome beer.

Draft at Max¬ís Sour Fest. Pours hazy dark ruby copper with a fizzy off white head. Tastes sour, tart, like raspberries, blueberries, yeast and faint raisins. Light/medium body and low carbonation. Smells like musky grapes, raisins, and sugar.

Pours a clear reddish brown with a light brown head that has good retention. Aroma of plums, black cherries, currants, green apples and a hint of vanilla oak. Taste is intense fruitiness a sharp sour character thats puckering and a touch astringent, red wine like character that finishes dry. Medium bodied with moderate carbonation...light, crisp and refreshing. Great Flanders Red.

Tap at Max¬ís Sour Fest. Pours mostly clear dark amber/light brown with thin, off-white head. Aroma is fig, dates, cookie malts, sugarplums, light caramel, and faint vanilla. Flavor is fresh sour fruit forward with light malty sweetness before drying out with an oaky and lightly tart finish. Light/medium body and medium carbonation.
A cinnamon spice vinegar aroma with a tart fruity flavor. Dark reddish brown color and fizzy head with a slight oily palate. A great standard sour.

2014 batch on tap at New Belgium. Appearance: finger of khaki head, amber color, lightly cloudy. Aroma: wine, vinegar, sour candy. Palate: light body, average carbonation, dry finish. Taste: very sharp sour with some sweetness on either end. Overall, I love this beer. One of the best sours I have ever had. Lovely.

22oz bottle (2013 vintage) pours cloudy dark reddish brown with a small finger of head. Nose is musty tart dark cherries and earthy cola funk, dank wood, soil. Taste is woody oak, tart cherry and berry, vanilla, funk, red pepper, touch of vinegar but in a good way. Finish is tart funky wood and cherry, some red wine, subtle red apple, nice fruity berry. Very well executed for the style, great sour.
Pretty sour, but otherwise evenly balanced. I prefer more tart, but there are nice sweet apple and caramel notes as well.
On tap at Riverview. Poured amber orange with no head. Aroma of oak and fruit apple. Med light carb with med bod. Taste of sour apple mostly.
If you want a strong, sour, complex beer, this is your goal. An explosion of flavor that is a delight to experience - albeit in moderation given intensity of flavors.

Big bottle thx to adnielsen (trade) cons 2013-12-21 G√∂teborg vintage 2012
AR: ripe grapes, spicey
AP: mahogny 
F: sour, tart, dry, kriek, almond nutty

Bottled: 06APR09

A: rusty red with a finger of dirty tan foam which dissipates in a minute to leave an etched mirror surface over an excellently clarified beer. No lace.
S: Oak, tart, cherry, red wine vinegar. I dig.
T: Tart, sweet, hollow, tannins without being bitter or dry. 
M: thin with moderate carb.
O: my favorite flander¬ís probably besides dissident (with a year or two on it).

Serving type: bottle

11-13-2011

I am an IPA drinker who is rapidly becoming a fan of sour beer. I pretty much like everything about this, from its sour apple nose to its sour and mildly astringent taste and mouthfeel. My only regret is its alcohol content, which prevents me from kicking back at my favorite pub and sipping the afternoon away.

Vintage 2012.¬† Une robe rouge√¢tre sur laquelle flotte un anneau de mousse.¬† Un nez piqu√© par certains microbes.¬† Des ar√¥mes de m√ªres sauvages.¬† Des effluves de terre chocolat√©e.¬† Aucune aigreur mena√ßante.¬† Un doux effet de balsamique.¬† Des pommes vertes et rouges.¬† Des licornes et Heidi Klum qui court sur une plage de Sunny Isles.¬† Un go√ªt sublim√©.¬† Mes papilles qui restent la bouche ouverte.¬† Un c√¥t√© malt√© qui emp√™che toute exag√©ration vinaigr√©e.¬† Des petites baies surettes qui explosent sous mes dents.¬† Lorsque le liquide se temp√®re, une superbe repr√©sentation d¬í√©quilibre et de folie.¬† Une savoureuse proposition.¬† Petra Nƒõmcov√° qui me souffle dans le cou.¬† Sur mon palais, un corps p√©tillant qui montre une texture l√©g√®rement vineuse.¬† Une finale tannique qui attaque all√®grement l¬íensemble des tissus de ma bouche.¬† Une proposition tr√®s et trop facile √† boire, superbe, fantastique, chim√©rique, √©pique, extraordinaire, fabuleuse, f√©erique, formidable, grandiose, hom√©rique, incroyable, inou√Øe, irr√©elle, magique, merveilleuse, mirifique, prodigieuse, renversante, stup√©fiante et folle.

One of my first sours back in the day. Still real good. Red brown with disappearing head. Nose of apple, vinegar, and citrus. Super sourness at front gives way to sweeter, sugary finish. Green apple all the way. Lighter mouthfeel with nice carbonation. Good stuff.

UPDATED: JUN 16, 2014 Cloudy brown-red, deeper tan head.  Strawberry, grassy aroma.  Some vanilla.  Very sour, some tang.  Quite dry through the finish.  Incredibly acidic, very lively.  Medium body.  Very big, but reasonably well balanced. Excellent beer.

Draft->snifter at Iron Horse. Dark amber with offwhite film. Tart and sour fruit, cherries, berries, vinegar, wood. Decent mouthfeel, pursing finish. Quite good, best of the Lips of Faith series for me.

Reddish brown colour, dissipating white head. Aroma of acetic vinegar, red fruits, wood, apple and citrus. Sour flavour, fruity, apple, citrus, quite tart. Bit thin body. Sour finish, citrus and apple. Decent, albeit quite straightforward sour.
(From 66cL bottle @ ZZT VIIIb, Oirschot 2013. Thanks for sharing, joes!)
Pours a dark orange slightly unclear beer with a good white head. Smells sour. Tastes heavy sour with a sweet finish. Lively carbo, thin body and a watery texture.

22oz bottle. Murky rusty brown with a spotty light beige head. Aroma of musty wet wood, malt vinegar, cherries and light fruit. Flavor is fairly tart upfront with sour vinegar, light caramel malt and a dry alcohol. Medium to light body with a dry mouth feel. Have had this one numerous times, always a nice beer if your in the mood.
Zzt¬í13. Bruine kleur, niet helder, geen schuimkraag. Ruikt zuur, fruitig. Smaakt zuur en fruitig.

Bottle @ ZZT 8 shared by Joes. Clear red color, virtually no head. Aroma is quite sweet, some red fruits, slightly sour. Taste is quite fruity, quite dry, quite sour, but pretty nicely balanced. Medium body and carbonation. Nice one!
Bottle @ ZZT9 thx to joes. Murky red with a small off-white head. Smells sour, fruity, cherry, minty. Tastes sour, fruity, berry, cherry, lemony sour. Thin to medium body, soft carbo.

On tap at Naja?s. Reddish-brown with little head and no lacing. Aroma of tart cherries, vinegar, and wood. Taste is similar with not too much puckering sourness, moderate carbonation, crisp mouthfeel, and a dry finish.
Great lacto development with a round body. Finishes nice but a little thin. Fantastic aroma with a good development on the palate.
Cloudy brown with a light layer on foam. Sour sour apple aroma. Tart sour apple up front with a malty oak finish. Very nice.
Pour is reddish brown with a small tan head. Good head retention. Aroma of dark fruits (cherry, raspberry, plum) and slight vinegar. Flavor is better with notes of oak, sour acidity, and dark fruits.

Draft to growler at state line..what a nice surprise to find this..medium brown color slight haze with small head..aroma is great bursting with fruit..cherry..sour apple..fig..tartness almost comes through the nose.trace of vinegar..mouthfeel is stellar..light to medium bodied with layers of complexity sending just the right amount of puckering sourness without overwhelming and it does finish with a dry quality..what a tasty offering..glad to be able to fill up a growler..excellent stuff..well done..

Pours a deep, reddish brown with a tan head and lacing. It has a great aroma of sour cherries and some funk and other dark fruit. The flavor is strong cherries up front leading to a great sour finish over a medium body.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
22oz bottle pours a hazy reddish brown pour with a tan head. Sour fruit aroma and taste.
Bomber, heavy bubblegum aroma with some meaty and juicyfruit notes. Rich and creamy profile sliced with heavy acetic. Lots.going on here, a really fantastic sour.
Tap at kegstand...dark pour with thin off white head...sweet aroma..taste is freaking incredible...love it..one of the best sours ive had

I have been wanting to try this one for sometime and finally got a hold a bottle. It did not disappoint me. Smelled like a pretty typical sour, yeasty fermented, slight fruity aroma. Appearance was brown with very small red or copper hue when held to the light. Taste was awesome, not your typical sour red. It had more of a tart cranberry than sour cherry. Which was a surprisingly nice change. Overall a must try for a fan of sour beers.

On tap at Flanny¬ís in a tulip. Pours an occluded dark mahogany with a brief, one-finger, white head. Nice understated nose of sour cherries, damp leather, light lactic acid, and musty oak barrels. Very tart taste to start with prickly funkiness, a bit of soured red wine, earthy oak tannins, and some dark cherries and green apples. Some sweetness creeps in late to help temper the sourness before it pops up again at the finish. A solid Flanders-style sour.

2013 in 2013. Reddish brown, thick fast fading head. Cranberry and red wine nose, touch of funk. Taste follows, but drinks very smooth. Super food friendly, nice acid. Mouthwatering pucker. Whole greater than the sum of it¬ís parts. See why this is a standard bearer for sours. Wish New Belgium didn¬ít gouge for this stuff in CO. Ain¬ít right.

Poured from a bottle. Pours a rich brown color. Aromas of sour cherry and cranberry, sweet caramel, and hints of wood underneath. Tastes tart with a bit of sweetness in the middle and then a really nice tart finish. Tartness is cranberry, sour cherry, and a hint of green apple. Finish is quite nice and long-lasting and encourages you to take another drink. For a sour beer lover, this is an excellent sample with a very reasonable price.

Capped 2011 bottle. Really interesting. It starts with a tart, sour punch and then I swear it finishes slightly sweet like meaty cherries. I also like how it doesn¬ít get very acidic, even as it warms. Well done and true to style. I like how it has stayed good even with it being produced in larger quantities these days compared to the old C&C vintages.

I have come to appreciate the style more and this is well done. Sourness comes up in the aroma with some fruit. The color is dark golden with a white head. Puckering mouthfeel that covers everything. Decent carbonation. Sour is the predominant flavor here with some wood and fruits. No hops detected. Not a go-to for me but good all the same.

A: Brownish/Red Hue, Passes Mild Light, Off White Head, Some Lacing

S: Apple Cider Vinegar, Oakey, Sour Mash

T: Sour Cherries, Apricots, Sour Mash

M: Decent Carbonation, Medium Bodied, Semi Sour

Overall, pretty solid brown sour ale, astringent but not over bearing.

This beer arrived a dark amber color. The head was a quarter inch in height, and receded slowly into a ring of lacing which left some foam sticking to the sides of the glass. The aroma is tart, sour, acidic, with moderate yeast barnyard notes, hints of plum, and fainter hints of wood. The taste is of more tartness, more sourness, with hints of malt, hints of barnyard, and a great pucker factor. The mouthfeel is medium bodied with fine carbonation, and a silky texture. Overall, this is a great beer...a nearly perfect beer. I would love to drink this regularly, and really wish it was more widely available.

UPDATED: OCT 1, 2014 10/5 2013: On draft at New Belgium. Pours dark rose red almost brown. Aroma I start cherry sour nice. Taste is tart dry burst of flavor, red wine, vinegar, plumb. 3.9

10/1/2014: At Stephen¬ís 2nd annual Great American Beer Festival Tasting on 10/1/14. 2009 c&c. Pours murky almond. Aroma is medium plus acidity, light cherry, not much funk, some sweetness. Taste is really nice for an oud bruin, one of the better ones I have had. Really sour, makes me almost sweat, but still really nice, not much barrel coming through, cherry is there, but not super authentic tasting. Really nice, a real sour, nothing wrong with it. I would give this to any of my non-beer people friends as a good example of a sour. 4.0
On tap at new belgium. Pours a dark brownish red. Aroma is fruity and tart. Taste is sour, spicy, hoppy. Really delicious.
Solid beer here. Really nice tartness. A little pricey for the bottle though. Definitely would have again.

Had the 2010 La Folie that had been aging for 3 years and poured it into a snifter. Amazing sour brown aroma. Some lacing on the glass. Sweet fruity and slightly tart flavor with a dry finish. An amazing sour for sure. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Pours amber with nice off white head and some lacing. Tart and slightly sour. Cherries and fruit. Dry finish. Very nice.

A very different taste! Fruity and strong, just a small head and a bit of lacing. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Keg @ Beer Run. The pour¬ís deep brownish red with a small head. The nose is jammy raspberry. Mild tartness. Funky buggy wood. Cherry compote. Mellow fruit leather. Inviting stuff. The taste is pretty damn excellent. A really good sour brown. Sweet/tart cherry and cranberry. Mild mineral. Leather, some brown bread. Crisp, nimble on the palate. Overall, pretty awesome.
2012 vintage. Deep brown like a root beer. Fizzy short head. Aroma is tartness, a bit of feet, light fruit. Taste is vinegar, green apple. Medium body, very dry. Good stuff.

On tap at Clarkston Union. Nice but not much of a bite. Poor finish, good flavor and nice aroma

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

bottle shared by jean-micha√´l, thanks bro! pours unclear light brown, red tint, with a small light beige-orange cap, some retention and lacing. woody, oaked cherries, leather, tobacco, nice acidity profile - acetic, citric and lactic, bit of earthiness and stone fruits. average carbonation, medium body, very nice woody-fruity, bold yet welcoming acidic and grassy finish. classic and everything as it should be - excellent rendition! much enjoyed it!

Bottle. Pours brown with an off who¬íre head. Aroma of sour red berries, malt, some peppery notes and some cellar notes. Flavor is sour and somewhat malty with cherries, caramel, lemon and vinegar. Medium body, average carbonation.

Bottle 650ml @ Hotel Room, Hacienda Hotel LAX, El Segundo, CA
Pours slightly hazy amber/brown with a off-white head. Aroma has notes of malt, sour berries, citric acid, wood and hint of caramel. Taste is light sweet and medium sour with a long vinous, dry, sour and berry finish. Body is light to medium, texture is thin, carbonation is soft.

Bottle, 22oz. As Lips of Faith Sour Brown Ale. It pours an off-white head of moderate size, with nice lacings. Amber in color. The aroma has some balsamic vinegar, with earthy, woody notes, caramel and dark dried fruits. It¬ís full-bodied and soft on the palate, lightly tart, with a pleasant carbonation level. There¬ís caramel, dried fruits, sour berries, vinegar hints, earthy hints and a lemony touch in the flavor. Lasting finish. A really pleasant sour, balanced, tasteful and sort of quenching. 130822
Bottle ¬í13 from City Beer. Pours a deep reddish brown with a small white head. Aroma of tart cherries, Tastes of tart cherries, raspberries and very earthy with a dry finish.

Draught @ Smoke & Barrel, D.C.
Pours dark reddish-brown. Negligible head. Little nose, almost like cassis.
Green apple-flavour to start, sticks to the top of your mouth a bit. Mildly earthy, dry finish. OK, but a bit one-dimensional.

2013 vintage, bottle. Iced-tea brown, shimmering ruby when backlit. Moderate coarseness, tan carbonation, fast rate of decay to placid surface. Aroma is tart blackberry with grass/vegetation and muddy lake after rain fall. Fairly sharp sourness, moderate acetic acid. Other berry notes (light blueberry). Medium-light body on the watery side, a bit oily, but an enduring, slightly hot, lightly prickly carbonation. flavor is a big wave of sourness, nicely infused moderate acetic, light caramel sweetness, hint of nuttiness. Bit of sour raspberry. Fruit and malt are overshadowed by sourness. Highlight is how nicely the sharp acetic tones blend into the sourness. Just the right proportion. Still, the malt sweetness is rather light here, making the beer seem less complex and balanced overall than might be expected of such a highly regarded Flanders...

Bottle with Ray, Chris and Jay. Pours lightly cloudy brown with average tan head and lace. Nose of cherry, oak, vanilla, horse, granny smith apples. Medium body, tart. Nice fruit flavors - apple, cherry, cranberry.
2012 Bottle. Tasty sour brown with a lot of cherries. A little oaky. Good beer.

Brown with a thin lacing of white head. Aroma is strong sour fruit. Flavor is sir,.acidic fruit with a strong caramel malt. Slightly bitter, with a tartness in the finish.

Wife: 4.3

I'm just not sure with this one. Crazy sour at first. Thought it was undrinkable. Kept at it and eventually adjusted. Started to like it at some point. Still, could use some sweetness and less tart. Uncompromising. Can't really get the wood either. Still, intrigued by it. Something different.

Pours a rich mahogany color with a fizzle off white head that dissipates quickly. Sour cherry, apple, grape, malt and oak aromas. Sour cherry, apple, oak, malt, and tart flavors. Very sour and carbonated with a tart finish.
clear red-brown, moderate tan head with short retention. cherry, raspberry, grape jelly, slight vinegar, oak, blackberry. very sour, very light sweet. medium body, slick feel, dry finish.

22oz bottle in a tulip. Pours deep ruby/brown with a lacy, beige head. Aroma of sweet tarts, dark malts, some oak, and light spices/earthiness. Flavor the same with a nice tart, dry finish. Average texture. A really good beer.
Really tart and sour, but incredibly quenching. Loads of sour fruits, some funk, and as the beer warms more darker flavours emerge - raisins, caramel. So good.
Strong cherry notes. Sour as sour can be. A little funky finish. Nice new Belgium. ....

'12 vintage Pours reddish brown with low white head. Aroma is funky fruits, taste is highly tart and acidic, with a long finish, great sour!

Third sour of the night..this beast does not mess around...smell is not as funky with bits of cherries...pucker up this is BY FAR the most sour beer of the night. My lips hurt,cherries...sourness. Cool.

Bottle - Raspberry jam, young red wine and a tiny bit of funk. Cloudy orange and red with no head. Raspberry, huge sourness, dry with a chalky flavour. Finish is all chalk.

This is one of the closest things to Cantillon that I¬íve encountered. I like many sours but I am most impressed by those sour enough to change to palate over the course of several sips. This is the only domestic sour I¬íve tried that does that. Otherwise it¬ís also a great beer, though probably not everyone. This is definitely more for sour fans although it is accessible as it could be while still wrecking your palate with acidity.

Draft. Aroma is sour. Appearance is a dark brown with a lasting head. The taste is sour through out but has a definite carmel malt ribbon through the sour flavor. Palate is sour, obviously. Overall, a really good sour. Would buy if i could find some.

UPDATED: MAR 31, 2017 Smells of oak barrels and sweetness. Fruity aroma, with the vinegar like sour mixed in. Brilliant smell. Taste is pucker sour. Sour overpowers the sweet very slightly, but overall is very balanced. 2015 version: seems like there is more new beer and less old aged. Not as pucker sour as it used to be. Still great and complex and Woody, but palate is almost a bit watery and lacks the complexity it used to have. Dropping 4 tenths.  2016 version similar to 2015. Not nearly as pucker sour as it used to be. Complex and woody, but body is light. Sour maybe 3 of 10, used to be more like 6 or 7.  Still very good, used to be great. Now it is more like rodenbach, used to be like rodenbach grand cru. Dropped additional tenth.  ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours a dark copper with a tan head that quickly dissipates. Notes of cinnamon, dark fruit and sourness with emphasis on sour. As I am not a sour ale expert I can't put this one in perspective but I did enjoy it. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle at Sourfest. Deep amber pour with a bubbly white head. Cherry, vinegar, oak, touches of sweet maltiness, and strong tart sourness. Strong sourness, deep cherry, oak, funky yeasts, touches of citrus and earth. Solid complexity and good beer.
bottle. Brown with small head. Has to be the one of the sourest beers I¬íve ever had. Bottle describes flavor as "puckering" and that¬ís a great adjective. Excellent flavor.

Draft. Pours dark amber brown with a short off-white that finishes as a ring. Minimal lacing. Bright, complex aroma full of lovely cinnamon spice and sour apple. Medium sour flavor. Light-medium body, oily texture, and a tart sour finish. Good balance between strong elements of sour and oak.

2008 vs 2012.

2008: Pours a deep red with thin off white head.  Aromas of apples, apple cider vinegar, barnyard.  Flavors of medium sourness with a light sweet backbone.  The vinegar was more present in this year vs the 2012.

2012: Pours a deep red with thin off white head.  Aromas of sour apples, cherries, and other sour berries.  Flavor is lip puckering sour with some mild fruit notes trying to peak through.  

I will be the first to admit, this isn¬ít my favorite style.  Although I really enjoy expanding my palate.  Overall, these beers were different.  For me, the 2008 was an easier drinking beer.
On tap at Ashley¬ís in Ann Arbor. Very nice, aggressively sour, but delicious. Cherry flavors.

UPDATED: NOV 2, 2016 New Belgium¬ís Lips Of Faith La Folie Sour Brown Ale is really something. I had the 2012 brew, and this was my first sour ale. Wow. First off, I¬íll say that when they say sour, they don¬ít mean "kinda sour" or "hints at sourness." I did not find myself struggling to "pick up on the sourness" from this beer. I found myself struggling instead to pick my face up off the floor. This is a freight-train to the mouth kind of sour.

This beer pours murky brown with very little head or lace, and the aroma is a mild malt that¬ís just dominated by something like sour cherry. The flavor is aggressive. I guess that¬ís one word for it. Honestly, all I could taste was the sourness. It¬ís more of a sour apple in terms of flavor, and not the sour cherry I thought I smelled in the aroma. There is a little spice, a little background richness, but this stuff starts sour, finishes sour, and leaves a sour aftertaste. This beer is not trying to cozy up and be your friend. You¬íll like it on its terms or you won¬ít like it at all. I cannot say I really enjoyed this beer, but I can¬ít remember the last time something bowled me over like this did. I will eventually try this style again, but not soon. I¬ím overwhelmed.  My rating here is an honest first reaction.  If I develop a taste for this style I will change my rating as appropriate.  

SECOND REVIEW, OCTOBER 2016.  I sampled this beer again three years later when I toured the brewery in Asheville.  This second review is based not just on the sample I had at the brewery. I enjoyed that sample enough to bring home a bottle, and I¬íve been sipping it this evening. As it did three years ago, La Folie pours brown with very little foam. Whereas I only picked up on malt and cherry on the aroma in 2013, I notice other notes on the aroma now. The barrel aging process is conspicuous, and there are fruity notes apparent other than cherries. In fact, this year, the main secondary characteristic I notice in the smell is apples, apple cider, and brown sugar. This beer smells amazing. 

The flavor, which was simply too heavy-handed for me three years ago, seems more nuanced and multi-faceted now. That big, aggressive sourness is still there. There¬ís no getting around that, and if sourness isn¬ít something you appreciate, you probably won¬ít like this beer any more than I did when I first tired it. I guess my taste-buds have been dialed in more carefully, because along with that huge sourness I now also pick up on very strong woody and nutty notes on the flavor. There is also a crackery, dark bread quality in the background that¬ís the best part of the exhale. This beer is layered so carefully. Sour is everywhere... if this beer were music, every note would be played in the key of sour. But there are so many more instruments here than I noticed the first time around. This beer is as dense as a symphony.

La Folie is still an uncompromising beer. If you already have a taste for sours, you will probably find much here to like. If you don¬ít, this beer is just far too aggressive to pick up as your first taste of the style. Nonetheless, I¬ím glad I did find access to the style, and glad I tasted La Folie again. If I¬ím able to find it easily enough in my area, it is going to become a regular presence.

From bottle. I¬ím generally not a huge fan of sours. This one was a bit too sour for my taste. The wood didn¬ít really come through. I got more of a fruity and malty aroma. The pour is an unattractive brown, but it¬ís a brown ale, so it¬ís not really special in any way for the style. Taste is too overpowering on the sour, which doesn¬ít allow any other notes to properly come through IMO. Decent mouthfeel.
Pours a deep red with small tan head. Smells oaky, apples, cola Tastes very sour, rich, fruity, and again- sour. Nice finish. Good beer, very good sour

Doing a vertical tonight, from ¬í¬í09 - ¬í13. Starting with the ¬í09, it pours dark not really clear amber with a dark cherry hue. Aroma is great bringing sweet cherries and some light zingy malts. The flavor has a decent amount of tart and cherries blended so well together not biting the palate but going down quite smooth. The body gets a bit better with the years going on, the ¬í11 was better than the ¬í09 and ¬í10.

2013 vintage bomber at 50¬∞; vibrantly classic deep auburn body flashing amber highlights beneath a 1", quickly fading, light khaki head decorating the vessel with a few dominant angled peninsulas, and random polka dots of lace; a lazy sour and sweet fog illuminated by sunny rays of cherry, plumb, and sweet tart with light candy bringing life to a deserted barn; amplified fruit and tartness flood the palate from a lightly drying slick body, resonating layers of everything the aroma promised

Bomber. Pours a dark copper and ruby color with an inch of light brown foam. Lots of apple cider, cherry, oak and vinegar in the aroma. The flavor is aggressively sour and tart at the start with a healthy serving of white grape, cranberry and strawberry rhubarb notes with a bit of malt and oak at the end. Mouthfeel is medium-bodied with moderate carbonation and an extremely dry, tart finish. Insanely sour but remarkably balanced and drinkable.

Clear very dark copper with ruby hues and a medium bubbly off white head. Aroma is some gently sourness cidery with nice berry notes. Flavor is vinegar with green apples and fuity acidness and some wood at the end. Medium to light palate refreshing and complex.

A - Dark mahogany brown with ruby highlights. A one finger off- white head.

S - Sour cherries, green apples, acidic grapes, brown sugar, old oak wood comes at as it warms

T - Tart granny smith apples, sour cherries, grapes, raspberries. Sharp musty wood soaked in fruit and vinegar. The oak is heavy on the finish but blends perfectly adding notes of vanilla and a touch of tannin. Finishes mouth wicking dry.

M - moderate carbonation, sharp around the edges.

Wow! This is extreme mouth puckering sour. There¬ís so many layers of sweet and sour. This went far beyond my expection!
This is simply a masterpiece!

Serving type: bottle

02-24-2011

Pours hazy brown with voluminous tan head. Aroma is dominated by sour yeasty barnyard with vague notes of vinegar. Woody notes linger. Amazing lingering sour taste with a sweet crisp finish. Amazing beer

Wife got a bomber of this, poured into small snifter glass.  Reddish brown color with light tan head.  Aroma of vinegar, some fruitiness (cherries, raspberries) and a little malt.  Taste is tart fruit (green apple, cherry, some grape), vanilla and oak notes, and caramel malt.  Light body, average carbonation, tangy, sour with a clean, tart and dry finish.  Tasty, slowly learning to appreciate sours.

Bottle from Wegmans Sterling - pours cola with a white head. Aroma is sour cherries and funky yeast. Taste is sour, like cat¬ís claws, stabbing sour and then it retreats only to claw you again. Overall, solid, but a little too aggressive for me.

Bottle from Wegman¬ís Sterling. Pours brown with an inch of khaki foam that disappears quickly. Lots of sourness on the nose. Has a bit of the vanilla from the barrel blended with the sourness. Lingers a bit. Solid for style.
Bottles thanks to Jake (11-13),  nice brown pour with some ruby tint, minimal head. Big tart cherry aroma with a little malty hint. Taste is very tart and nice cherry flavor, really dig this one.

Vinegar, tart, tangy, sour cherry, sour grape, sweet tarts, tomato, orange / lime zest, woody, funky, worchestershire/tamarind, Granny Smith

Bottle @ home ... from jarvit..It pours clear reddish brown with a medium creamy light tan head...... The aroma is vinegar, sour cherries, acid and sweet ripe fruit..... The flavor is sour, cherries, vinegar, acid and citric.... very good!!...

Pours a clear dark red with small light brown head, no lacing. Smell as some fruity notes like cherrys and raspberrys, oak, lots of sour notes. Taste has light caramel, oak, tart, cherrys, light raspberrys, good sourness. Medium body and carbonation. A really good one. Will have again for sure.
Draft at crunchys. Nice dark brownish red color.  Great sour taste. Almost tart-cherryesque.

I seem to appreciate La Folie less than some. At $17.99/bottle, I expected stellar, but instead got good. Very enjoyable raspberry aroma, Very tart (but certainly not the tartest sour out there), with some notable flavor contribution from the oak barrels. I think that the reason it falls short is that there is really no back-of-the tongue flavor contribution - it seems like it lacks a third dimension.

Bottle (2013 vintage). Pours reddish brown with a small tan head. Aroma of strong sour fruit (cherries and raisins) with some malt notes. Medium body with strong sour and tart fruit flavor upfront with a slightly dry and sour finish. One of my favorite sours.

Bottle (2013). Pours a hazy, dark red with a quarter finger of coarse, tan head. Settles almost immediately with minimal lacing. Aroma is cherry, tart, lactic. Flavor is tart cherry, moderately sour, mild vinous character. Moderate carbonation, medium- light body, crisp texture, and dry finish. A very good sour, moderately tart, more so than I remember from the 2011 release, nice tart cherry character.
Very sour tart cherry aroma. Not much to the head, dark red in body. Sour vinegar cherry taste with a dry cider vinegar finish. Very crisp on the palate.
Bottle at home. Pours a deep red with champagne head. Aroma is leather and fruit. Taste is tart fruit with pleasant oak character. Dry, dry finish.

2013 bottle, first sip is extremely sour which is delightful, the aroma has a woody sour cherry nose. The flavor is very tart the sour cherries are very prevalent, the oak, vanilla, and other very woody flavors come through also. Probably one of the best sours I¬íve ever had.
On tap at Collin's Pub in Seattle. Pours an reddy brown with not much of a head. Strong tartness that dies away quickly. Plum flavors.

Pours a clear copper with a tan head that attenuates to a thin cap. Has a raisin and mild olive aroma. A sour taste that lies somewhere between green apple and a little less than fully ripe grape. 2013 Bottle.  Dark red pour with an off white head,  aroma of sour and tart cherries.  Taste is sour and tart with cherries, oak and a little apple flavor.  Great beer!

Very good

UPDATED: JAN 18, 2015 Pours a nice brownish with good lacing. Aromas of vinegar, sour cherries and red wine. Sour lemon flavours. Bubbly.
I always like a good sour ale, and this one delivers for the most part. Red, sour, though always could be more vingery and less fruity in my opinion. Great beer.

On tap @ Public House in Vegas. Clear russet brown with a medium tan head. Aroma of sour cherries with underlyiing chocolate and woody elements. Funky sour cherries, dry cocoa, dusty wood, light leather. Quenchingly sour, not puckeringly sour-- something I really appreciate. Delicious.
