text: 22oz bottle, capped only. Tough to give it high marks because the aroma is decidedly one smell, the look is brownish red muck, the taste is tart and quenching with a lip puckering character that I enjoy, and the palate well.. its sour. not a bad rendition i like sours with a little more sweet.

Clear reddish copper pour with small off white head. Aroma of green apple, citrus, vinegar and sour smell. Taste is mouth puckering tart green apple, tart cherries, citrus and sour. Finishes with a hint of sweetness but dry at the same time. Over the top mouth puckering thats not really my favorite style, but I can understand the high scores on this one, top notch quality for this style.

On tap @ Clarkston Union. Poured into embassy glass, dark ruby red. Beautiful color!  with small off white head. Nose is cherries, berries, slight vinegar. No lacing to speak of, taste is hay, funk, tart cherry, sour apple. Mouthfeel is medium, with carbonation that is medium to heavy as well. Finish is long a very pleasant with a slight astrigency that reminds me of Campari. Big fan of the Flanders style and this is a sparkling example.

2011 bottle. Aroma has balanced notes of dark fruit including tart cherries, cassis and untie blackberries. There is also a bit of an oak note in the aroma and some acidity to balance the fruitiness. Pours brown with a thin tan head that recedes fairly quickly. Some muddy amber highlights to the color. Flavor starts with a bit of a sweet fruity note with dark cherries, cassis and tart raspberries. This changes mid palate as a bit of an oak character leads the palate to some finishing tartness and acidity. The finish is quite acidic and mouth puckering. The mouthfeel is medium bodied and has a touch of smoothness to it before the acidity causes it to finish dry and crisp. Medium low carbonation and low alcohol warmth. Overall a very enjoyable Flanders Red, but I wish was still a live beer so I could see how it developed with time. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours a dark brown cola color. Aroma of sour cherries, sour citrus, candy sugar, and roasty malts. Flavors were amazingly sour, lots of sour cherry, sour cola, candy, and a bit of the roasty nuttiness. Body was pretty light, and I liked that it had so much flavor for being on the lower end of abv. Nice light dry finish. For me it¬ís hard to drink a ton of this, but it is absolutely delicious and it is high on my list!

Bottle. Pours a dark copper with a reddish hint and tons of carbonation.  Head disappeared quickly. Aroma is sour. Flavor is sweet with a woody/oak taste followed by a mouth puckering sour. Nice beer but fairly expensive.

Had on tap.

Arrived a clear ruby red with no real head to speak of.

Aroma of dark fruit with a definite tartness present. Some wood and tree bark as well.

Immediate dark fruit on the flavor reminding me of cherries and figs. Lots of tartness along with vinegar and some funk. A little bit of lighter citrus in there as well. Mouthfeel is very watery, unfortunately, and detracts somewhat.

Overall, I was a little underwhelmed by this beer. It seemed to lack some complexity and the mouthfeel was terrible.

On draft.  Pours clear deep red, no head.  Aroma is sour cherries and apples.  Taste is tart fruit (cherry, apple), vinous, just a little earthiness.  Very nicely balanced.  Medium body, light carbonation, dry finish.  Quite nice overall.

Glass: Half pint glass
From: URGE American Gastropub in Rancho Bernardo (San Diego, Calif.)
Price: $6.00 
Misc.: N/A

Poured a dark red, plum color with about a finger (when I got it) of marshmallow white head that initially had good retention. Nice spider web lacing on the sides as the beer went down, averaged out on the top.

Smelled sour cherries, green apple, rum, black cherry, plum and Cherry Coke.   

Tasted sour cherries, black cherry, tart, Smarties and still that sour green apple. Some sour grape as well.

Medium body. Oily texture. Average-to-lively (above average) carbonation. Extremely long smooth finish. Definitely the best part of the beer.

Very good beer overall. I¬ím still learning the sours and Flanders¬í, but this seems to be one of the better ones I¬íve tried. Would definitely try it again.

Tap sample at the brewery.
Clear deep mahogany color with brown hues and a small beige head.
Sour cherry aroma, with cherry liquor, wood, vanilla and some sweat.
Flavors of sour berries, raisins, almonds, low bitterness with some vommit and acid.
Puckering, super dry finish, high carbonation, light-med body and interesting.
On tap at public house. Aroma is sour apple and some cherry. Flavor is tart, apple, cherry and oak. Delicious.
Draught.  Belgian Brewfest Boston MA.  really complex and refined palate.

Bottle, from trade with skycracksopen. Pours a deep ruby-hued brown body with a tiny off-white head. Aroma is vinous peppery cherry-oaky malt tones with soy sauce and herbs in the back. Taste is woody raisiny balsamic and cherry notes, hints of smoke, earth, dark malts and red wine. Full body, soft carbonation. Well balanced with a right proper dose of sourness. A nice wild ale.

On tap. Brown with a small ring of bubbles. Nose of tart fruit, dark grape must and a touch of fresh fish. Taste is lemon juice, tart berry, earthy vinous and must notes. Medium body is dry and has medium-high carbonation.
On tap at Capitol Beer & Taproom; nice sour aroma and sting on to the throat.  Falls a little short on the toungue; but a solid offering from New Belgium.

1/2 pint at draught house.  Reddish-ruddy brown.  clear, light lacing.  Aroma is complex...I can¬ít pick everything out.  Light taste for the style, I agree with the "effervescence" and "earthiness" but not the sour apple, more citrus sour to me.  Lights up the whole tongue.  It¬ís a legit Rodenbach doppleganger IMHO.
Huge glue aroma.  Sour taste with hints of oak.  Lots of flavor with some fruit here and there.  Huge brown color with a little lace.  This beer is seriously sour.

Pours dark red with a white head that dissipates quickly. You can smell how tart it¬ís going to be and it has some earthy barnyard to it as well. Taste is tart  overwhelmingly tart, definitely makes you pucker. Definitely sour cherries and some apple as well as that yeast funk. On the palate it is very light and dry with fizzy carbonation almost like soda. Overall one of my favorite sours I¬íve tried because of how unforgiving the sourness is, definitely New Belgium¬ís best.

Bottle poured a clear red hue w/ no head. Big boozy rum aroma. Big sour front to a moderate sour finish. Taste of tart cranberry most dominate some oak. Dry mouthfeel similar to a dry red wine. One of the better sours I¬íve had.
This may be the worst beer I¬íve ever tasted. Sour to the point of tasting rancid. Imagine the beer equivalent of spoiled milk.

Bottle from Jstax Thanks ! Pours a rusty ruby brown with a finger or so of eggshell foam. RIch aromas of earthy cherry, wet wood, floral rose, and some berry bits as well. On the palate its got a nice sour kick with a complex flavor profile similar to the nose. Amazing woody undertones and a great mouthfeel. This beer is sour and tart where so many others go balsamic and soy sauce. Excellent flemish style for a US brew !!! Top Notch.
Earthy sour with a great red brown hugh to it. Best enjoyed slightly chilled.  Will stock up on this.

The aroma is sweet and sour with a fruity quality. The appearance is red brown with a small head. The taste is like the aroma. The palate is smooth. Overall I am not a fan of the style but this is drinkable.
the sour of the beer is the dominate drive of this beer. its nice and tart. fairly thin but highly quenchable.

On tap @ Chuck¬ís 85th. Pours dark reddish brown with minimal head. Sour cherries jump out on the nose. Big, lip puckering sourness on initial taste. Solid notes of apple, cherry, and oak. Dry, crisp body that finishes super clean. Easy for many sour beers to hide their alcohol, but this is nicely moderate.  Probably the most commonly available sour and delicious to boot!  Pretty sure this was my first sour many years ago, and although my reaction to them has changed quite a bit, this is still an archetype for the style.

UPDATED: APR 2, 2014 Sample draft at One-Eyed Betty¬ís.  I¬íll start by saying I¬ím not big on sours usually.  This one was more intense than the usual sour.  Aroma is sour apple and berries with a hint of oak wood.  Taste was so tart I almost choked.  This is a very intense sour beer with big sour apple and sour berry flavor.  I appreciate this beer for what it is but it was just too much for me.

Re-rate 3/29/14.  2013 bottle thanks to mrebeks for sharing.  I¬íve come to enjoy sours more now so I¬ím glad I got to revisit this one.  It¬ís still a little more sour than I like but it wasn¬ít nearly as intense as my original review.

Bottle. Pours a deep red with small tan head. 

Smells oaky, apples, cola

Tastes very sour, rich, fruity, and again- sour. Nice finish.

Good beer, very good sour. Can¬ít wait to finish the rest of the glass!

UPDATED: AUG 31, 2014 First ratingInitial Rating Date: 10/17/2012Sampled at GABF on Saturday October 13, second sessionClear brown color, tan head. Acidic, fruity scent. Tart, acidic taste. Medium mouthfeel, low bitterness.7/3/7/3/14=3.4Rerate1 pt 6 fl oz bottle thanks to Nisse666! Sampled on December 21, 2013.As New Belgium Lips of Faith - La Folie Sour Brown Ale.Clear dark red color, small fizzy pink head. Sweet, light acidic, berry, vinegar scnet. Semi-sweet, a bit of vinegar, berry taste. A bit thin mouthfeel, very low bitterness.6/3/6/2/11=2.8RerateDraught at New Belgium Brewing Company in Fort Collins, on April 6, 2014.Clear brown color, small teal head. Acidic, currants taste. Fizzy mouthfeel, very low bitterness. Acidic scent.8/4/8/2/15=3.7RerateBottle at Sweet & Sour, S√§tila, 2014-08-30. Thanks to tkrjukoff!Marked Lips of Faith 2013.Clear brown color, yellow head. Acidic, vinegar scent. Acidic, sour taste. Sour aftertaste, also a bit roasted. Medium mouthfeel, very low bitterness.7/4/7/3/14=3.5
Rate from memory. had 2 bottles. color was brown with not much head. taste was tart with an apple vinigar taste.

UPDATED: DEC 25, 2013 Bottle (bomber) from as trade with heyta. Clear reddish brown, medium beige head. Fruity aroma with red apples, some vinegar, wood, and caramel. Medium bodied, medium carbonation. Semi dry, low bitterness, medium acidity.

Bomber bottle: Pours a deep dark brown with ruby tones and a small off-white head. Aroma is green apples with hints of cherries, jams and earthy oak tones. Sweet flavor is malty and sour apples with hints of oak in the tart, mouth puckering finish. Very refreshing and delicious!

Bottle thx to Tom10101
Pours kind of mahogany with low beige head. Some lacing. Aroma is of bread, cherries, acid, sweet, raisins. Taste is very tart, acidic, fruits (cherries). Medium body. Overall: Unfortunately, too much tartness for my taste, almost to the choking point at moment. It hides other features of the beer. Good beer anyways!

UPDATED: JAN 9, 2015 2011 vintage shared by tom10101. Intense sour on the nose with a bit of oak and a lot of malt sweetness. This sweetness doesn¬ít translate into a cloying taste as I thought it might, good thing it didn¬ít. Pretty acidic mouth that leaves you puckering for a more than average time. You can really feel the oak too. Great sour!

Bottle (22 oz). Thanks Andrew! Amber with a medium off-white head and some lacing. Aroma of red fruits (cherries), wood, bread and sour notes. Intense/aggressive taste of red fruits and sourness with strong notes of wood and hints of apple. Mouthfeel is dry and acidic. Very good sour brown ale. Agressive and complex, I really liked this one!
2012 clear dark red no head. Aroma of sour cherry vinegar wood. Great sweet and sour taste. Cherry wood vinegar. Great long Finnish.

22oz bottle, 2012 batch.  Served at around 45F and allowed to warm in the glass.

Pours clear reddish brown with a two finger light brown head that recedes to a ring and leaves only a few spots of short-lived lacing behind.

Aroma is sour, vinegar, apples, cherries, a little funky, some wood and a hint of vanilla.  All comes together quite nicely.  Good to very good strength.

Flavor starts with a big blast of sour, quite puckering, strong sour apples, cherries, vinegar, oak, a little touch of sweet malt dances around, particularly at the finish, but this sour first and foremost.  Minimal alcohol.

Mouthfeel is light/medium bodied, a bit sticky, lowish carbonation.

Very nice Sour and quite sour at that.
Had this one bottled thanks to Wyl!  An excellent example of the style.

Bomber - 2011 vintage

A: Pours a black-looking but reddish brown color with a fluffy off-white head. Retention in the sniffer is decent

S: Ripe cherry, sour unripe cherry, wet wood, vinegar and other orchard fruits and berries. Really nice

T: Super sour, lots of "green" cherries, ripe fruit, chocolate??, vanilla, and wood (not sure what kind, but it¬ís new to me). Pretty intense, as I am completely new to sours

MF/D: Pretty viscous (I wish I knew the standard body for the style), sour beginning, middle and end palate, but not necessarily dry. I¬ím not sure that this is drinkable in terms of beers per sitting, but a very nice beer to pair with food on a special occasion

Notes: new to the style and still am in the process of getting used to sours, so don¬ít look at my review for guidance

UPDATED: FEB 19, 2017 At Rockwells. Quite puckery sour at first. Then it calms down a bit. Wine like and woody flavors. Maybe could have been a bit sweeter for my personal tastes but over all quite nice. Serving: Tap

Clear dark brown pour, moderately thick loose head that disappears quickly with a little bit of lacing. Aroma is relatively mild sour. Flavor is simple sour, moderately intense, without much depth or complexity. Has slight vomit-like aroma finish. Was expecting more from this one.

had as a 2010 sour brown ale.
pours a clear dark brown with a red tint, a thin beige head that dissapates, no lacing.

smell is of wood, wild yeast, spice, caramel, and a bit of malt.

taste is sour, spice, caramel, yeast, and some malt.  ends tart and spicey.

2012 bottle coutesy of Tale of Ale, cheers Reuben!
Pours deep cherry-mahogany with tart raspberries and balsamic vinegar on the nose. Quite highly carbonated, a touch of caramel then plenty of sourness and fruit reminiscent of oxidised red wine.

I do love me some La Folie. C&C is great but will have to update the next time I crack one of those. Reg, 22 oz here. Reading about why NB chose to past these bottles makes sense to me in the sense that this is a good beer as is & that is how the blender wants you to drink it. Start off wood-heavy but soft enough. Touch of tooth-stripping harsh acidity as expected.
Recent vintage.  Pretty unremarkable.  Tastes nice and tart, but one-noted.  Tart finish but little else going on.

UPDATED: MAR 25, 2013 Dark reddish brown tap pour, fine foam but disappears quickly. Aroma of sour cherries. Taste is sour up front with a light toastiness in the finish. Nice and sharp on the palate.

UPDATE: 2013 bottle. Virtually the same beer as above with added funk detected in the aroma.

Tap at Harry¬ís Lips of Faith Tap Takeover. Pours clear reddish brown with a very small head that nonetheless leaves decent lacing in its wake. Aroma is tart and woody, with notes of red grapes and port. Flavor is tart woody with fruity notes of grape and raisin, plus a touch of biscuit. Nice.
2012 Vintage. Brown color, sour green apple aroma. Bright sour notes until after the third sip, when the wood, and sour apple notes come through more. Fantastic Sour ale

22 oz bottle poured into a tumbler pint glass. My first sour ale! I¬ím so excited...

A: Pours a translucent dark burgundy color with excellent clarity. The head is a two finger light mocha color featuring a moderate texture and poor head retention. Not much lacing, either. Still, the body color is so beautiful, I had to give extra points.

S: This really has a lot going on. Tart fruits (such as pear, apples, and cherries), a nicely done oak note, and so on. Like I said, there¬ís so much going on, it¬ís hard to pick out individual scents; even still, it¬ís a fantastic smell.

T: Hella tart, but it¬ís an excellent sensation that¬ís kept in check beautifully. Initial tart cherries give way to a subtle malt backbone, while the finish and aftertaste is full of accumulating oak tannins (not to mention a great lingering sourness - not overdone or too weak, just right). Very vinous, like I expected, with nuanced, pleasant vinegar notes popping up on the flavor profile every now and then. The balance between sweet and savory is pulled off with gusto, as well.

The only thing preventing me from scoring this higher (read: a 5) is simple: I¬ím not used to sour ales. Like I said, this is my first one (and I don¬ít friggen¬í care how expensive they are, this won¬ít be my last), but I reckon this would be a great introduction to the style, and it¬ís balanced fantastically enough so that most drinkers will be able to appreciate some of its subtleties without suffering too much palate overload.

M: Moderately creamy smooth, up until the midtaste, where it becomes prickly, coarse, and dry from the oak tannins and healthy carbonation. Quite mouthwatering at times. It¬ís at a weird middle ground in terms of drinkability: do I sip it slowly to appreciate all of its nuances, or do I chug it at a semi-quick pace because it¬ís so damn good? Guess I¬íll do both options intermittently, ¬ícause I¬ím hardcore...

O: As a student who¬ís pretty much on a budget, trust me when I say I¬íd still buy this again and again. I probably won¬ít in the near future, because of that fact, but it¬ís good to know such an excellent sour is so easy to find in my area. Plain and simple, this rocks.

UPDATED: AUG 2, 2013 When they put on the bomber "seriously sour" they said it right. Poured from a bomber a dark burgundy color with a creamy, tan head with a caramel hue. Aroma is tart, barnyard funk, wood, cherries, apple, and caramel. Flavor is big sour front with apple and cherries, notes of wood, funk, caramel, and malt. Mouth feel is acidic and oily. Wonderful, world class brew.

22oz bottle from NJBeerNerd.  Deep dark red with a small off-white head.  Aroma is sour, acidic, and sweet with lots of cherry and berry notes, some wood as well.  Taste surprisingly lacks sweetness, very dry, with a little funk and good acidity.  Finish is dry.  Light body, moderate carbonation.  It¬ís not bad.  If NJ got this, I would still always opt for Bockor Cuvee instead.

Bottle thanks to Errl, shared at weihenheizen¬ís tasting. Thanks! Pours a dark brown with a steady beige head of foam. In the aroma I get a lot of cinnamon and a little brown sugar. Taste is a good deal more tart than the aroma would indicate. I get some chocolate notes in here as well. Drying mouthfeel and a little sticky.

Refrigerated bottle poured into a tulip.  Pours dark amber with light brown head.  Little lacing, light body, and low carbonation.  Taste is simple tart, roasted malt, and a hint of nut.  Part english nut brown, part sour.

Sample at the brewery.  Comes a clear reddish brown with a minimal biege head.  Aroma of sour fruit, malt, vinegar, and wood.  Taste is lots of sour fruit, caramel, malt, oak, and vinegar.  Finish is dry.  Nice.

22oz. Had this many times so thought I would rate it today.  pours reddish brown wiith good carbonation.  Moderately sour, woody and earthy with some apple/cherry fruitiness. This is a good gateway sour for newbies.  I¬íve heard the prices vary a lot but near me at $16 nearly double a Rodenbach, and with many other better choices I will go for something else.

One of the best beers in this style I have have. This is a style I do not drink a lot but is a great change of pace. More money then I like to spend on a 6 % beer but you can find many this good. Sweet and tart with lite oak notes. The more you drink the more you crave.
Awesome beer! Deep red, sour like raspberry and just plain good. Almost like an unsweetened cran apple martinelli¬ís (but better obviously).  Also, it miraculously cured my stomach flu.

Draught at Apex. Very dark red with fine, thin lace. Almost dark brown. Big cherry, vanilla, balsamic vinegar nose. Very sour, woody, with vinegar, cherry. A bit htin. Not so complex, but nice. Dry, woody finish. Doesn¬ít compare to some of the Cascade beers I had earlier today.

Elated to see this on tap and reasonably priced at Brixie¬ís in Brookfield, IL.. Dispensed to a snifter with a brown, ruby highlighted color, cream & bubbles head that diminished quickly to a ring & film, and left some very clingy ribbons of lacing. The nose was tart cherry, apple, and grape, and pleasant oaky/cask hints. Full bodied, rich flavored, smooth yet decidedly sour, and dry to the finish. A real treat!

130712. Aroma sour cherries, hops. A strange party in my mouth. Not Bad.

UPDATED: MAY 17, 2015 Bottle.  Clear reddish brown pour with a light brown head.  Vinegar and sour cherry aromas.  Some woody highlights with vinegar and sour cherry notes (original rating from July 2012).
Re-rate (May 2015):  Bottle generously shared by JW, 2002 vintage.  Delicious with huge vinous notes.  Oak, sour grape, and caramel malt backbeats.  Really good body and mouthfeel.  Complex and very tasty.  Impressive.  I always heard the old cork and caged versions were fantastic.  This did not disappoint.
UPDATED: NOV 20, 2015 Dark reddish brown. Lots of oak, sour cherries, pine, tannic, dark berries, vanilla, red wine.

Sample, from a bottle, Mondial de la bi√®re, savoured on June 6 2012; eye: coppery, clear, no effervescence, tiny ring of beige head, slight lacing; nose: sourness, acidity, light malt, wild yeasts, musk, woody; mouth: sourness, acidity, freshness, light malt, wild yeasts, musk, woody, a tad short sour finale with presence of acidity, not much carbonation, mildly sour, slick texture; overall: fine

FRAN√áAIS

√âchantillon, d¬íune bouteille, Mondial de la Bi√®re, savour√©e le 6 juin 2012; ¬úil : cuivr√©e, limpide, pas d¬íeffervescence, petit anneau de mousse beige, tr√®s l√©g√®re dentelle; nez : aigreur, acidit√©, l√©ger malt, levures sauvages, musc, bois√©; bouche : aigreur, acidit√©, fra√Æcheur, l√©ger malt, levures sauvages, musc, bois√©, finale aigre un peu courte bourbon avec pr√©sence d¬íacidit√©, peu carbonat√©e, moyennement aigre, texture coulante; en r√©sum√© : bien

Bottle (hand bottled 11/07) shared with Pawola22. Thanks bud! This one was really aged to perfection, as it was incredibly drinkable with bright, vibrant sour notes and balanced oak and fruity qualities. A real pretty pour of silky milk cream head, some sticky retention, and pretty, deep medium opaque, rusty brown body. Hazy oak, toasted caramel, and fruity sour lead the way in the nose. There are also some buttery grains, deep fruits with cherries and pears, with some minor vinegar. The feel here is absolutely perfect. Its hard to describe, but the flavors come off deep and bold, but never over the top. Very oaky, strong for the abv, and balanced. Sweet and sour cherries, and oak come forth up front in the flavor. Pears, mixed dark sour fruits next, then balanced with caramels and toasted nutty grains. The flavor and nose play off each other real well. This was overall pretty fantastic, and a great experience as far as sours go. Up there with the best.

Bottle. Sweet berry, vanilla, oak, earthy yeast flavor. Brown tinged ruby with a small tan head, nice lacing... really pretty. Smooth, woody sour flavor like a well aged, sweet fruity balsamic vinegar.  Medium to full body.  Very nice.
Bottle.  Sweet-sour berry and woody vanilla aroma.   Dark red with small head.  Mildly sweet sour berry malt and Belgian yeast flavor.  Nice balance.  Very nice and tasty.

Bottle courtesy of CanIhave4beers.  Thanks, bro!  2011 vintage.  Pours a clearish, very deep amber, almost brown with a pillowy tan head that faded after about a minute.  Aromas of oak, sour fruit, funkiness.  Taste follows suit with acidic sharpness, tarty sour fruit, and finishes by clobbering you over the head with a big oak stick.  Very nice.  Slight pucker factor, but nowhere near a lambic.  This is about on the same level of awesomeness as supplication, which is to say that it is one step behind consecration.  Still, very good.  I would drink this again if it were available near me.

2012 Edition

Poured from a 22 ounce bomber into a New Belgium globe. Bottline date of 12/23/2011 printed on bottle.

Appearance: Pours a clear dark brown with ruby red highlights and a 1 finger light tan head. Head dissipates fairly quickly, leaving a small puddle of foam around the edges and in the middle. Minimal lacing.

Smell: Tart aroma with a hint of sweetness that features vinegar, cherries and a hint of wood.

Taste: A mix of sweet and tart cherries up front followed by vinegar in the middle before ending with a mildly tart finish. Aftertaste is sour yet light. Very well-balanced flavor.

Mouthfeel: Medium-bodied with a good amount of carbonation. The sourness is mouth-puckering in a good way..

Drinkability: Excellent drinkability. I¬ím loving this one and will have no problem polishing off the bomber in short order.

Overall: Very good beer overall. While I haven¬ít had a ton of Flanders Oud Bruin beers so far, this one is the best I¬íve tried. I¬íd definitely recommend trying this one.

750mL shared with my wife.
Bottle #4819 July 2008

A: Brown with a slight reddish tint and a small head that leaves no lacing.

S: Sour cherries, wood. There is no mustiness or basement funk. The aroma is a fresh sourness, if that makes sense. A hint of sweetness is hidden behind the sour scents.

T: Sourness right away, with cherries, wood, and a wine-like tannin finish. The flavors are blended together masterfully. The wood aspect is phenomenal, really making this beer special. There is a slight fruity sweetness which adds to the complexity of this delightful brew.

M: Puckering, good carbonation level.

D: After a couple glasses, my throat is beginning to sting a little. That being said, this is very drinkable, if you have an affinity for potent sour ales, as I most certainly do. Highly recommended. A must have for those who enjoy sours.
Okay, so I love sours. This is a great example and gets a higher score because of the wonderful oakiness. Spot on to style. The wild yeast provides a decent funk backgroud. Pucker up!

Pours a Dark brownish red color with a small brown head. Aroma is sour lemons, malt, cherries, and oak. The taste is over the top sour, it makes me pucker a little. There¬ís a nice malty backbone that¬ís completely dominated by the sour. Thinking about it makes my mouth water. Let me put it this way, it tastes like it¬ís been aging in an oak barrel for 3 years, but in a good way.

Bottle sample at a sour tasting at Noam¬ís office. Many thanks DSG. Pours orange to brown with a medium beige head, aroma of raisins, chocolate, vanilla, wood, some sweetness and acidity, flavor is sour and dry with plum juice, tomatoes, spiciness, live, medium bodied, nice

@Mondial de la Bi√®re 2012, Montreal - hazy reddish beer, little foam left; fairly sourish; notes of wood, vinegar and cherries; medium-bodied, sourish; dry and long fruity finish with hints of vinegar and wood

Bottle to tulip (2012 vintage). Looks good; a hazy brown with low carbonation and thin lacing. Smells spicy; cinnamon and nutmeg with a little tart mixed in. Tastes good; Sour apple and plum notes. Mouthfeel is par for the course. This is good!

Bottle sample at a sour tasting at Noam¬ís office. 2011 bottle. Thanks DSG. Pours dark brown, with a hazy yellowish off white head. Soda, grape juice, some cherry and plum aroma. Tastes sour and fruity with some tomatoes. Medium body, acidic. Not bad at all.
Poured from a bomber into a tulip with little head.  Smells of oak and stone fruit.  Tastes the same as the nose with funkiness and tartness.  2012 version
Mahogany color with white head.  Aromas of apple vinegar.  Taste is very sour with a dry finish.  Overall, a tasty sour with tons of flavor.  Well done.

Never seen such a clear brown pour. Bottle is a bit older so no head. Huge aroma of sour cherry. Medium bodied big lemony flavor the sweet then finishing with a huge sour

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

From a bomber into a wide mouth water glass????? Vintage 2012 Lips of Faith. Pours a fairly dull but accurate brown. Little to no head and zero lacing. Mild sweet nose of brown sugar. Surprisingly not sour smelling.   Mouthfeel is very carbonated and  very burpy.  Taste is very sour. Plenty of Sweettart flavor. Some dark fruit, sour cherry and mild Belgian funk. Overall it was a decent but not great beer. I just didn't get much flavor depth on this one, just sour. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
One of the better sours I have had the joy of tasting.  Loved this beer and it set me off on a voyage to get into sours.  Such a refreshing beer.

Appearance: :La Folie pours a delightful copper color from the bottle. In the glass there¬ís a deep red surrounded (when held to light) by a piercing amber color. There¬ís a finger of light beige head that moves on as quickly as it shows. Lacing is extremely mild.

Smell: There¬ís a tartness up front here, it blends and stands as an overtone for an almost vinegar aroma. Deeper lies is a citrusy apple smell. As it starts to closes on the nose there¬ís also grape and white wine here. Really nice.

Mouthfeel: Almost like white wine with something filling it. The weight here goes on the help carry the tartness is the flavor. 

Taste: Tart on the top with a bright white wine flavor standing out. It¬ís odd that the least prominent smell is the most prominent flavor. There¬ís a green grape flavor there that is distinct from the wine. As it rounds the middle of the tongue there is also a roastiness complementing caramel it leads up to.the last thing I notice, a powerful, rich, charming smoky oak. It really stands out here at the end. 

Overall: Really a great beer. If you ever get a chance to spend the cash on a bottle, I say buy two. You can get the supreme mouth pucker they were going for with the fresh one and age the other to bring on the oak character that makes this beer stand out. Yet again though, a world class beer is held back by it¬ís price. Sadly, I¬ím pretty sure that¬ís how they make it so world class...

19/V/2012 - 1Pt. 6Fl. Oz bottle @ De Hopduvel - 2012 vintage (2012-521) Thanks to BoBoChamp for sharing the beer!
Clear red brown beer, no head. Aroma: some caramel, nice sour nose, tart apples, strawberries, some tobacco, bit of red lace candy. MF: soft carbon, medium body. Taste: apple skin, little bitter, tobacco, lemony, pretty tart, fruity as well. Aftertaste: very earthy, tobacco bitterness, pretty sour, red currant,s raspberries, some overripe to rotten fruits, bit meaty, metallic, something is off. And this beer gets a 100 and Rodenbach only 94??? Ridiculous. Wake up, American chauvinist pigs! This doesn¬ít even come remotely close to any beer from the Rodenbach family.

Fourth beer in the Bottleworks Cellar Tasting for Seattle Beer Week, 2007 10th Anniversary Blend. Pours dark brown with half a finger of off white head. Smell is candy (sweet tart), vinegar. Taste is strong tart, wood, acidic, mouth drooling pucker, really good, amazing even.

Pours a dark brown color with no head at all. Aroma typical of a Flanders, slight fruity with malt notes also lacto in the back. Taste is very tart in the best way possible. Pickering with fruits and malts, definite lacto notes, a little on the dry side. Overall this is my favorite Flanders, so freakin good!

65cl, Vintage 2012, as New Belgium La Folie ¬íLips of Faith Series¬í, American brew, thx to Secret Santa!, complex sour brew, sour/woody and slightly fruity/vinous, balanced, clear, nearly no head, good brew, yet very expensive!

From bottle into Rodenbach sour glass. A: very sour, rotten raspberries, and high citrus levels. App: very dark amber with 3 finger tan head. T: very sour on the front of lime juice, milder citrus in the middle, ample sour lime citrus in the back. P: crisp bubbles, very smooth. Aftertaste of solid lime juice. First New Belgium beer I have had that is truly the style of the old world.

22oz bottle dated 12/29/2010 poured into tulip glass.  2011 vintage.
Aroma: vinegar, cherries, lemons, oak, malt
Appearance: fairly clear, reddish brown color with just a bit of tan head that faded quickly.  laces glass just a bit.  no rising bubbles visible.
Taste: heavy sour! mild sweet, hardly any bitter
Palate: light body, thin texture, extremely fizzy carbonation.  finish is heavy sour and light bitter
Overall: This is a very well done beer.  The sour isnt too overpowering.  I have not had many sours before but I think this is a good start.  It is very tart but also refreshing.
Schwerer, leicht s√§uerlicher Sherrybeginn. Im Mittelteil holzig, konstante, in geringen Teilen bei√üende S√§ure. S√ºffig, erfrischend, adstrigenter Abgang. 12/12/10/12/10/12
Wonderful aroma, some tart fruit on the nose, nice mouth feel, pours with no head, sharp tartness with a dry tart cherry finish. very good..

Extremely tart!  Pours brown, slight head, translucent.  

Taste is sour, sour, and more sour!  One of if not THE most sour ale I¬íve had.  Finish is tart and dry.  

Very drinkable due to low abv.   I would still recommend a friend or two to knock out a bomber because of how strong the flavor is.

2012 bottle shared at the Brass Tap Sour Breakfast, poured an amber color, with aromas of barnyard funk, tart cherries, dark fruits, and some oak.  Flavors are the same, just a mildly tarter version of it.  Real nice beer overall, will have to buy more the next time it comes out.
Pours deep red color and a small off-white head. Aroma with lots of fruit flavors: cherry, grape, and other dark fruits. Taste is also sour with hints of cherry, apple, and citrusy.

1 May 2012, bottle. ruby brown, clear, thin fizzy head. sour notes are strong as soon as it is poured. up close there is wet bread, blue cheese, bubble gum, and lots of tart notes. thin body and very effervescent. kind of musty, very dry oaky characteristics. really reminds me of a dry wine. tart cherries as well. really nice.
Tap. Garnet with creamy head. Smells clean, sour, and a little sweet. Nice sour flavor, very little sweetness. Slightly warming, light carbonation, a bit of a head edge.

The aroma is vinius with notes of dark cherry and some oak. The beer is deep red to brown with a small head. The taste is very tart with recurrent vinous, cherry, and oak notes. The beer is fairly dry with a pickering sourness in a medium to thin body. Overall good, it nust is perhaps a little too tart for my tastes.

Had this a number of times including recently at East Nash Beer Fest. Solid Sour Ale.  Pleasant as can be. More tart than sour. Notes of red and wine wines, apple, other fruits, and wet wood. Blended amazingly well with Cocoa Mole. Great beer.

UPDATED: JUL 14, 2012 Bottle. Poured a deep amber color, medium tan head. Good lacing. Aromas of cherry, funky yeast, cranberry, raisins, oak, rich malt. Taste was filled with apples, and other acidic fruits, wine, mouth salivating sour palate. Awesome beer, thanks for the sample Lauren.

Pours a reddish brown color. Minimal head retention in the tulip glass. Aroma is of green apples and hints at the acidity of the beer. Taste is dry and tart almost vinegary. On the finish there is an earthy note and hints of sour cherry. Good beer but not my favorite sour, too dry.

Pours deep red with a beige head. Aroma has alot of that vinegar/balsamic thing going on along with vanilla, lacto acid, a bit "flemish", nutty, deep dark cherry, sweeter malts and some raisins. Taste is has that flemish feel aswell along with dried fruits, funk, balsamic, vanilla, brown alish notes, sweet malts, lacto acid, cherry and a dry and tartish end. Pretty good.

Bottle. Poured a dark amber almost brown color with a nice two finger tannish head. Aroma was cherries, malts, and yeast. Flavor was acadic, tart and yeasty. Sour in the finish. Not my style but I can admit when I try a great beer. This one was above average.

Draft. Pours deep red brown with a beige head. Tart and acidic fruity aroma with lighter earthy notes. The flavor has a good balance of cherry sweetness and tartness, with medium acidity and earthy and musty notes. Nice.

Aroma: some cherry, some sour green grape, old floorboards, also a bit astringent; Appearance: a very clear, pure/calm (if that makes any sense) transluscence, brownish red; Taste: definate apple notes (even though I stand by having smelled cherry and grape), a wonderful tart, bordering on sour, but not bitter, some raisen; Palate: makes your mouth water a little bit, just a hint of bitter only have several swallows; Overall: immediately made me want to come back for more after my first glass, I will drink the entire pint myself and think nothing of it, I¬íve been looking for something to enjoy as much as I enjoyed Two Brothers Askew, and this is far superior

Pours a nice amber with a small dark tan head.  Aroma is fruity, tart, funky, wood, some vinegar notes, raisins.  Interesting flavor, sour apple, dark fruits, raspberry, sour cherries, wood, funk, high carbonation.  Tastes old and fruity and awesome.

Bottle. Pours a clear, deep red/brown with a small beige head. Aroma is sweet, sour and dry with notes of brett, malt in the background and a candy-like touch. Flavour is sweet and sour as well, with notes of raisins, and malt in the background. A bit cloying. Sour finish with a dry wine-like bitterness, and a lingering cloying malt note. Pretty good. 30.03.12.

Pours a clear ruby color with a thin tan head.  Aroma has nice fruitiness...cherry...lightly tart.  Flavor is more tart and acidic...akin to a rodenbach...mild balsamic without the sweetness.  Mouthfeel is light and lively with a dry, tart finish.
Pours a reddish brown with small carbonation.  Aroma is stingy vineagar, and malt.  Taste is very astringent, slightly fizzy, malt vineagar and a great sourness.  Wish I had more.

Listed as La Folie "Red" on tap at Venti¬ís in Salem, OR. It has a light ruby color with thin head around the rim of the glass. The sour was shocking to start but it was crisp. There was a notable lack of yeast flavor apparent in most wild ales.

A - Pour a dark ruby-brown that is almost clear around the edges and a thin finger of frothy khaki colored head atop. The head fades down fairly quickly leaving behind some nice lace.

S - Aroma is full of sour cherries, oak, vanilla, some funk and farmhouse smells, and a bit of sweet malts.

T - Starts out with sharp and strong sour cherries with some acidity, some oak and a bit of vanilla alongside. Through the middle, some sweet malts with a touch of dark fruit and a bit of funk comes through. The finish is a mix of mellowing sour cherry, more funky farmhouse flavors, vanilla, oak, and some sweet malts.

M - Medium bodied with mild carbonation. Feels smooth with a sour, dry, and lightly acidic finish.

D - Very drinkable. The strength of the sour cherry flavor here is fantastic and the beer has some nice complexity around it to provide some balance.

Bottle thanks to Rasmusott. Pours dark amber with no head. Raspberries dominate the aroma along with caramel malts, brettanomyces, raisins, musty oak barrel. Rather malt forward with some oak and funky bretty goodness. The taste is very tart - lots of bacteria and brettanomyces, musty oak, sour cherries, citrusy sourness, caramel malts. A quite enjoyable sour ale, but a bit generic.

Pours a reddish brown with a small head. Aroma is of wine, brownish malts, not-quite-vinegar. Taste is sour, but not in the extreme. The brown ale backdrop provides an interesting counterpoint to the sour ale aspects. Body is very light. Sourness is done correctly through and through. Good complexity and good balance.

As ¬ìLips of Faith ¬ñ La Folie¬î. Sample at pushkinwow¬ís Beer Geek Extravaganza. 24MR12. 
App.:  Rich brown, tan rim.
  
Aroma:  Rich tangy fruit, wood, funk, classic Flemish sour, rich dark dried fruit support.
  
Palate:  Medium body, full, rounded effervescence.
  
Flav.:  Sour cherries, wood, funk, acidity, dark dried fruits; sour and bitter, good malty fruity, spicy finish.

Nice.

Sharp aroma with a extreme sour bite for the nostrils.  Without friends knowing what i ordered sitting close to me, I told them to try my Porter I ordered and they about dropped the glass.  Funny trick!  Pours deep black.  When held up to light a deep cranberry red shines through.  Taste is sour wine grapes and bitter sour candy.  Not my style of beer but I appreciate sour ales a lot.  They are wildly different than anything I¬íve ever tasted before.  Cheers

UPDATED: MAY 20, 2012 2012 bottle pours reddish brown with some short lived light tan head. Aromas are sour apples, and vinegar. Tastes are lactic, sour apple, some maltiness, and not overly sweet. Body is light to medium with average carbonation and a nice crisp finish. Overall, a wonderful sour that lives up to its billing.

UPDATED: JUN 28, 2012 Glad I could make La Folie my 1500th rating!!  On tap at Road 34 in Fort Collins.  Clear dark dark amber with a small persistent white head. Aroma is super unique. Medium tart sourness with an earthy dark malt tone, very slight chocolate, burnt caramel, and a little oak. Taste is smooth and balanced, complex but easy to drink. Dark earthy burnt toffee malt, some medium sourness yeastiness, a fair touch of oak, earthy dark cocoa, earthy toffee again, and a mildly puckering finish with a aftertaste of earthy oaked toast. Super complex, and very flavorful. And a fair amount of some citric hop on the finish as well.  Might just be my imagination....

burgundy color with small, bubbly, off-white head. The aroma is tart and funky. Sour cherries, green apples and yeast. Taste is sour cherry up front with a thin vanilla flavor in the middle, and some more oaky cherry flavor at the end.

This was a very enjoyable drink.  Split a 2012 bottle with my friend.  The taste is heavily sour with some sweetness.  Some apple butter and balsamic vinegar notes.  Nice mouthfeel with a long finish.  Overall, I enjoyed this beer and would not think twice about buying another bottle next time I see one.

A friend in San Francisco shipped this over. Poured into a Tulip at fridge temperature.

A - 1 finger off white head. Gone immediately. Dark read to brown appearance. 

S - seriously tart. Citrus and berries, wood and Pinot grigio. Cherries 

T - insane tartness. Berries, red wine, oak ands some smokiness. Floral

M - 90% bubbles. Light bodies

O - wow. A+

Bomber. Pours dark reddish brown, small off-white head that dissipates pretty quickly. Dark hue, but pretty clear. Nose is big cherry, vinegar, sour green apple. Taste is incredibly tart right up front, more sour cherry and apple. Fleeting finish, and that¬ís my only knock against it; I¬íd have liked a bit more lingering. Still, pretty fantastic.

From notes.  First reviewed 12/10/2011.  Served on tap in a snifter.

La Folie has a deep brown color with a cherry tint. As the glass wanes, a fuller cherry color is noticeable. A simmering white head is slowly reduced over time and leaves some light sticky lace.

The aroma is fairly light on any sugar of malt presence. Tart cherries, a burst of lemon, and a bit of orange all provide a tart aroma. A lot of woody oak comes through as it warms up a bit.

A dirth of true malt presence really lets the sour flavors come through right away. Lemon juice and zest come through strong, with tart cherry adding a bit of additional zing. The sour flavors grow into a climax midway through, and slowly come down as a fierce woody oak flavor steps in to close out each sip.

This is definitely on the dry side for what I have had in the sour arena. There is not much malt sweetness, although the intense sour flavor does create some salivation, giving an illusory mouthfeel presence of a sweeter beer. The carbonation is fairly standard, with small bubbles neither being too crisp nor creamy. For how sour it is, it is not that acidic and even less vinegary. 

Overall: This was the first sour I had a long time ago, and it threw me off. Now I would say it is a great addition and one of my sour standbys.

Red/brown, huge off white head forms, with good lacing. Smell is nice, cherries, caramel. Taste is cherries and brown sugar, oak, very acidic, lemons, more fruits, very sour finish. Mouthfeel is light to medium bodied with medium carbonation.

Tap @ Euclid Halls, Denver. Pours deep ebony with a huge creamy light brown head, leaving nice lacings. Aroma of sweet tart fruit, cherry, peach, raspberry, oak, yeasts. Taste is huge sour fruity, raspberries, cheery, oak, green grapes, light vinegar, tartness. Thin body, soft carbonation, lasting dry sour finish. Lovely beer. 050312

Bottle. Pours a dark reddish brown color with a beige head. Aroma is of dark cherries, pop rocks, balsamic vinegar, caramel and sugar. The flavor is quite tart with lots of cherries and balsamic vinegar, the pop rocks like flavor, caramel, brown sugar, oak and some dark fruit. The body is medium with a dry mouth feel. Overall a really nice Sour and its a lot like Rodenbach Gran Cru, just not as complex.

Tap at a charity event for Alex¬ís Lemonade Stand. Small carbonation. Aroma is of wood and fruit although there is no fruit in it. Taste is slightly acidic and sour. Reminds me of Supplication. Very nice beer.

Bottle at Toronado SF. It pours deep ruby, with a thin beige head. The nose is malt vinegar, balsamic, tangy cherry, strawberry and wood. The taste is malt vinegar, tart cherry, wood, stewed strawberry, cherry pip, touch of spice and lemony tartness, with a tangy-tart finish. Medium body, moderate carbonation and decent balance. I like it quite a bit, but prefer Rodenbach Grand Cru.

Lips of faith series: Acidit√© agressive, ass√©chante qui mart√®le sans retenue. Pomme grenade explosive avec les tannins du ch√™ne, combinaison parfaite pour accompagner mon magret de canard. Forte personnalit√©.
Big cherry, sour apple nose w/mustiness present.  Oaky, tart cherries, apples with some great funk on the palate.  A great sour bite with good carbonation.  All around  a fantastic beer,.

Usually not into sours but thought I¬íd give it a try.  This beer is so complex, the taste goes through a few transitions.  Its acidic, fruity, and dry.  I really enjoyed, after every sip I would think that was a crazy flavor but kept wanting more.

Deep beautiful brown with brilliant red edges and tan head. Light citric acidity, cherry, wood, red wine-type notes, raisin, mild toasted malt, faint vanilla  Flavor is sweeping medium tart sour, dark cherry across the front of the tongue that mellows and dries out a bit.  Some raisin.  Lingering citrus-type sour, vanilla, and very light toasted/roasted malt.
2005 corked vintage from RBWG) Nose is dark fruits,tart..Taste is sour skittles, tart, wood,apple, earthy, brett..Palate is tangy and dry..makes you pucker..Wow

Rating #2000. Original hand bottled, caged and corked vintage that I¬íve had forever. 11/07 - #13,388. Shared with Ceebs25 for the special occasion. Pours a murky, dark brown-red colored body with an inch thick, lively, dirty beige head that dissipates slowly and leaves a veil of beautiful lacing throughout. Gorgeous beer. Aroma is funky and tart with some barnyard, sweet cherries, and wood. Slightly acidic and a light caramel, smooth malt shows up behind the sourness. Pretty awesome aroma and the flavor is no different. Tart and funky up front with a great sourness. The mellowness of the brown malt gives off just a touch of caramel and really keeps everything balanced and exceptionally easy drinking. Some sweet cherries, acidity, and a good amount of wood before the cherries grow in tartness and the sourness picks up in the finish, but it ends so clean and balanced while drying with just the slightest bitterness and a really nice woodiness. The aftertaste doesn¬ít linger forever, but has a very pleasant sweet cherry sourness and acidity. Very smooth, clean, light body with a slightly lively, very soft carbonation. Overall, an extremely impressive sour. Everything works exceptionally well together and it¬ís hard to think that this beer would ever be drinking better than it is now. Wonderful, clean sourness with a nice cherry sweetness, plenty of wood, and a great, light malt base. This was worth the long wait to open. Awesome.

(75cl bottle) A brownish red body with a medium diminishing tan head. Sour, tart aroma with notes of dark wood, yeast, and hints of cherry and apple. Medium body with mild soft carbonation. Bright acidic flavor is tart but not cloying; barnyard, mild spice.
On trap at Alchemy.  Pours a murky brown with no head.  Aroma of dates, but I don¬ít know what dates smell like.  Smooth drinkable sour...

I bought a single 22oz bottle of this at Woodman¬ís in Janesville, WI for $12.79 in Early 2012. 

Pours a dark brown color with a thick, fluffy head. There is a semi-strong sour scent mixed with sugars and fruits. The taste is unlike anything I have ever had before. There is a strong, sour tartness in the taste. It¬ís sour but yet fruity and juicy mostly of apples. For some reason this totally took me back to my childhood when Warheads were a popular sour candy, this beer is basically a beer version of sour apple Warheads. Once again, unlike anything else I have ever had before. Well worth the try even at $12. Great work New Belgium.

2012 vintage. Pours deep dark red with white head that mostly dissipates. Aroma is complex: lactic sour, wood, sour fruit, basement, and the slightest hint of vinegar. Flavor is massively sour. It is hard to believe that there is no fruit in this beer. Sour fruit with a some bready malts and just enough funk. Mouthfeel is lively and finish is long and sour. Better balanced than last year. This is up there with any sour (or beer) out there.

I really can¬ít say I am much of a fan of New Belgium but I absolutely LOVE this beer. Pours a dark, dark brown with a reddish hue with a bit of a head. Smells tart and sour with a touch of some thin malt sweetness underneath. Taste is tart, dark cherries, fruit and the brown ale base serves its purpose quite well. Not sure I detect any direct flavor from it but its a great base. Very crisp, with a enjoyable amount of carbonation to it, and lighter in body. I absolultely love this beer and if it was even somewhat affordable I would have this as a staple in my fridge during the duration of its release period.

La Folie Sour Brown 2012.  Pours a Dark Brown with a about a fingers size head.  The Aroma is earthy and has hints of tart cherry.  Taste is very sour with cherry and vanilla with candy notes on the finish.  Palate has a medium body with nice tingly carbonation and a good sour finish. This is an amazing sour beer and lived up to the hype I have heard. All and all amazing!
750 ml champagne bottle. Pours a copper red color with white head. Tart cherry, lemon and vinegar flavors. Mouth watering with intense flavor. Great sour.

The 2012 Lips of Faith Series in a 22oz bottle.
Color: Dark brow
Aroma:Woody vanilla, some barn and saddle
Body: Big sourness, tart, some apples, lemon, grass and hey
Finish: Dry and tart
Over-all/Mouth-fell:More sour the\an I expected, lightly carbonated, medium body
Cranberry nose, twigs and sticks. Clear tea, thin yellow head. Very tart, cranberry flavor. Mouthfeel is like 9%olt battery on the tongue, not hot.

Bought in the big bottle and aged for around 2 years. Poured with a big head on it and a wonderful sour scent. Really enjoyed the sours on this. Big earthy tones and a little sweetness in the aftermath.
Whiskey- like appearance. The nose is a complex mix of oak and a little brett. Medium bodied sour ale. A very good example. Medium finish.
Heavy vinegar, cherry, grape and oak aromas. Above average sourness that lingers.

Bottle found at Spec¬ís, dated April 6, 2009. They said it has been in the attic...
Very wild aroma, soured raspberries and cranberries. A good head can be worked up, but it doesn¬ít last very long. Color is almost like Coca-Cola. Taste is very sour, even moreso than what I had on draft a week ago at the New Belgium tasting room. Maybe due to the age. Taste sensation almost like extremely dry cranberry/grapefruit juice, then it finally gets a little sweeter with hints of licorice. It is different with age, not better or worse. I really like!

On tap. Thin cap that vanishes quick with a small island of happy tiny bubbles getting to float on this clear, deep brown liquid awesome. Aroma is sour apple and cherry. Woody too. The taste. Lots going on. Sour cherries, tart apples, dark malty taste to it. At first tasted nutty, that ripped into the fruitiness mentioned. The nuttiness maybe what I get from the sour wood? Don¬ít know, but it was great. I really enjoyed this beer.

RBAG. From bomber. Pours brown, clear with a thin white head.  Aroma has apple fruit, big sourness. In the mouth there is big sourness, mellow vinegar, lemons. Medium body. Soft carbonation. Long sour finish. Very satisfying sour.

Pours dark reddish brown with ruby highlights and a fizzy white head.  Aroma is tart, sour cherries, red wine, and a hint of vinegar.  Taste is very tart with notes of sour cherries, red wine, and oak.  Excellent beer.

Pours a dark red/brown, with small tan head. aroma is sour candy, yeast, slight roastyness. Lively carbonation, very sour off the bat, but an odd amount of roastyness, almost like a stout. Some oak flavors, lots of fruitiness, apples, cherry.. The roasty malt flavor really sets this sour apart and makes it interesting compared to others I have had. Great stuff.

Bomber. Pours a chestnut brown with a thin, soapy beige head that has great retention and leaves decent lacing. Aroma is tart apple, woody oak notes, a touch of caramel, sweet fruity notes, hints of spice and dusty stone fruit. Flavor is oddly nutty and somewhat roasty up front, and unexpected, but interesting start, tart apple, sour berries, lactic acidity, some acetic acid in there as well, light earthy notes, musty leaves, toffee and some spiciness to the finish. Palate is light to medium bodied, a liittle syrupy up front, has a nice, moderate strength very blanketing carbonation and an fairly dry acidic finish. Very tasty. Good all around package.
UPDATED: FEB 14, 2012 Pours a dark cherry brown, little head out of the tap.  Fruity tart cherry flavor that ends without needing to make a sour face.  Balanced well for a sour.

UPDATED: NOV 27, 2012 ** I¬íve since had a few C&C versions of La Folie, all of which put the bottled vintages to shame.  The ¬í04 is particularly stellar. **

Shared with Nate as a precursor to our inaugural Night of the Sours. 2011 vintage.

Body is brown with red hues; nice head and lace. Tart cherries greet my nose right out of the bottle. Still holds faint hints of lightly toasted malts, which is a nice touch. Funky sour yeast demands to be sipped.

Sour cherries over a brown ale base. Oaky barrel goodness. Tart, funky yeast. Great blend job, impeccably balanced. Full, creamy body.

One of the best off-the-shelf sours available in the USA, and a fantastic value at ~$14/bomber. Praying they decide to ship to NYC soon.

UPDATED: FEB 28, 2012  A - interesting clear golden red pour , with little off-white head . 

S  - Subtle soy sauce and basalmic, sour grapes,  and apple cider . 

M - simple sour that mixes well with the tastes, high carb. 

T- sour on the nose , with apple cider and sour grapes, light malts, soy sauce. Simple. 

O - my first sour and it was quite simple but good. 

7/7+

Poured a murky brown with a ring of head. Aroma was very sour apple and cherry. Super sour taste with sour fruits and vinegar. Very dry on the palate.   Not an everyday drinker but very interesting and I will definitely have it again.
Bottled sample from the 2010 series.  Not my style of beer but this was enjoyed by all who tried.  Am sure it is a great one.

22 OZ Bottle, Labeled as New Belgium Lips of Faith - La Folie Sour Brown Ale-Brown pour w/almost no head but good lacing. Sour aroma. Very, very, very, very sour flavor to this, sour apples, woodsy, oaky, earthy, but mostly sour. Although it was so sour it made me pucker up & shudder w/every drink, & I certainly wouldn¬ít want a beer like this every night, I really liked it! Just can¬ít drink too much of it at a time. Long SOUR finish

UPDATED: OCT 12, 2012 Draft 10/12/12.  Taste after a year to get into sours now reveals a medium tart cherry finish, with some tart green apples.  Starts off a bit funky to reveal the full on fruit assault.  Much more enjoyable than a year ago.  


Draft 12/15/11.  Pours dark brown w mahogany, tan with little head.  Smell is sour ripe cherries, earthiness, maybe green apples.  Taste is very tart to me with sour cherries, other berries and just a hint of vinager.  I can¬ít say that I loved it as I am still trying to adopt the style, but it certainly had its moments of pleasantness and I would like to try again.  7/3/7/3/15 3.5

Trevlig syrlig doft.
S√∂tsyrlig smak, j√§tte sn√§ll men mycket fina jordgubbstoner

Bottle, as New Belgium Lips of Faith - La Folie Sour Brown Ale. (bought at Binny¬ís Beverage Depot - Lincoln Park, Chicago in October 2011)

Clear reddish/brown with a minimal white head. Nice sweet aroma with berries, wood, apples and maybe some vanilla. The sourness was soft, but it was there. The taste was good, berries with a pleasant sourness. The finish was dry. Reminded of a Rodenbach. Worth a try.

UPDATED: DEC 23, 2012 Date: December 8, 2011 Mode: Draft Source: Heritage Beer Geek Christmas Tasting Description: Reddish brown pour with some head, sour, tart and maybe some oak or woodiness in there.  Damn this was ripe, too much for me, but I am not a huge sour guy.  Could smell this before even lifting the glass.  

December 23, 2012 same as I remember woody sour apple that is just mouth puckering sour in the finish.  Bumped overall to a 15 from 14, but left the rest.

2010 VINTAGE consumed on Thanksgiving pours murky light brown with little head and little retention.  Aroma is sweet malt vinegar, earthy malt like a scotch ale, green apple, sour funk.  Taste is a hint of chocolate, sour green apple, toffee, malt vinegar tartness and acidity.  Body is medium, frothy, active carbonation, dry sour finish.  Overall, a great age on a great brew.  this one gets really malt vinegary with age, if that¬ís your thing.
EXCELLENT SOUR BEER. Greatest bang for the buck. Accessible just about anywhere now. The sweetest of the sours. (Without tasting like chinese food)

Pours a deep brown red with thin white head.  Aroma is full of sour notes and malty goodness.  Taste is a bit more subdued, revealing some chocolate and caramel malt flavors.  Really complex as this beer is still unwinding itself on my tongue a few moments after a sip.  Very nicely done!
A wonderful sour beer.  More vinegar flavors than heavy fruits like some others.  Great to drink, not overwhelming and a good level of alcohol.  One of my favorites.
Pours a beautiful deep brownish-red with fizzy head, a tart raspberry flavor with a lingering, deep-seated lime finish.  Quite delicious and surprisingly refreshing.

22 oz bottle.  Crystal clear and tawny, it pours lively and is still after a few moments.  the aroma offers cherry and hints of pineapple, with some vinegar and afull earthy dose of Brett.  Medium-light in the mouth, the acidic edge is surprisingly mellow.   The flavor is an appetizing balance of must, wood and sour fruit, the finish a firm shot of dark malt vinegar.  As complex as any Flanders ale.
Full tart mouthfeel with a lingering raspberry taste in the finish. Great sweet/sour balance with clean fruity flavors.
Delicious flavors of sour crab apple, cherry, wine, and oak. A very delicious sipper and one of the best sour beers I have had.

From 2010.  Pours a translucent mahogany with a small tan head.  Fantastic, classic, vinegary sour brown ale nose with notes of caramel and toffee.  Great balance on the flavor.  There¬ís just the right amount of bite to this.  Classic balsamic vinegar flavors and sourness.  I love this.  It¬ís right up there with Deschutes The Dissident in terms of domestically made sour browns.

22oz bomber from Pinch poured into a snifter. Pours a dark nut brown with a small bit of tan head. Aroma of green apples and alcohol. Taste is heavily sour. Tastes like Granny Smith apples and Warheads candy. Light bodied with a thin texture. Lively carbonation and a long sour finish. Overall, very good for my first sour. Something I would drink again, but next time I would share with a friend.

2011. Poured from Bottle. Poured a dark brown with a tan head. Aroma of tart apples and cherries, slightly sour. Medium sour taste with notes of grapefruit. Slight "Cap¬ín Crunch" bite at the end. Not my favorite, but I¬íd drink again.

AROMA: metallic, sour cherries; APPEARANCE: deep brown with strong red tones, not much lacing after a few minutes but it pours big; TASTE: so sour, PALATE: a tiny bit creamy, good body but not full, a bit effervescent, big finish, very rounded; OVERALL;   If you like sour beers, this is as good a place to rest as any.

In taster at Churchill¬ís in San Marcos.   Looks dark ruby red.  Like brown head.  Smells of amber malts and slight sour.  Tastes of some amber malts and super sour like grapefruit.   Lots of tart.  Overall 7.5 of 10.

This brew poured up a rich, dark amber colored body sporting a hearty foamy head that quickly dissipated but left a thin sheen on top to form out some amazing lacing effects on the glass.  Aromas rich with cherries and sour mash, oak and clover.  Flavors of sour cherries (really sour cherries), oak, spices, and clover.  Did I mention this bugger was sour?! All flavors are well-balance but it¬ís the ¬ësour¬í that you better get prepared for!  Medium-bodied with a spicy, sour finish; but very, very refreshing.
Dark brownish red color.  Aroma of cherries and cinnamon.  Really tart flavor.  Enjoyable beer.  Like Rodenbach, but more sour.
lost my notes for this one. Considerably the best belgian brown I¬¥ve ever had. Remember it had loads of edic, tannins, and cherries. Heavy palate, desert style. We were all blown away

Serving Glass: Poured from tap into tulip/snifter.

Appearance: Very dark red with a pinkish tint. Small cap and some nice lacing.

Aroma: Oak, tart apples, grapes and cherries. Some pepper. Great oak aroma.

Taste: Major cider and vinegar. Very tart and sour. Lots of apple and grape, with a great oak character. Very light cherry. Finish has some nice peppery notes.

Palate: Moderately high carbonation, medium body. Nice dry and tart finish.

Overall: Hallelujah, I finally have had a New Belgium beer that I actually love.

Bouteille. Couleur Brune avec des teintes rubis, beau col pr√©sent tout au long de la d√©gustation. Odeur s√ªr/acide avec le cot√© bois√©. La pomme y est aussi bien pr√©sente. Go√ªt s√ªr avec l¬íacidit√© ne venant pas trop couvrir le go√ªt. Finale me rappelant la sensation des bonbons s√ªrs ayant berc√©s ma jeunesse!

This reminded me of a more acidic version of rodenbach grand cru.  Taste was very similar with a bit more of a sour apple flavor. Finish was a bit vinegar and not quite as pleasant as I had hoped.  Still enjoyable though.
Sour apples are dominant with some plums in the finish. A little one dimensional but an amazing sour nose. Pretty awesome, but not amazing.

Mild funky Brett with some fresh cut wood and a background of cherries for the nose.  Medium sourness with dark surgars and berries.  Old wood flavors taste in its wake.  Dry vinous finish.  Very enjoyable, looking forward to the next bottle, which is important because this isn¬ít so rare that I could only have it once in my lifetime.

on tap @ Tylers Apex. no date, not on tap now, but wan¬ít that long ago. Good aroma, sour & sweet. got a quick raisin/date scent that quickly left, the a fruity  sour smell dominates, tart apple, some berry about it. Dark reddish orange color. Good head, ok lace. Sour flavor. Medium body, smooth mouthfeel, dry tary finish. Tasty, nice range in aroma, lots of fruits, big bitter brew.
user_location: the Containment Area, North Carolina, USA

text: I know there are people that like this, but I cannot be included in their number.  Bomber to Chalice.  Pours dark amber with no head at all, bad sign.  I smell sour cherries and soy sauce, another bad sign.  Taste is sour, yechh, Couldn¬ít finish it on a dare, or even a double dog dare.  I¬íll try to be fair on the numbers, but this is not for me.
Reddish brown with off white head.  Slightly tart aroma.  A nice tart edge on a moderate bodied beer...much like a rodenbach.

Bomber 2011. Reddish brown with a tan head. Nice sour and funk aroma, tart raisins and prunes, apples, oak, bit of vanilla. Sour and tart, medium bodied, decent carbonation, gets you at the sides of the tongue and leaves a nice coating throughout your mouth. Finish is dry and tart, great balance between the sour, tart, and funk. Well worth seeking out.

Bottle. Poured a clear dark brown with an average sized light brown fizzy head that was gone before I took the first sip and had virtually no lacing to speak of. The aroma was kind of sweet with roasted cookie malts and a sweet yeast with notes of brown sugar, some dark dried fruit and a hint of sour apples. It tasted very lightly sweet and malty with a nice dried fruit note at first then WOW did it get sour real quick with a strong does of sour apple at the end. Mouthfeel was light to medium in body and very dry in texture with a very lively carbonation. Overall as sour beers go this one is right up there. Very sour and very tasty. If you like sour beers this one is definitely worth a try...

Poured pretty rough, results in a nice 2 fingers of head that goes away right away. Leaves no lacing.

the smell is sour and tart candy! when it is cold the smell is a bit mild, as it warms the sour candy smell comes out much more.

The taste is great. Each sip get a bit more sour each time. Sour I get a lot of currents and dark fruit from this beer. A great dry finish on the mouth with a great lip smack of sour pucker!

Had a bomber by myself and it reminded me of when I would eat a whole bag of sour gummy worms and wreck my taste buds when I was a kid!

Poured from a 22oz bottle into a goblet. The aroma was amazing. Hints of red fruit, green apple, vinegar, and a crisp sour aroma. The color was a deep amber/brown. This its where it gets disappointing. The flavor of the beer was of indiscriminate sourness. No specific aroma notes were present in the flavor of the beer. Just....sour. There was basically no malt body or backbone. Not the worst beer, just fell well below expectations.

UPDATED: JUN 28, 2012 Yet another delicious sour from New  Belgium.  La Folie doesn¬ít attack your tastebuds with Warhead-like aggression; rather, it takes a moment for the sourness to build, slowly growing momentum until the oak-laced finish takes hold.  Easy-drinking yet deep, this brew rocks.

UPDATED: FEB 25, 2013 Dark brown with a ruby highlights and a nice beige head. Aroma of sour cherries, apples and other fruits, spice and wood. The taste is quite tart, but with assertive malt and fruit profiles. Medium bodied with long, dry, tart finish. Very nice.

Cherry aroma and a nice first sip pucker on the back of your tongue.  Light black licorice and heavy fruit especially cherries both in the taste and on your palate.  I didn¬ít get a lot out of the aroma but there was a ton of aromatic food (burgers, steaks, soups) in the general vicinity.  It was a nice light sour overall, very pleased to have been introduced to it at Urge Gastropub in North County San Diego.

22 oz bottle

Aroma- Smell is of cherries and apples with some vinegar.

Appearance- Dark, full amber color with some fizzy head that dissapates quickly. No lacing.

Palate- Very pleasant to the palate. Sour, but no heartburn. I find this to be a very refreshing sour ale.

Overall- Very high quality beer. Wish this was readily available to me!

Tasted on 5/24/11 from a 750mL corked and caged bottle obtained in a trade, bottled in November 2007.  Pours hazy dark amber with a thick white head which slowly recedes to a thin, even collar of lace.  The nose is super complex, tart, sour, and funky with caramel malt, balsamic vinegar, vanilla oak, red fruit, and green apple.  The flavor is abrasively sour with tart red fruit, green apple, funky barnyard brett, brown sugar and caramel malt, vanilla oak, and a good amount of tannin.  The body is medium with an oily texture, light but stinging carbonation and a long sour and funky finish.

UPDATED: MAY 1, 2014 ReRate:  bottle from green¬ís in atlanta.  muted sour and green apples aroma.  Tastes are a sharp tart mix of brown sugar, more tart, green apple, tart, and then some caramel maybe...  this is some spike stuff - really tight and even bitter lemon tart with sweet caramel malt in the background somewhere.  Green apple lingers in the long vinegar sour taste.  Even better than the first time.   Bumped rating a point.
------- the ¬í10 and ¬í11 at Proof - not sure who brought it.  Nice sharp sour taste - cherry, vinegar.  Wonderful - need more than a taste to evaluate properly.  Look forward to a re-rate.

UPDATED: JUN 13, 2011 this beer is one of the best sours out there. always a treat to get some on draft or out of the bottle. recently had on tap at falling rock.  tasted nice and tart. 
6/11/13 2010 bottle on tour at New Belgium. Very tart and sour a delicious beer

Corked and caged...thanks to whoever popped this at Dave¬ís going-away tasting.

With age this beer takes on a sort of raspberry character in addition to massive amounts of tartness; there¬ís certainly a good bit of acetic acid, but it doesn¬ít burn the throat or overpower the nostrils.  Really a damn good sour; one of the best American Wilds ever made and certainly better in the old bottles than the new.
Don¬ít know who to thank for this but it was a treat.  Tart, tart, more tart and tart.  Refreshing and crisp.  Good try it.
Bottle. Clear dark brown pour with a fizzy head. Aroma is sour fruit and wood and brown ale. Taste is acidic sour with strong earthly and fungal notes. Palate finishes dry.

22 ounce bottle, 2010 vintage.  Served in a tulip glass, the beer pours a ruby red/brown color with about an inch light tan head.  The head didn¬ít stick around for too long, and there¬ís a small amount of lacing on the glass.  Aroma is apple vinegar, tart cherries, oak and some brown sugar.  The brew tastes like tart and sweet cherries, vinegar, tart apples, plums and a bit of caramel and chocolate.  It¬ís mostly sour but the sweet flavors are definitely noticable.  There¬ís also a lingering tart finish.  Mouthfeel/body is medium, it¬ís a bit slick and smooth with good carbonation.  I think it¬ís a pretty good overall brew.  I¬íve been looking forward to trying this for a while, and I certainly wasn¬ít disappointed with this beer at all.  Definitely worth trying.
Bottle shared by a friend. Clear brown pour with a medium beige head. Malty nose with caramel, toffee and some tart fruit. Creamy caramel flavor with cherry, berries and a sourdough bread finish.
Bottle.  Poured brownish red.  Medium head.  Aroma was dried fruit, sourness, funk and alcohol.  Flavor to match.  Really sour but nice finish.  Great beer.

Poured into Snifter glass.  Color is a ruby brown.  Aroma is sour grapes and alcohol with some chocolate.  Flavor is sour fruit also with chocolate notes on the finish.  Palate is tart and has a wine like feel.  Overall I am entirely unfamiliar with this category but it seems to be everything I¬íve heard about a sour.

UPDATED: AUG 7, 2015 Poured from the bomber into a tulip style glass. Pours a Brown with a slight reddish hue. Thin frothy tan head. Aroma is like that of a strong ale, slightly strong alcohol, with strong hints of dried fruit, raisins, prunes, etc. Also some chocolate from the malt is noticed, on the finish as well as the aroma. As my first sour, wow this is sour! Second sip is much more mild. For my first sour, I am really impressed with the s look forward to many more.

It poured a hazy brown color with an off-white head. The sourness was prominent with a light bitterness. The aroma was tart with a hint of berries and cask wood. An excellent sour ale with lots of lively carbonation.

UPDATED: APR 2, 2012 Bottle, shared with tarheels. Pours hazy brown with a big yellow/off-white head. Aroma is barnyard, tannic, oak, cherries, some acetone. Flavor is very tart, oaky, sour apples, more acetone. Finishes dry, tart. Too much nail polish remover.  

Re-rate, 2012 bottle: huge improvement over previous sample, very little vinegar, primarily oak and lemon/lime, sour apple, intense sour. Very good.

On tap at Roman¬ís pub.  Opaque brown with a thin tan head.  Aroma is wild and funky with tannins, oak, mild tart cherries and notes of varnish.  Taste is moderately funky with wild Brett yeast, oak, tannins and cherry.  Sour and tart but not mouth puckering, this slow sipper was pretty tasty.

Bottle. Clear dark brown pour with a quick fizzy kahki head that fades. Aroma is sour cherries and wood and I get a faint vanilla too. Taste is acidic sour cherries and a oak taste along with bitterness. Palate is thin and acidic and finishes dry.

my first new belgium. thanks to the great Rb member at redlight for sharing! aroma is sour, tart, a bit of oak. taste was more of the same but not as smooth as i like my sours. overall a decent sour but I prefer RR

This beer pours a nice dark brownish red color, small amount head and a touch of lacing on the sides of the snifter it was served in. Overall a beautiful appearance.

The smell was tart, sour cherry and apples with an obvious oak back note.

The taste was a delicious malty cherry and apple combination. A touch of the oak but the tartness tends to overwhelm the pallet. This to me is not a bad thing. The flavor profile is tart and a bit puckering, but it also has a complexness to it with the tree fruits and the malt and the oak.

I find these sour beers to be almost addicting as I can¬ít stop sipping them once I start.

The mouthfeel was right on for the style and it wasn¬ít too thick or syrupy, nor was it too thin.

I really enjoyed this beer.
22oz bottle, sour tart aroma, hints of oak and cherry. Very Bretty, sour but.smooth. Probably the best beer out if Colorado. Absolutly amazing.

clearly im not a fan of sour ales. this one came bottled, pours amber/brown with a large tan head. aromas of oak, apple and cherry. heavy sour beer which is so strong as to overwhelm the other flavors.  the sour apple/cherry flavors are lively on the tongue and last. if you like sours you¬íll like this, if not you¬íll think what i do---it¬ís just too sour.

Bottle, 2011 release. Pours a deep reddish-brown with a cinnamon-colored, fine-grained head. Nose is tart apple, vinegar, stinky cheese, and vanilla -- and I mean all those in a good way. Taste is immensely sour with no sweetness -- there are more apple and vinegar notes, as well as some oak and roast malt, and an overlong, funky finish. Wow, this is sour.

On tap at New Belgium with Carla, Andrew, Natasha and Mark. Pours a hazy hazel with tan foam. Smells sour with hints of oak and cherry. Tastes lightly sweet with medium sourness and hints of cherry, oak and maybe a little apricot.
bomber from a trade with ericandersnavy. shared with jsprime. awesome wood aged sour brown ale. jeff liked it too!
One of my favorites. You will not be disappointed if you like sours. Very sour, though.  Pricey, but good.
A really nice sour with a touch of vinegar flavor.  One of the best sours I¬íve had in a while.

Tap at the New Belgium pub at Denver airport while on layover at Thanksgiving 2010 ($6.50...not bad for a quality airport pint).  Pours equal parts red and brown with a layer of beige foam.  Aroma is big on fruit -- mainly sour cherry but also some apple and pear.  Also aroma notes of tart balsamic, some red wine, and a hint of funk.  Flavor of sour cherries and vinegar ("cherry vinaigrette"??) with some red wine, dry wood, and just a bit of funkiness.  Watery mouthfeel with some lingering sourness but not lip-puckeringly so.  Not Duchesse or Rodenbach but still quite good.  (942, 509)

Dark brown pour, little off white head, that dissapeared quickly. Aroma is very complex. sour cherries, oak, grassy, dark brown sugar, wet hay, and some light coffee. The flavor is very tart, like lambic tart...........it really gives off a wicked barnyard lambic sourness. This is an incredible beer!

medium brown with little white head and high carbonation for the style.  nose of wonderful sourness with hints of vanilla and oak.  low bitterness before wonderful tartness and more oak character.  dry finish and wondeful exampe

Strong fruity notes for the aroma. Amber red with clear complexion. Tan fluffy head with a dash of lacing. Heavy sour taste accompanied by a medium body. Slick texture with lively carbonation and a long, pleasant finish. Fantastic sour ale!!

Bottle thanks to my Secret Santa! Pours a clear reddish brown with a thin but dense off white head, beautiful. Aroma is sour, ketchup, cherries, vinegar - all very much like duchesse. Taste is sweet and sour, cherries, a bit of vinegar and quite a bit of caramel sweetness too. Palate is well carbonated and beautifully coats the inside of the mouth with the rich flavors this beer has to offer. Yum.

Ruby brown pour, lots of tan head, good retention... The aroma is strong and successful displays the vinegar and tartness of a flanders red... The taste is not as good, too harsh and astringent. After you drink half a glass good to go. Second time drinking this at the price of $15 no way I¬íd ever get this again. Get RGC for 9.

Via trade.  The aroma is sour, vinegar, substantial smoke, oak, tart cherries.   The appearance is clear brown/red, vanishing white head.  The flavor is vinegar, caramel, tart fruit, slight soap(?).  The finish is tart cherries. other fruits.  Medium/thin in body.  Enjoyable.

Deep brown pour, quickly fading head.
Aroma is big sour fruit. Flavor is super sour apples and fruit, with notes of blueberries, with a big sour to sweet finish transition. Round but puckering mouthfeel.

3rd March 2011  Bottle shared at ACBS courtesy of Steptin. Cheers James! Clear dark red beer, tiny cream coloured head. Sourish medicinal and Dr Pepper nose. Light dry palate. Taste follows the nose. Very dry finish with a sourish note. Not really my kind of beer but this was alright!
22oz bottle.Pours a dark brown with red tones and a similar red toned head.Nose is bright cherry and yeast.Taste is very sour cherry and apple.This is a beautiful sour,very straightforward and solid.

Serving: 22 oz. bottle from Whole Foods Austin.  It pours a slightly cloudy brown with ruby highlights but not much in the way of head.  The nose has a mix of funk, barnyard, cherry, oak, darker malt, and a nice sharp twang.  The flavor delivers that twang in a sour punch up front.
