The fruit notes add nice complexity with some malty sweetness helping to even things out.  Finishes surprisingly dry.  Nice oak and vinegar notes in there.  Medium bodied with high carbonation leading to a dry, clean finish.  Really well done.  Definitely one of the better sours I¬íve had.

Pours a medium brown. Good balanced smell that leads with green apples, with subtle ale/alcohol. First taste shocks the mouth a little, although not nearly to the extent of NB Le Terroir. Definitely a sour ale, but the brown ale comes through in the finish and as the palate adjusts becomes increasingly balanced. Lively and certainly tart (apples, maybe a little grape/cherry), but I could see drinking it by the pint unlike some other sours I¬íve had. 
22 oz bottle- 2011 batch, served in 6 oz tulip.

aroma is a rich creamy malt, with some slight raisny aroma in there as well sweet toastiness, awesome aroma, unlike anything I have ever smelt, first taste is sour, but not too sour and compliments the sweetness awesomely, very interesting beer, after a few swigs the brown ale really starts to come out at the end and finishes with a toasty creamy malt flavor that would be an awesome brown ale on its own even without the sourness, appearance is a dark brown, overall very awesome beer

Draft at Papago. Pours clear purple-brown, thin off-white head, ropey lacing. Nose is big port, cocoa, red grapes, funk. Flavours of tannin, red grapes, light soap, funk/yeast, long finish. Very bracing and tart. Tremendous.

From Notes (Thanks Armin!).  First sour ever.  Didn¬ít really know what to expect and ended up loving it.  A wonderfully mouth puckering sour beer, very dry mouthfeel.  Lots of tannin flavors, some fruit, dark cherry pits.  Woody.  Very nice.
Nice sour pucker. a great red ale, especially coming form new Belgium, It is a sour beast on tap.

UPDATED: SEP 20, 2014 Bottle @ Plovmand tasting. Red/brown body with a medium offwhite head. Aroma is sour, fruit, berries, balsamic vinegar. Flavor is sour, balsamic cherries and notes of oak. 7,4,7,3,15
RE-RATE: Lips of Faith Series, 2014. Bottle bought in CBX. Unclear brownish body with a small offwhite head. Oak, tart, fruit, berries, cherries, vinegar. Really delicious.

Bottled 11/07 sampled 1/09
Received in trade with sfromdawes, thanks for the opportunity.

Pours a crystal clear red/amber with a massive bubbly off white head that calms down after a while but never totally leaves. Aroma of tart cherries, acid, a little bit of funk, some spice. I can smell some sweet malt in the background especially as it warms. The taste is quite the puckering experience, sour citrus fruits, a bit of acid, some funk. Body is medium, mouthfeel is sour, carbonation is high. Great sour ale, I¬ím glad I got the chance to try this.

Pours darker amber brown with a tan head that quickly disappears.  Aroma is sour, acidic, and a little oaky.  Taste is very oaky, very sour, and finishes clean and maybe a slight bit bitter.  Sour notes are complex, cherries, apple, white grapes, lactic acid.  This is a very well done sour.  Very well done.

Bottle, 2011 release.  Aroma is sour cherries, wild yeast funk, raisins, plums, vinegar.  Pours a deep amber/brown with a 1/2" head that dissipates immediately.  Flavor is dominated by sour cherries.  Notes of oak, dark fruits, apples.  Fairly tart, but has a hint of sweetness in the finish.  Light-medium body with high carbonation, dry finish.  Great brew, really enjoyed this.

2011 bottle. Aroma is sour, lacto, wood, chocolate covered oranges, apple. Lots going on. Pours a murky brown. Wow. Very earthy and dry with a super nice sour finish. Notes of toffee and caramel. Great carbonation, really works with the beer. The sour flavor is incredible. The only beer from New Belgium I¬íve actually enjoyed. This is great.

UPDATED: OCT 4, 2015 Bottle. Cola pour with minimal head. Wood, nut, and vinegar all over everything. Special beer here. Awesome.

Update - not gonna adjust the rating for this, but I had the pleasure of trying a 2007 c&c version of this at WTWBA 2015 in Minneapolis. Good lord, was that amazing! I¬íd probably rate that in the 4.5 range.

Red-tinged brown in the glass with minimal head.  Sharp sour fruit aroma with a hint of oak.  The first thing that jumps out at you is the acidity in this beer, it¬ís pretty sour.  Flavors on the palate (other than the acidic sourness) include wine-like fruitiness and oak.  Finishes dry.  Great beer, definitely not for everyone, but a must try for fans of wild and/or sour styles.
Wow this is a good beer, dark pour with a small head.  Sour fruit aroma.  Almost lip puckering sour, but not overwhelming.  Nice bite from the carbonation.  Makes my mouth water.....so good!

22oz bottle.
Dark amber color with a small bit of head.  Aromas of sour cherry and a hint of oak.  Flavor is complex and just plain delicious.  Wonderfully sour with the slightest bit of vinegar.  All in all, this is one of the best brews I¬íve ever had from New Belgium.
Interesting beer, lotsa funky notes, nose just makes me happy, little to no head. flavor is funky sour with some nutty notes and some dried fruit. kinda horse blankey on the nose as it warms
(Bottle).  Pours dark brown with off-white head. Aroma is raisin, cherry and funk.  Nice beer. Very vinegary.

Bottle at plovmand tasting. 
Pours a red-brown colour with a white head. 
The aroma is dominated by balsamic vinegar, caramel, cherries and a hint of oak. 
The flavour lags some smoothness oak and depth, but has notes of cheap balsamic vinegar, cherries and caramel. 
Finishes with a pleasant after taste.

UPDATED: MAR 7, 2011  The carbonation is perfect and flavor is balanced...both sour and fruity. Super refreshing. It¬ís not as "winey" as some Flanders can be.  

3/4/2011 - got to drink some more of this. I love how it is a punch of tartness and then finishes dry. A great beer. 

3/7/2011 - having just had another supplication from Russian River, it¬ís so hard to think of la Folie as being as amazing. I¬ím gonna drop this a few cause it¬ís not even on the level of the sours that deserve upper fours and five.

Not sure how I haven¬ít rated this since I¬íve had it many times. 09 bottle. Pours a deep brown with a glowing red edge and a small off white head. Aroma is a beautiful mesh of sweet and sour cherries, sharp and aggressive with a nice vinegar character to it. A very nice earthiness. Flavor starts with a sharp cherry bite, aggressively acidic in a pure beautiful way. Excellent woodiness to balance the sharp and a touch sweet fruit, cherry and vinegar through the finish. Medium body and a sharp spritzy carbonation. Just an amazing sour ale.
Dark brown with a thin, light head.  Smells like green olives.  Very tart taste, almost vinegary.  One of my favorite sour beers.

Poured into a tulip.

3.5 A: Nearly clear dark amber brown color. One and a half fingers of frothy light brown head with poor retention and no lacing. Not very pretty, but given the style, it¬ís okay.

4.5 S: Tart with a healthy acetic acid twang. Woodiness with sour cherries and a touch of green apple. Not entirely complex, but forceful (in a good way).

4.5 T: Puckering sourness from the top with tart cherries and plums. Again there is a good bit of acetic acid. Plenty of brett funk as well. Oak woodiness with a soft caramel sweetness.

4.5 M: Light-medium body. Pleasant bubbly carbonation. Puckering up front with a soft semi-dry finish.

4.0 D: Very tasty brew. The drinkability would be higher if it wasn¬ít so acid forward. Still, I¬íd love to have a few of these on hand.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 01-17-2010 03:37:27
Clear brown pour with a thin head.  Slightly funky aroma with cherry, vinegar and nuts.  Flavor is mostly dark fruit with some background nuts and just enough sour.  Very nice beer!

Bottled. Reddish coloured. Unclear. Light brown head. Aroma of tart, cherries, sourness, some fruits and spice. flavour is grapy, sour and very tarty. Loads of cherry and sweetness. Medium to full bodied. Dry and cherrydense sourness in the end. Refreshing and delicious. Thx. plovmand for sharing.

Bottle. Pours reddish brown with a creamy light tan head. The aroma is sour cherries, acid, berries, vinegar, sweet caramel and sweet ripe fruit. The flavour is cherries, berries, caramel, vinegar, acid, sour apples and barnyard. Very delicious!

clear amber,  smooth small white head.
sourish aroma, slightly spiced, wood, raisins or dark fruits.
flavor is sour, stingy note that is perhaps a little citrussy, wood. nice flavor.

Smells like sour apples. Creamy light mocha head with a cherry cola appearance. The cherry cola that gets the grenadine added! Very heavy sour flavor. I dont think you could getmore sour in a beer. Taste like the green War Head¬ís candy. Very wild flavored and I loved it.. I was the kid who would eat sour gum balls all day!

UPDATED: APR 2, 2011 2010 vintage. Pours clear brown with red tint and fast fading, full tan head. Smells fruity, strawberries, with hints of sourness. Tastes sour, without a doubt, and fruity- strawberries and raspberries. Medium-bodied with a fluid, acidic texture and active mouth-carbonation, New Belgium La Folie from the Lips of Faith series 2010 finishes dry and less sour than expected. (4.8)
                                                                                                                                 2011 vintage. Pours deep mahogany that shines ruby red with a multi-finger tan head. Smells like sour red fruits: apple, strawberry, cherry; mild malty hints and no real hop presence. Tastes exceptionally sour, just sour at first but then some fruit flavors come forward, following the nose. Medium-bodied with a rolling, tingly texture and mild mouth-carbonation, New Belgium La Folie from the Lips of Faith series 2011 finishes solidly sour, asking for another taste. (5.0)

On draught and from the bottle across multiple batches/vintages. I have had this beer a lot and can¬ít seem to get into it. While I do feel that it is New Belgium¬ís best beer, and a sour that you should seek out if you can¬ít get anything else (e.g. Rodenbach or Duchesse), it still contains the tell-tale characteristics of the New Belgium fermentation characteristics that I liken to fresh lawn bags--the big black plastic ones that you put leaves into. I respect this beer, but only to a point. Aside from the aforementioned "off" aroma and flavor profiles, the beer is well structured and balanced on the palate. It is certainly worth a try to decide for yourself. As a huge sour fan myself, this one just doesn¬ít do it for me.

Pours like well-composed reddish brown juice.  Mild carbonation.  Aroma is sour apple, wood.  Flavor is acetic acid on the sides of the tongue.  Some nuts. Very clean on the palate.  Stephanie said it tasted like a warhead.  My first sour red.

Pours dark reddish brown, almost no head.  Aroma is funky, sour, some apple vinegar notes.  Medium body, high carbonation, dances on the tongue.  Very nice palate.  Soft yet intense sourness, green apples, long sour finish with a hint of funk.  Very nice!

Cask conditioned at Dieu du Ciel.  This beer has a reddish tinge and no head.  It just smells right: tart, apple skins, berries and sour candy.  The flavour is much the same.  It¬ís tart, with no off flavours.  Grape skin bitterness.  The body is quite full.  Excellent!

Very sour, very tastey. Pours brown with little or no head. Sour aroma, some toasted malt and a gentle nuttiness in the background. The tartness in the flavour gains in intensity toward the finish, some malt sweetness is there. Nice medium to full body
Mahogany color,small beige head.Sour nose,hint of carmel.Big acetic strong sour palate.Too puckery for my liking

This was really sour, even for a sour ale.  But still very enjoyable.   Pours a dark brown and has a deep sour bitter taste that overpowers the malt sweetness.  Good caramel notes and dark fruit notes as undertones.  Could have been scaled back a tad, but I enjoyed it very much.
Fermented cow pee. Absolutely horrible. Very disappointed. More words then. It looks good in the glass, it smells funny and it tastes horrible. I want my money back.

A little surprised by how much I enjoyed this. Rich and full. Not too carbonated. Medium level of the funk with a good solid sour finish. Not too earthy - more refined than anything. The base beer I gather would be very nice just by itself. Top class.

Draft at Cooper¬ís Alehouse poured into a tulip. This was very sour. I have tried several sour beers before, and almost all of them were more enjoyable than this: sour cherry, vinegary tartness clouded over other aspects of the beer. Faint rich maltiness and no noticeable hop flavor/bitterness. I didn¬ít know this was oaked when I tried it, don¬ít remember any oak flavors. Possibly a draft problem, possibly served too cold.

Notes from 10/2008. C&C 2008 vintage.

(Let me preface this by saying I am new to sour beers and this is the first Flanders Red I have bought. Still, I have high expectations for this one.)

Darker than I expected: a dark bing cherry crimson with a nice-looking two finger, lightly pink head. Head recedes, but it takes a few minutes to get down to a comfortable half finger skin atop the beer. 

Tart cherries. Sweet vinegar. Other fruits I can¬ít quite put my nose on ... Granny Smith apples? Woo - puckeringly sour at first, but I just let it sit in my mouth and coat the tongue and my mouth seems to acclimate. Somewhat metallic mid-palate, but that could just be the astringency of the oak. Definite cherry. The sourness is great without being overwhelming. Hard to pick out particular flavors, but this is solid. 

Smooth and balanced. The tartness lingers, but this one finishes dryly. Feels great.

Sip, puck, sip. I would say this is surprisingly drinkable, as I find myself wanting to go back to it for another sip 30s after my last one, and that¬ís saying something for this type of beer. But I suppose only time will tell as I make my way through the bottle. Excellent beer overall by NB.

Bottle:Pours a clear, blood orange with a subtle off white head that dissipates.cherries, toasty wood, raisin,vanilla, cinnamon on the nose.explosion of tartness! Maybe a bit of vinegar, vanilla notes, cherries,grapes, with a carbonated mouthfeel.long sour finish. Rodenbach esque!

UPDATED: DEC 29, 2010 2010 bottle. Poured deep red/brown with a creamy off-white head that faded fast. Nice aroma of brett, cherries, oak, and vanilla. Very sharp, acidic sour with hints of cherry, and oak. Didn¬ít expect it to be this sour considering it¬ís so fresh. Absolutely loved this beer! Can¬ít wait to have another.
*12/28/10 2006 bottle courtesy of Styles:
Poured ruby/brown with almost no head. Huge acetone aroma, Mouth puckering acidic/vinegar sour. Maybe a little too far gone, but still loved it.

From notes:

Corked and caged version, 2008 vintage. Pours a deep dark ruby/chestnut brown color with a two finger tan foam head. Decent retention, slowly fading into a lasting ring that leaves sporadic spots of lacing left behind.

Complex aroma with hints of earthy oak and vanilla as well as some tart funky sourness and dark fruit notes.

Tart and puckering medium body with hints of earthy wood/oak and sweet, tart funk. There is a very slight vanilla presence as well as some dark fruit flavor. Hints of cherry, raisin, date and fig. An excellent balance of sweet, tart, sour, funky and dry flavors. Slightly vinous with subtle grape flavor. Slightly acidic but easy to drink with an intense puckering sour feel that lingers throughout into a dry finish.

UPDATED: SEP 19, 2011 4oz pour. Someone opened a 2007 bottle recently so had to re-rate. This beer had something on the aroma that I have never experienced. It was almost like a spice mixed with a green wood note. Absolutely incredible.

In the nose I get oak, tart cherry and apple. Some serious twang alongside all the fruit. Flavors of grape, cherry, caramel and so dry in the finish, wow. This is delicious and enjoyable and luscious. Carbonation is spritzy and keeps everything in play.
Aroma of sour apple, tart cherry, vinegar with a little oak. Appearance is dark red\brown with tan head. Flavor matches the nose. Palate is bubbly. A nice sour, maybe a bit high rated for me.

Ruddy brown pour with a loose, off-white head.  The aroma is deep oak, red wine vinegar, molasses, and a little rum raisin bread.  The flavor is very oaky with a nice sweet balance of brown sugar, rum raisin bread, balsamic vinegar and a long, smooth lacto sourness.  Dry, medium body with moderate carbonation.

UPDATED: MAY 7, 2016 Draft with Linh at Neighborhood. Pours a very dark brown with reddish hue and nice light brown lacing and great carbonation. Aroma is sour cherries, apple, oak, and a touch of chocolate? Mouthfeel is delicate carbonated body with notes of sourness, tart cherries, earthy notes, wood, and other fruits. Great sour ale.

Bottle; Pour is a dark brown with amber highlights - the head is a very modest beige that quickly subsides and simply rims the glass. Aromas are very powerful sour notes; apple, cherry tart, vinegars. Flavors are quite powerful as well - you do get the oak, sour apple, cherry skins, a hint of earthiness, vinegar, but it is all just so tart for the style. Which I think does detract a bit from my enjoyment.
Poured brown smelled tart tasted sour with a nice dry aftertaste afterwards left a sweet tart taste in my mouth

Appearance: deep brown with ruddy reds and burnished mahogany highlights. Head is cappuccino which fades fast into a thin collar. Swirls with miniscule dotted lace the color of cappuccino foam.

Nose: cherries, chocolate, and grapes, all sour please. Hint of brown vinegar, hint. Gentle leather and funk in the background while mud, must, leather, and funk hang gently in the air. Plum skins.

Palate: smooth in the front, sour in the middle and back. Grape, plum, and cherry skins. Sour chocolates¬Öif there is such a thing. Gentle funk lingers and mingles but never detracts from the party, simply adding to it and enhancing. Refreshing. Soft once more at the very back of the swallow where leather and must linger. Gently coats lips in chocolate covered cherries, sour please. Blink once, kiss of fresh lemon zest, blink twice, gone. Sour fruit skins and leather last longest after each quaff in said order of chocolate sour cherries, plum skins, and grapes.

Final Thoughts: wow and wow. Supposedly these newer batches that are part of the Lips of Faith series from New Belgium haven¬ít been ¬ìup to snuff.¬î I can¬ít speak for past batches but my bottle was fantastic, a brew I¬íd love to have in my fridge on a very regular basis. Thanks sis!

On tap.  Near black in the glass with aroma of cherry, tart, sour, and slight vinegar notes.  Taste follows aroma with spur cherry up front, dry and tight tart, and lingering tart/sour with slight vinegar through the finish.  Nice dry quality throughout and not too sweet.  Really good beer.

Clear red with a minimal head... Brash aroma slightly sour fruity... Slightly lively, medium bodied very fruity, not as brash or sour as i had expected, but quite flavorful, nice dry finish... Top not oud bruin...

Pours reddish brown. Nose of sour cherries. Very sour cherries, and vinegar. Very tart apples and sour cherries on a medium-bodied palate with a cider vinegar finish. I get that this is a sour beer, but it¬ís just way too much. I¬ím not sure how I¬ím supposed to enjoy a beer that makes my face pucker every time I sip it. Frankly, I¬íd rather take shots of vinegar than drink any more of this beer. I imagine this is similar to what they gave Jesus on the cross.

Bomber poured into tumbler. 2009 bottle--or so I was told. I don¬ít see a vintage anywhere on the bottle. Pours a deep burgandy with a small dissipating head. Aroma is really funky--I smelled the pungency as soon as I opened it from two feet away. Also present is some brown sugar, barnyard, tart crisp fall apples. Taste is mouth-puckering sour--by far the most sour beer I¬íve had. Granted, I¬ím still fairly new to this style, but this is seriously sour. I don¬ít detect any sweet or bitter notes whatsoever. It¬ís all sour. Hints of cheese and earth (like mushrooms) on the back of the tongue. Delicious. Full, full in body; highly carbonated with an oily mouthfeel. Awesome beer.

Bottle from a trade with cbkschubert. 2006 vintage, bottle #1233. Shared at Maltzilla¬ís All American Weekend. Pours hazy reddish brown color with tan head. Sour cherry aroma with some wood and funk. Wow, this is extremely sour. Sour cherry and apple flavor with some oak and earthiness. Very acetic. Light to medium body with lively carbonation. A great brew. Huge thanks Craig.

UPDATED: APR 6, 2012 Tasted from a 22 oz bottle purchased in Fort Collins, Colorado. Dark red/violet/brown appearance with a creamy red head. Initially a red velvet aroma followed by a notable sweet, sourness with vinegar, black cherries, and plums. Initially very sour with some sweetness at the front of your mouth. Very full bodied, red fruity flavor in spite of the noted sourness. Kind of a dull sourness that weakens towards the back of the mouth. Very tasty and one of the most unique American Sour ales. Holy shit, this totally reminds me of Rodenbach.(4.0)
2009 bottle, courtesy of notalush. Fuck yeah, Brandon. Super amazing, funky, lactic, rich dark berry aroma. Super tangy, rich dark blackberry, raspberry, nice acetic, woody, tangy sour flavor. Way better than 2012 or 2011. Thanks Brandon!!! (4.5)

A: Pours a tawny brown color that is not entirely transparent; nice white head.

S: Lots of tarness of cherries and other fruits on top of a brown base. A little bit of funkiness going on as well.

T: The taste is quite sour, but not overpoweringly so. The biggest fruit component is of cherries, and there are oak hints complementing the sourness.

M: Prickly and sour; quite good. 

D: Unbelievably drinkable for the style with the perfect amount of sourness--I¬íll definitely be looking for quite a bit more of this one in the future.

UPDATE:

Corked and caged version labeled as 06-348, which I assume means that it was bottled in mid-December 2006. Thanks to bmanning for popping this open on 11.10.2010. 

This is incredibly tart with some modest cherry and quite a bit of acetic character, especially in the finish. A bit of very mild earthy funk in the nose. This is one of the most sour beers that I¬íve had in a long time.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 09-24-2009

Tasted at the Bistro Barrel aged fest 2010. I cant¬í believe I haven¬ít tried this beer up until now. It pours a reddish brown with a khaki head. The aroma is sour cherries with a sweet edge. The flavor is tart cherries with a mild hint of leather and some barnyard funk in the finish. Very juicy fruitiness in this one. Now I know what to pick up when I¬ím in the mood for a really good Flanders red.

This is an awesome beer and could very well be one of my favorite Flemish sours. Great yeast barnyard funk going on here. Leaves an effervesces after taste and just enough sour tartness to lead you into the next sip. Slight sour cherry or over ripe apple flavors. Great no correct that AWESOME beer!
This beer was awesome. Fruity aroma and flavor. Lots of apples. Ends with a great sour bite.

Tap @ Parkway. Cloudy red-brown, tan head, fine lace. Sour nose with a hint of cinnamon, medium-light body without much malt sweetness detectable under the marked sourness. Green apples in the middle and finish - where it gets more complex and the oak seeps in. Fine carbonation, nice. Not my favorite sour, but very good.

UPDATED: JAN 21, 2012 ***re-rate - its good!8888On tap at Denver international. Murky red brown goodness, thin white cap. Smells sour! Dark cherries, berries, vinegar, lots of oak, hints of apple - very cool. This is so f¬íing sour it¬ís amazing! Big oak, sour as shit cherries, vinegar, almost like a wine that has gone bad. Earthy and some funk that haunts every sip. Big carbonation. The sourness is hurting.

bottle.  Pours opaque dark ruby color with small brown bubbly head.  Aroma: black cherry, raspberry, blackberry, rich brown ale malt, slight vinegar.  Smells very good.  Flavor is mouth puckering sour raspberry, blackberry, sour cherry.  There are some notes of vinegar which personally I do not like - it is not dominating but present enough to detract from the beer.  Pretty good, but doesn¬ít stand up to the russian river sours I¬íve had.  Those, although very sour, do not have this vinegar aspect.

Sampled from the 22oz bottle. The beer is sour. Really sour - but it is incredibly wonderful. Lip puckering good. Certainly not a traditional beer, and I don¬ít think I could drink this alone, but as a group, together with others, it¬ís good.

Aroma:  Balsamic vinegar, cherry, sour, yet rich.
Appearance:  ruby/brown, light beige head
Taste:  Intense, fruity sourness upfront, followed by musk, sweetness and oak notes, finishing dry.  The bottle I opened was a bit too cold, once it warmed up the tartness was well balanced by the sweet, earthy flavors.  
Palate:  Medium body, lively carbonation, finish doesn¬ít linger and is dry
Overall:  My first experience with a sour, was a bit intimidated by the style, but ended up enjoying this very much.

2009.  Dark maroon, transparent.  Little head.  Aroma is raspberry seeds, sour cherries, berry jam - wonderful fruit flavors abound - dry oak and subtle earthiness.  Reminiscent of Rodenbach Grand Cru.  The taste is very sour and dry.  Great pucker.  Wonderful sour.
Light fruity aroma.  Stickey red body.  Flavor of cherries and sour.  Not my type...
From a bottle poured a brown color with a small amount of head.  Nice tart flavor with a lingering aftertaste.

500ml bottle.  Big balsamic vinegar aroma.  One of the most intense Krieks out there.  Oily head, deep cherry red color.  Hardcore cherry sourness.  Lemony brett.  Intense.  Deep oaky tones as well.  Awesome beer.

On tap at Falling Rock Tap House 2009. Pours a hazy brown with an off-white head and hints of lacings. Some sourness with a light bitterness. Tart with aromas of berries, cask wood and hints of glue. Full bodied. Lively carbonation.
Bottle from a generous trader. Pours cherry brown. Nose and taste of tart sour apples and wet wood. A bit acidic. Overall, pretty good.

Bomber, fairly dark cherry mahogany w little ow head that fell away to almost nothing rather quickly. Aroma is wood, sour, fruit, herbal spice, w hints of Jagermeister and bitters herbs.
Flavor is very clean, tart, quite vividly sour/acidic, tannic, woody, aged fruit, dried cherries.
The sour/acidic hits first, with a rich, creamy, spicy, woody middle w a tart sour finish. Not sweet, but creamy, silky to balance the tart.
Classy offering.

Pours plain brown. Small off white head does not last.  Good malty brown ale aroma with a hint of tart. Super tart flavor covers up all the taste of the beer. I think they went a little too far with the stacybopillus. Lol. Haha. Somewhat dry. Might as well be sweet tart beer.

Well, upon looking up New Belgium beers it appears my rating got nuked somehow.  So I¬íll be going from memory on this.  Poured out a dark ruby red with fluffy off-white head. ARoma of sour fruit, yeast, light toasted malt and some cherry.  Taste much the same with it essentially mimicking Rodenbach.  Solid.

Poured from a bomber, pours a dark ruby brown with a thin head, aroma has ton of funk mixed in with sour cherries and plum, the taste is very tart and has a great flavor of cherries with plum and oak, this is a wonderful beer!

This was my first taste of a sour ale and I really enjoyed it. Poured from a bomber into a glass it formed a tan head that dissolved quickly, but left a thin layer of foam behind.  Aroma was citrus, fruity and almost like freshly cut lemons.  Flavor was quite sour- like unsweetened lemons, but very fruity with hints of cherry.  It had a surprisingly smooth mouth feel and was very refreshing. Would drink this a lot more if it wasn¬ít so expensive.

This is a unique and special beer... a sour ale broadly available (well except in new England) and delicious in a bottle. All the sours ranked higher you can¬ít really get anywhere except the breweries. Also I like how it¬ís not bottle conditioned.  Great flavors of chocolate and funky cherry. New Belgium really makes a good argument for best large micro brewery
Tried at the brewery twic on a tour.  What an amazing sour.  Great tartness and just the right cherry notes.  I love this beer.

Poured in tulip from bottle.

Appearance - Dark ruby/brown in color, with little head or lacing. Lovely natural carbonation bubbles.

Aroma - Earthy, tart cherries and plums, just a hint of smoke

Taste - Wonderful. Tart cherries, plums, oak, bretty barnyard, sour, vanilla...just a complex array of flavors. Dry finish to cut through the sourness making it a very refreshing beer.

Palate - solid prickly carbonation. mouthfeel is very appropriate for this beer. Not too thin to be watery but not too thick to take away from the refreshment

Overall - wouldn¬ít want to session but drinking a pint or 2 is very enjoyable.  Really like this beer.

Location: Bottle at Max and Andy¬ís Fantasy Tasting, 5/1/10


Aroma: The nose has wood, sour cherries, roasted malts, and a other berry notes

Appearance: It pours a hazy dark reddish-brown color with a beige head atop it

Flavor: The taste is somewhat sour and woody with a flavor and a nice tartness

Palate: It has a solid mouthfeel, a medium body, and a long and somewhat acidic finish

Overall Impression: 
Overall, I thought this beer was very solid, but it didn¬ít blow me away.  Just a very solid sour beer.  There is not much more for me to add beyond that...

UPDATED: SEP 22, 2010 1 Pint, 6oz bottle. Poured a dark brown/ruby with some orange around edges; no head. Aroma: sour grapes & apples, tart berries, wood. Taste: sour & tart grapes & berries, wood, sour apple notes, mildly acidic. Syrupy but dry mouthfeel. Medium body. Finish: clean, sour, tart, mild acidic burn. Overall a nice Sour Ale.

sour fruity aroma with hints of blk cherry, though i think that the sour scent is tricking me into the black cherry smell. Pours very dark reddish/brown with a small head that does not keep. very sour, acidic taste with many fruity flavors. Tastes more like a sour green apple than cherries. finishes with vinegar. really gets over the tongue well. Overall a good beer, looking forward to trying more sours!
22oz bottle pours a deep, ruby brown with zero head.  Tart nose, smoky, malty, brown sugar.  Smells sweet and tart.  Flavor of cherries, berries, hay, grassy, acetic.  Full bodied, tart finish.

750 ml bottle courtesy of Summer Secret Santa ¬í10. Pours a dark reddish brown with a good sized beige head. Funky, sour aroma that reminded me of cherries and Granny Smith apples with a little vinegar thrown in too. Tart, sour palate that really makes you pucker with a bitter finish. Wonderful funky sour cherry flavor with honey notes and a taste of the oak barrels it was aged in. Great stuff. My 800th rating too.

22oz bottle, thanks to erice for bringing this one back from CO.  Pours a cloudy deep reddish brown.  Aroma has tart cherries, oak, and lots of acetic acid.  Taste is quite sour, reminds me a lot of supplication, but a little less well balanced.  Lots of acidity, oak, and tart fruit, with medium sweetness and a bit of apples... finish tastes like dry cider.

UPDATED: AUG 30, 2012 Falling Rock 10th Anniversary bottle shared by cpferris.  Thanks Chad.  Pours a murky brown with a small white head that settles to a bunch a bubbles at the edge of the glass and leaves some light lacing.  The aroma is oak, cherry, some light brown sugar and caramel as well as a bit of vinegar.  The taste has a light initial sweetness as well as a decent tartness.  There is oak, cherry, and a bit of brown sugar.  The finish has a decent amount of acetic acid and lots of oak.  Medium bodied.  Low-medium carbonation.
Aroma has notes of oak with hints of vanilla. Pours a clear burgundy red with slight white head. Sweet flavor with cherries and citrus. Average carbonation.

Thanks for sharing, bro!  Pours a reddish-brown color with a medium off-white bubbly head.  Aroma is largely like Rodenbach - tart apple and cherry notes, and light oak.  Taste is much the same but very dry and extremely acidic finish, almost too acidic.  Very good but not different enough than Rodenbach to stand on its own, and too acidic.

This is another shining example  of  why I love trying all different types of beers. A brown ale that is sour, the idea sort of blows my mind, but works. It had a super taste, one that was mostly bitter and made the cheeks pucker. It also had a super funky aroma to it as well, citrus and ginger is  what I got. Big thanks to my FLAbeer crew for sharing this one.

I have had many vintage of this beer.  All are good, although I miss the older vintages that are caged and corked.  A great all around brown sour that is easily to find.  I will drink more of these in the near future.

Aroma of sour warheads and balsamic vinegar. Color is deep red/brown, headless. Flavor is slightly sweet, slightly, bitter, and pretty malty- this is incredibly balanced. Bottle form a trade with Lithy, thanks!

Appearance is very dark, but translucent.  Amber color when held to the light.  Aroma is a faint sour candy, taste is like melted sour patch kids.  Medium palate, simple, not very complex, but refreshing.
Reddish brown in color... Aroma is sour, reminiscent of a gueze... Flavor is oak, sour malts, cherries... Finish is slightly sour, leaves you wanting more... Delicious beer

I¬íve had this beer so many times, so many vintages.  Every time I have it I remember how much I LOVE THIS BEER. Plum skins, plums, cherries, with a shade of oak. Sour in the front of the mouth. Fresh and crisp. Seriously, don¬ít drink this beer. Buy it and send it to me instead.
Bomber shared with Jeff.  Clearish maroon, beige edge head.  Aroma of grapefruit and brown sugar, taste is nicely sour throughout, no dryness, minimal funk.  Decent balance, wood, spice.  Very nice.

Thanks to Jeremy and Kevin for sharing the 05, 08, and 2010 Vintages.  Interesting results...score based on 08.

¬í05
A-pours a clear burgundy red color with a slightly off white colored head.

S-the nose has notes of oak with hints of vanilla underneath.  lots of acidity and acetic acid, tart cherries, wow this burns the nostrils not in a good way.  the vinegar and acidity in this beer is huge.

T-the flavor isn¬ít bad but I can¬ít finish this beer.  more sweetness than the nose, sweet red cherries, light oak presence, tons of acidity and vinegar.  this heats the entire body and makes me sweat all over.  rest goes in the drain...

M-smooth feel to it, somewhat creamy in the mouth with a medium body.  tons of carbonation, prickly and rough to swallow, very dry and still can¬ít get over the heat.

D-the flavor isn¬ít offensive but this is the most acidic beer I have ever had, it burns my body and I literally sweat every sip I took.  By far the most acidic and most acetic beer of the group.

¬í08
A-very dark burgundy, almost brown and much more dark than the 05.  the edges are red with a slightly off white colored head.

S-the nose is seemingly well balanced, tart ripe cherries, moderate oak presence, hints of leather, acidity takes over with more sour cherries.

T-well balanced acidity on this, nice cherry tartness up front with a good fruity sweetness to it.  hints of leather, the acidity is strong in the back with just a touch of vinegar.

M-smoother and softer especially in the finish with a medium body and crisp dry finish.

D-considerably better than the 05 and best of the three.  this has a decent balance of acidity to flavor with a nice ripe tart cherry presence.  not overly complex but still a decent beer.

¬í10
A-this pours the darkest of the three, chestnut brown in color with an off white head.

S-the malt presence from the base beer is present in this, sweet cherries with a very light tartness to it.  there is some acetic acid in the back but not strong.

T-follows the nose, base beer still present, malt body, good amount of sweet cherries and very light tartness.  least complex of the group but still drinkable.

M-this is the least acidic beer of the group and probably the softest palate of the bunch.  slightly dry finish, not as dry as the 08, medium bodied and a little syrupy.

D-this seems to be the easiest drink of the bunch, least complex and least amount of acidity.  the sweetness is present and the sour is quite low.  the oak presence is very light in this one.

Overall thoughts-the 05 was brutal, flavors weren¬ít off but the acidity ramped up so much no one could drink it, the 10 was the easiest drink but also the least "sour" of the group and really lacked the sourness or acidity you would have liked to see.  the 08 was the best balanced, base beer pretty much gone but enough oak presence and acidity to create a decent brew.

Intense complex aroma similar to a red wine, dark fruit, sour apple.  Dark red ale, minimal head with no lacing.  Medium bodied, thin texture with a very sour yet dry finish.  Tongue is blasted with sour fruityness that is almost overwhelming.  I can appreciate the style and see how some people can enjoy it, but man, I just can¬ít seem to get it.  Very likely the last sour ale I purchase.

22 oz bottle. 08.10.10. 2010 Vintage.
Pours deep reddish brown with an opaque orange hue. There is a slight off white head that quickly dissipated into itself. The nose is lactic acid, French oak, cherries, vanilla, dried apple, vinegar, and some wild yeast. The taste is tart cherries and apples at first that transition into a dry white grape like middle that finishes with a creamy oak and vanilla palate. The cherry/apple/grape taste truly lingers throughout the drink. I really enjoyed the oak flavor and the amount of dry and bitter wood. The legs are sticky and the mouthfeel is very creamy. What a great sour ale. I thought the Erics Sour Peach was great but this is very very good. The taste is similar to Consecration without the super vinegary flavor. I must vintage a bottle or two.

Bomber.  Nice amber brown pour.  Off white medium head.  WONDERFUL citrus/sour aroma.  Heavy sour taste, but without the stereotypical candy sweetness.  Feel is good, but it gets a bit thick in the mouth after a couple of pints.

2007 750ml bottle shared by Timbo, thanks man 
Appearance: Poured clear copper/amber with a nice off-white head, no lacing 
Aroma: Tart fruits, oak and yeast 
Taste: Tart cherries, woody and malts 
Very nice, not overly sour.

1300th rating.  22 oz. bottles from Randall¬ís- 2009 and 2010 vintages tried side-by-side as part of a Lips of Faith tasting I hosted.  Both pour a hazy reddish-brown color with a small beige head with decent retention.  Aroma of sour, dark fruits (cherries mostly, with apples and plums), oak, grape skins, and a little vanilla.  Flavor of the same dark fruits, with cherries leading and grape skins coming in later, oak, vanilla, earth, and wild yeast.  The 2009 wound up being a lot more sour and tart, while the fruit was much mellower in the 2010, opening up the oak notes more, as well.  Interesting how this one developed in a year.  Medium-bodied, with a sour, fruity mouthfeel and average carbonation.  Fruity, oaky, and sour.  Just an excellent sour ale, and I can¬ít wait to revisit any vintage of this one.

UPDATED: APR 14, 2011 Bottle from 08 thanks to dmac. Pours a dark reddish color with a little head to it. Smells like wet wood and a slight sour smell in there as well. Has a pretty big sour taste with cherries and some wood in the flavor as well. Pretty damn tasty

750 ml cork and caged bottle from 03/2008. Poured a red/brown murky body with a foamy off white head. Aroma is sour with notes of vinegar, wet wood, funk. The flavor is just soooo tart and sour. The aroma really did not give any sort of inclination on just how sour the flavor was. I would have to say this was almost on level with consecration, really good stuff.

750ml bottle no. 1261 bottled in January ¬í09.  ours a reddish, clear body with a moderate, off-white head that dissipates into a nice ring.  Sweaty, sour aroma with some dark fruit undertones.  Super, lip-puckering sour, but pleasantly so.  Apple, pear and some sour cherry come through.  Light, crisp body with moderate carbonation.  Sour, lingering finish.  Like a sour candy, but dry.  Excellent!

Bottle.  Pours dark amber, small 1/4inch head.  Aroma:  nutty, sour. raisins. Taste: intense sour, cherries, hint of orange, almost on the warhead level of sourness. finishes sour and smooth. medium bodied.  Overall the best New Belgium beer ive had to date.

UPDATED: JUN 9, 2012 A: Dark reddish brown body. Moderate khaki cap with fairly good retention. Lots of rising bubbles. Slight lacing and a tight ring with some skim towards the center of the glass.

S: From the second the bottle was opened you could smell the rich and sour dark fruits. Various berries and dark cherries dominate. Sour from a distance and hints at what is to come.

T: The dark fruits are lively and sour. Pucker inducing yet refined enough to be able to explore the various berry flavorings. Slight oak and vanilla seeps in toward the finish.

M: Moderate bodied. Sour throughout. Perhaps a little more carbonated than ideal. Lingering puckering feeling.

O: A very nice brew. In many ways reminiscent of RR consecration.

Bottle, pours a clear, red-amber body with light brown head.  Tart aroma of sour apple and cherry, acetic acid, and light malts/nuts.  Flavor is similar with a sweet malt and maybe a cocoa/caramel tone near the finish.  Medium-bodied with a smooth mouthfeel.  Tart sour cherry finish.

Draft, SIB.  Dark orangeish brown with a thin white head.  Vinegar and lemon sour aroma on it with hints of berryish fruit.  This beer tastes tart throughout upon sipping, layering vinegar, lemon, and sour cherry with an earthy finish.  Remarkably complex for how sharply tart it is.  I also found this served as a great refresher and palate clearer in a festival situation.

sour fruity aroma with hints of blk cherry, though i think that the sour scent is tricking me into the black cherry smell.  Pours very dark reddish/brown with a small head that does not keep.  very sour, acidic taste with many fruity flavors.  Tastes more like a sour green apple than cherries.  finishes with vinegar.  really gets over the tongue well.  Overall a good beer though i will not be drinking on a regular basis.

UPDATED: SEP 27, 2013 650mL bottle, pours a clear dark amber with a small beige head. Aroma brings out sour apples, some dark malted vinegar, and dark fruits. Flavour brings out sour dark fruits, some sour apple, malted vinegar, and some medium acidity. Quite acidic and moderately vinegar. Very well-balanced and certainly one of the better ones in the style.

My second sour ale.  Quite a dirty pour, murky brown with no head although showed good carbonation.  Aroma was acidic, musty, sour and nuts.  Taste followed suit.  Lots of vinegar in the finish although I really enjoyed this one.  Quite an experience.

UPDATED: NOV 30, 2011 Bottle, 2005 Vintage, drank in June 2010. One of the best sours I¬íve ever had. Pours ruby brown with a medium - but strong - beige head. Acidic, tart nose with fruity notes, wood, and light funk. Flavor is quite sweet, but the lip-puckering sourness quickly overtakes the sweetness. More wood, moderate barnyard, tons of citrus sour. Light to medium in body with soft carbonation. Warms and burns. Exceptional.

Update: Had some 2009 at The Funky 7. Gave it a 4.4 again.

22 oz bottle.  Pours deep red-tinged brown with a small off-white head.  Aroma is heavily acidic, vinegary, with lots of fruit flavors: raspberry, cherry, red grape, blackberry.  Flavor is also heavy on the citric sourness, dry, with some cherry, red apple, raspberry, perhaps a bit of caramel, but primarily this is outright sour.  This is a good one alright.

22oz bomber pours a very light brown head that dissipates quickly with no lacing to speak of.  The aroma is very sour, with some small amount of a barely sweet malt coming through.  The flavor is tart from top to bottom.  It improves, becoming more complex -- and more sour -- as it warms up, though it¬ís hard to let it do that since I can¬ít stop sipping it.

If I could drink only this beer for the rest of my life, I think I would be okay with that.  I¬íve had better sours, but this is one of my absolute favorites.

One of those beers which is much greater than the sum of it¬ís parts. It doesn¬ít really look that nice - murky reddish brown with a very quickly dissipating head. It smells OK, but Rodenbach Grand Cru (benchmark for me for this style) smells better. The flavour though is where everything pulls together, and for me, the depths of subtlety here out-do the "master" which is Rodenbach Grand Cru. This is art in a glass.

I consider myself to be a pretty experienced beer taster. So when I plopped down $12 last weekend on a bottle of this I felt fairly confident I was buying a "sure" thing. Wow, was I wrong. If you like vinegar with a hint of soy sauce then this is your beer. Otherwise, this beer sucks.

Whiskey colored pour from bottle.  Love the nose, featuring sour fruits, brown sugar and alcohol.  Taste is very sour, like biting into a lemon that was marinated in vinegar.  Dry, sour finish.  For some reason I have a hard time rating sour beers, as I find them to be very complex.  Overall, decent but not great.

750 ml bottle; dark orange with slight haze and thin white head; killer nose with tons of sour apples, oak sweetness, apricots; super dry with a sourness level that¬ís pretty much at my threshold; woody, sweet with fluffy sour lemons, pears and apples; prickly mouthfeel and sharp sourness; oak, vanilla and fruit; damn good, but what a sour bitch! 

Original Rating 10/31/08 (Score - 4.1): 750 ml bottle; big thanks to bvc for cracking this one out; pours dark amber and cloudy with spotty white head; wow, a sour bug for sure; some mild cherry and fruit mixed in the aromas, but the sourness almost knocks you off you feet; flavors of sour apples and pears; wow, quite a sour; my palate was shaky at this point of the night, so a revisit will be in order to feel the subtleties

Insanely sour and with a whiff of vinegar (in a good way) on top of dark malt, yeast and earthy neutral barrel in the nose. This beer is sour from start to finish!!! It is super dry and if it weren¬ít so dry it would be a dead ringer for Rodenbach.  Wow.  It is almost too intense, but share a bottle with a few people and they will either love it or hate it. This is a classic!

bottle(thanks to the kind soul that sent this, I¬íve forgotten and apologize), pours dark reddish brown with a thin to medium tan head.  Aroma is strong, lots of red wine, thin vinegar, and granny smith skins.  So appealing to look and smell.  Flavor is tart tart tart.  This packs a punch.  Pucker up to sour apple juice, acidic lemon zest, some oak and thin vanilla creeping in, but the sourness dominates.  This stuff will open your eyes!

On tap at DDC (not kidding).

Appearance : Deep red, no head.

Aroma : Sour and tart with a cherry-ish hint

Taste : Sour and tart, woody with cherry-ish notes.

Overall : Very fruity and sour. I took a good 45 minutes to drink my glass but I had such a great time. It was delightful until the last sip. Very nice beer and I¬ím pretty happy to I had the chance to try this on tap at Dieu Du Ciel !

¬í07 cork&cage. Pours hazy brown/amber with no head. carbonation is faint but enough to keep the palate light. Aroma of oak, tart earth, dark fruits. Drinks with a sweet and tart with fruits and oak, sour cherries, plum, faint apple. finishes tart but smooth with lasting fruit and earth end.

Multiple samples from different vintages. Pours a dark reddish brown color with a good sized off white head of pillowy foam that leaves sticky spots of lace around the glass. The aroma is very tart showing notes of sour cherries and apples mostly followed by balsamic vinegar, French oak, and some lactic cream. The yeast is very dry and earthy. The flavor is just as sour as the nose elts on with the sour cherries and apples taking center stage but is smoother out by the lactic cream and caramel malt. The oaky vanilla ties everything together nicely along with adding depth. Medium bodied with champagne like carbonation, but still maintains an easy drinking quality. This is a great sour beer, and just an awesome beer all around.

UPDATED: FEB 18, 2011 I have really been in the mood for a sour beer lately and this surely hit the mark!
La Folie wood aged beer in French Oak barrels.
Pours a deep ruby red/brown with a slight tan head.
Smells of sour apples with the tinge of tartness
The taste is...you guessed it...all sour. Apples, fruit, acidic, and earthy. 
Light in the mouth.
Very drinkable...if you are into sours. This one is sour front and center. 
A very good beer.
Have an older version that I will rate as soon as I decide to crack it open!
Re-Rate: After delving into the world of sours, I have to take this one down a bit as it is not as good as others I have sampled. Had on draft last night and although still a solid and affordable sour, it just doesn¬ít have the bite some others have.
Re-Re-Rate: Finally sampled a C&C bottle and WOW does it blow the new stuff out of the water!
Bottle at Max and Andy¬ís Fantasy Tasting. - Sour ales are starting to grow on me. Very fresh tart, like newly picked fruits. Bit of earthy, funky backdrop. Nice.

This beer came highly regarded by a friend and it did not take very long to find out why. Afterwards, when he told me it was brewed by New Belgium, I was a bit shocked. This is all about taste. The sour notes are so brilliant, it¬ís truly unlike any other beer I¬íve consumed. Awesome.

5/22/10.  Bomber into a snifter.  The pour is dark red/brown with a nice khaki head.  The aroma is awesome sour cherries mixed with vinegar (specifically apple cider vinegar) and a nice amount of funk.  The flavor is nice sour cherry (really sour!) with obvious oak and hitns of malt, meat, soy, vinegar, and acid, but all in a good way.  Lovin¬í it!

08/24/09 sampling:
22oz bomber purchased at liquidsolutions....

Appearance: 4.0 Lovely dark brown with red corners. 1 finger beige crown that rapidly dissipates and leaves a bit of lace.

Smell: 4.5 Sweet and sour goodness! So far this smells like a classic Flanders Red and I¬ím really excited to taste it! Vinegar notes, sour cherry notes, dark malts, etc. Complex for the style.

Taste: 4.5 Lots going on but it all adds up to sweet tart like goodness. Lots of sour cherry and almost a lemon like puckering flavor throughout. Gets better as it warms a bit. Good amount of complexity.

Mouthfeel: 3.5 A touch too thin IMHO.

Drinkability: 4.0 Flanders Red¬ís aren¬ít the most approachable to begin with but this brew remains fairly drinkable despite it being complex.

The cherries add to the acidity but this one is all about dryness and tartness. This is good but I¬ím still hoping my 2008 750ml bottle drinks better than this 2009 bomber.

2008 750ml Bottle consumed on 2/20/10

Appearance: 4.0 Lovely dark brown with red corners. 1 finger beige crown that rapidly dissipates and leaves a bit of lace.

Smell: 4.5 A touch drier than the 2009 bomber with more tartness and further pronounced brett. Sour cherry notes are still present but not as much malt as the 2009 bomber. Hints of toasted barrel and leather.

Taste: 4.5 Again the lemony brett notes and dryness are more pronounced than the 2009 bobmer. Lots of sour cherry still and a hint of barrel. Moderate pucker and the finish is fairly short.

Mouthfeel: 4.0 Is definitely superior to the 2009 sampling. A bit more heft to it with ample carbonation.

Drinkability: 4.0 Goes down fairly smooth but has a good amount of sharpness.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 08-24-2009

750mL bottle, dated 3/08, poured into a tulip.

Pours a dark cherry-wood brown that shows through a deep hazy copper when held up to light.  There is a small creamy beige head that recedes to a thin soapy cap that leaves a bit of lacing.

The aroma is tart cherries and green apples with some brown sugar sweetness thrown in.  There is also a bit of lactic sourness and brett in addition to the oak spiciness.

The aroma is even more sour, especially up front with lots of cherries and vinegar tartness with the sweetness of the brown sugar taking a back seat to the tartness and funk which comes out in the finish along with the French oak.

The mouthfeel is medium bodied and effervescent with a ton of oak and sugar-covered tart cherries in the finish.

I¬íve had this a few times and it¬ís a fantastic beer.  I¬ím not sure if it¬ís the best flanders red but it¬ís a great version of the style.

Geez...I surrender!  What a beer.  I though I was a sophisticated beer drinker until I tasted this.  All I taste is astringent vinegar aged in barrel.  I am presently licking my shoe to get rid of this amazing, well-aged taste...

Had a bottle in central park (illegal) on a beautiful NY saturday.  Had to drink straight from bottle unfortuantly but i know that it would have poured reddish as when i wiped my mouth, my sleeve was stained maroon.  tastes of sour apples and cherries and has a nice backbone, very refreshing; lip smacking puckery goodness.

Dark red, fizzy vanishing head. Pretty mellow aroma in this one, so the flavor will surprise you. Very rich and tart with a fruity balsamic/vinegar backbone. Probably had more heft/body than any sour I¬íve had to date. Good to know they¬íre still turning some stuff like this out.

UPDATED: MAR 5, 2017 Having had a two-year-old Rodenbach the night before, I felt I was ready for this bottle, schlepped graciously (and on request!) from the wide-open spaces by kuphish.  From Jan 09 - bottle 1261.  Deep ruby red but still lets light through, little head.  Sweet dark cherry nose, very sour dark cherry, light lactic and acetic a bit stronger.  Balsamic is (finally!) not overdone in a sour.  Taste is puckeringly, awesomely sour, very strong, got great reactions from all assembled.  Low but consistent carbonation, lightly metallic but not off-putting, has some firm Apfelschorle tones.  Even better when it¬ís scraping a coating of cheese or chocolate from the tongue.  Superlative - love it love it love it! [2010.05.10: 4.5]2016 bottle here in early 2017.  Where¬ís the sourness?  Has my palate become so inured?  Love the wood character but there¬ís so much less of everything else here.  [2017.03.05: 3.5]
Pours a brownish red color with minimal brown head. Smells like malt and dirty. Biting sourness, with both lactic and acetic. Tastes like sour dirt to me.

On tap at a brewpub in Colorado.  Folie is a wonderfully fruity sour ale that, to me, tasted of cranberry and sour apple.   Under the fruit, you could still tell you were drinking a beer -- which is a good thing considering the acidity and fruit.  Highly carbonated with a tall, thin head.    

My advice: look for 8oz pours or share with someone...a pint was borderline for me with all the acidity.
Really nice sour, similar to Haandbaak.  Scent of cherry and vanilla.  It¬ís a bit of a lip smacker.  Beautiful brown color.

Rich maroon with filmy cream head. Powerful sour tart aroma. Pungent and sharp. Body is actually rather well rounded. Good malt backbone off which a strongly layered sour tartness pushes off of like to ended magnets repelling each other. Apple cider vinegar and balsamic notes.  Intensely flavorful, but remains within the realm of drinkability even for the non-sour aficionado like myself.  Still.... I personally only partake as a novelty.

oured into a snifter. It pours a hazy medium red color with one finger of head. There is minimal lacing. The smell is slightly tart, with some fruit and oak just melding together. The aromas fit together like a puzzle. The taste is also slightly tart and sour, with some sweet cherries punching toward the front. Also has a good oak aftertaste as it warms. The mouthfeel is nice and thick, but smooth as well. The drinkability is great for the style.

A- Body is a hazy murky brown color. Pours with an approximately 2 finger foamy off-white head that subsides completely pretty quickly. No lacing is left behind in the glass.

S- Upon popping the bottle a big acidic tartness comes through first and is then followed by a subtle wood character and a hint of fruit.

T- The flavor is much like the smell. It starts off with a big acidic tartness which puckers the lips without going over the top. In the background are much more subtle characters of cherry,wood, and must as well as a hint of vinegar. The acidic sourness fades a bit for the finish and allows these other characters to emerge a little bit.

P- Well carbonated and a light-to-medium weight body.

O- This is a very good, well constructed beer. Something that I would like to have again-if I were sharing with someone. A nice slow-sipper and towards the end the acidity was starting to get to me. My 1st from New Belgium and I am looking forward to others.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 03-02-2009 18:35:10

UPDATED: MAY 4, 2010 Pours a dark ruby amber with a small, fizzy, tan head that disappears in a matter of seconds. The aroma is very woody, with sour apple, cherries, candied sugar, caramel, and cranberries. The sour apples come through first on the flavor, giving way to incredibly tart acid, with the afore mentioned fruits, and a touch of dry wood. Very powerful stuff. I personally am not a huge fan of sours, and this is a little hard to drink.
On tap.  Pours a deep amber with small white head.  Aroma of wood and sour cherries.  Tartness grabs the tongue.  Tastes of cherry and wood.  Wish i could have more of this.

aroma is dark sour cherry, burnt wood, caramel--a very deep aroma that is just a great sour-sweet mix.
dark brown, thin beige foamy head.
flavor is also a nice mix of dark fruit, malt vinegar, and a dry woodiness.
slightly on the thin side, which is works nicely. effervescent and comes with a super long sour malt-y finish.
Draft in Seattle. Really great. Dark brown pour and minimal lacing grad. Robust brown with perfect full sour. Tart cherry and bright raspberry. Rad.

22oz into snifter. I generally dont like New Belgium beers but this one surprised me. Excellent beer from NB and probably the best of the Lips of Faith series. Pours dark  brown, smells of brett, tastes of brett and sourness. Great sour brown ale.

sampled an old vintage at a homebrew event- deliciously sour, but not so much as to deter drinkability- a real treat, cherry, some dark malt, and oaky vanilla flavors come through- hope to secure a newer vintage and a more ample serving size.

Another great beer- The aroma is complex with a mix of anisette and sour cherries, with hints of a musty, root-cellar yeastiness.  Pours a deep brown red-brown with a good head (the head is short lived). Tastes of rich malt and sour oak with light tannins and floral esters. This beer is sour! I finally got hold of Rodenbach, only to find that it was closer to Duchesse De Borgogne than this beer. Full-bodied and creamy with a long, sour (but not bitter) finish. This beer is phenomenally rich and sour, and it testament to the brewer¬ís skill that it is able to avoid both any hints bitterness or sweetness. I have had this beer by itself and with a 2 1/2" thick bacon-wrapped filet. It was a wonder either way. I have brought bottles of this as gifts to multiple events and it blows people away every time.

Pours a clear, dark reddish-brown with no head to speak of.  Aroma of cranberry juice.  Extremely, extremely sour with strong cranberry flavor.  Quite sweet, a little sticky, high carbonation.  Finish has barnyard funk.  Mouth puckering.

For someone without much sour ale experience, this beer seems an excellent benchmark for comparing future sours to. The aroma is not overpowering, but some hints of sour apple cider, musk, and lots of tart candy come through. Pours a pretty dark brown w/ reddish hues and a darker beige head. Dry, buoyant, and quite acidic; taste is quite similar to the aroma, but more sour apple cider than tart candies, and the muskiness comes through as more "basement" quality than anything else. The first sip was a surprise, the second pitched the sale, and by the third, I was sold. Reminded me a lot of kombucha teas, actually. There¬ís an elegance to the earthiness of this beer -- quite nice.

Pours a medium brown color with a thinnish off-white head. Aroma is sour cherries, apple, oakiness, vinegar and some yeast. This is definitely a sour ale. Flavor of apples and some other sour fruits, vinegar, mustiness. Sour. Dry and refreshing.

first pour the strong smell of apples rush from bottle and some over ripe cherrys. leaaving a small beige head dark redish brown in color taste mirrors smell almost i think smell is lot better tho. certainly sour no lacing to be seen enjoyable

I decided to spend my St. Patrick¬ís day drinking sours.  Had this one side by side with a Rodenbach out of sheer curiousity.  You can definately smell their influential hand of yeasty goodness.  Has the fantastic tart apple, sour pomegranate, oak, musty tea thing going on, but then there is more.  Some underlying peach, strawberry, and leather.  Now for the taste.  One thing we American¬ís are good at doing, is going aggressive, and it¬ís apparent after the first sip. Everything i expected.  Instead of the softer doughy backbone of the entry level Rodenbach, it¬ís replaced by a big caramel prosthetic.  Acid is much higher.  More sweet, more sour, but still pretty balanced. If Rodenbach is "stopping to smell the flowers", then La Folie is like falling face first into a floral truck.  I think I have a problem, i¬ím falling in lust with sours!

Bottle - Mahogany pour with a small frothy khaki head. Light sour funk -- pretty accessible with oaky and balsamic vinegar notes. Nice and smooth, and not over the top. Lots of balsamic vinegar, a touch of oak--not mouth-puckering. Smooth and oily in the mouth. Real easy-to-drink and not too crazy for sour noobs.

On tap at Hamilton¬ís Tavern (San Diego, CA): Pours opaque brown and topped with a fizzy white head which reduces to rather nice lacing around my snifter. Nose of oak wood, tart dark cherries, and under ripened apples and peach. Flavors are similar, with added fructose and funk that lie against an underlying strawberry base.  Prickly carbonation. Dry, tart and super oaky. Drinkability: Distinctive. Stands among other top-tiered sours. Pairing: Aged cheese. Rebuy: Yess. #340 on 13032010, DG.

This poured a murky brown color with an average beige head. Aroma was very tart citrus, some oak notes, and some vineous character too. Flavor was astoundingly sour, very close to isabell, but not quite. Lots of citric acid, some earthy and woody notes, and some dark fruits as well. Overall a very nice sour.

Simply AMAZING!!!  I can¬ít imagine a better sour. Rodenbach doesn¬ít even come close. It¬ís like a fine wine in it¬ís complexity. If your a sour freak like me? Go for it. If you think you enjoy sours now and then. Stay away!

The aroma has hints of citrus and various fruits. Pours reddish brown with little head. Very sour taste. Almost overwhelming at first. Flavor grows on you very quickly. Has a medium body which leaves a bitter taste in your mouth. Overall, La Folie has a unique flavor which is not for everyone. It is one of the better sour ales I have tasted.

draft at flying saucer KC. pours a reddish brown with a sizable off white head. aroma is tart with sour cherry and earthy. mouthful is pleasant with earthy edge and a crisp sour finish. Very enjoyable, glad to be there for the keg tapping...
This is classic Flanders red to me.  Nice and sour, nice mouthfeel...an acquired taste but for those who like it this is a nice effort.

Bottle, pours dark (red with back sun light) with a short lived head.  The aroma is wood, sour cherry, and some leather.  The flavor is bracingly dry up front, morphs into sour, tart, cherries on acid, and some serious cask notes.  The palate is cleansing and suppors the flavor structure well.  Overall, damn good.

Bottle. 

Clear dark reddish brown with a small off-white head that leaves small lacings. 

The smell is acidic with tart berry notes and rather prominent notes of caramel. Notes of funky barrel and vinegar as well as some spices and toffee. 

The flavor has an interesting and enjoyable mix of sweet chewy malts and a prominent acidity. Aromas of toffee, gentle muted notes of bread. The acidity takes center stage in the middle with nice tart cherry notes, some lemon and vinegar. Notes of grass. The finish is a bit sharp and vinegary with notes of bitter grass and minerals. 

Medium body, smooth oily mouthfeel. 

Nice one. Complex and interesting. I like how the malts shine through at first.

Surprised I haven¬ít rated this one yet!  I¬íve enjoyed this great beveridge in many situations...on tap, in a 22, in a 750, high on LSD...and over and over again, it¬ís been one of my favorite American Sours, and NBB brews!    Had one again last night at Naked City for the first time in a while, and was reminded just how incredible the puckering and dry feeling in my mouth is after each sip of this beauty.  Please...never change this in any way!  It¬ís just too damn good!!!

on tap @ falling rock in denver. pours a dark burgandy with a thin, bubbly, beige head and a thick sheet of lace on the wine glass. aroma is simply excellent with big notes of tart red grapes, sour cherry, red wine vinegar, raspberry fruit-roll-up, and a hint of wheat and red apple. flavor is simply wonderful with huge sour fruit notes of cherry, berry, and grape skins with notes of tart melon that finishes with notes of soft caramel and oak. palate is medium bodied with bright carbonation with a tart yet smooth, dry finish. overall, a great sour ale.

Pours with a woody dark brown hue with a small off white head that is mostly diminishing. 
Aroma is of dark fruits, citrus - especially lemon, yeast. Nose is very sour, which may sound weird but is the truth
Neutral beginning with a moderate to heavy sour ending. toffee flavor with some coffee and yeast throughout the entire taste of the beer
Medium Mouth feel - light carbonation
A Great Sour Ale indeed!

UPDATED: JUL 25, 2010 New Belgium Brewing Company--La Folie Wood Aged Ale--Corked Bottle--2005--25.4 oz. Bottle.  6.00% ABV--30 IBU¬ís?  (4.0 / 5.0)  Belgian Ale--Sour Brown--Rich lacy head.  Clear rich bright amber color hazes brown with sediment.  Rich Belgian ester front.crisp dreadfully sour dry sweet Belgian ester caramel fruit citrus body.  Hot spicy sour refreshing end.  Sampled 11/18/2005.

New Belgium Brewing Company--La Folie Sour Brown Ale--Lips of Faith Series--Flanders-Style Reddish Brown Ale Fermented 1 to 3 Years In French Oak Barrels--2009 22 oz. Bottle.  6.00% ABV--10 IBU¬ís?  (4.0 / 5.0)  Brown Ale--Flanders-Style--Thin fizzy light lace tan head.  Clear bright red brown color.  Sweet toasted citrus ester mild hop front.  Intense sour fruit brown ale hint tangy citrus body.  No sediment.  Seriously sour tasty refreshing puckery citrus spice end.  Very fruity, but good.  Sampled 6/22/2009.  1 @ $15.99 Each.

New Belgium Brewing Company--2010 La Folie Sour Brown Ale-Lips of Faith Series-Seriously Sour.This Flanders-Style Reddish Brown Ale Was Fermented 1-3 Years In French Oak Barrels For MouthPuckering Perfection--2010 22 oz. Bottle.  6.00% ABV.  10 IBU¬ís?  (3.5 / 5.0)  Brown Ale--Flanders-Style.  Thin fizzy mild lace light tan head.  Clear rich bright dark ruby red color.  Ugly sediment dusting at end of pour.  Aromatic dark cherry fruit ester sweet sour front.  Mildly puckering green apple sour brown oak hint fruity tasty mild CO2 body.  Dry crisp clean citrus end.  Hard to get past the sourness.  Refreshing and tasty.  Sampled 7/25/2010.  2 @ $14.99 Each.

Pours deep brown with ruby highlights and a nice tan head.  Woody aroma up front with cherries, vinegar and vanilla coming in.  A bit of raisin.  Taste is tart cherries and malt that turns sour and puckers you right up.  Finishes dry with the sour lingering.  Mmm Mmm good!
aroma almost smells of cola and fruity. nice reddish brown appearrance. only the second sour ale ive had and i love its mouth puckering love leaves me craving more sours. very good from new belgium

A: Very dark brown with a bit of red tint and a thin layer of white foam.

S: An incredibly tart nose. Vinegar, cherries, and a bit of wood.

T: Amazing tartness on this! Cherries, lemon, wood, and a slight grape flavor.

M: Very crisp, causes a puckering sensation, and a great amount of carbonation.

D: Absolutely fantastic all around and very easy drinking.
After touring the Rodenbach Brewery a year ago, I haven¬ít found any better beer to catch the style of Rodenbachs Grand Cru. It may be in my top ten favorite beers.

Brown with a small beige foam which leaves a tad of lazing on the wine glass used. Nice fat (brown) malty aroma with plenty of wood, raisin, vanilla and some milky light chocolate. Flavour starts sweet and fat malty but is quickly swept away by a nice dry and fruity acidity. Finishes on a longlasting sweet and sour woody note. Smooth properly carbonated mouthfeel. Nice with lots of flavour for the ABV but I am lacking a bit of complexity.

New Belgium you really earned your name! I didn¬ít think a non-Belgian beer could taste like this but reading that the brewmaster from Rodenbach also made this, now it makes sense. Brown and ruby red hue with thiin tan head. Thin tan head layer. Aroma is cork and woody. Wonderful sour apple champagne like taste. Tastes remarkably like Rodenbach.

On draft @Toronado.  My first sour beer experience- now I know what everybody is raving about!  I don¬ít know how this stacks up against the competition, but I¬ím happy to give New Belgium a big thimbs up.  This tasting has inspired me to check out other sours.

A wonderful example of the sour red ale.  New Belgium does its roots proud with this beer.  The sour apple is balanced perfectly.  An eminently sessionable sour (if such a thing could be said to exist).  Quite frankly, I am in love.

Bottle. Can¬ít remember who traded me this, but thanks to you!
Vintage 2007
Pours deep, wonderful red with a fairly large, but rather fizzy white head. Disappears rather fast, but leaves the great deep red colour to really play in my glass. Aroma is splendid. Lots of oak, cherries, funky and a wonderful underlying strawberry note. High, prickly carbonation and a good, light and breezy mouthfeel. Tart, fruity flavour, oak, lambic notes, peach, cherries - and some fructose. Dry, tart and super oaky. Top-class and probably the best American sour ale I¬íve tried.

I¬ím relatively new to sours, but wow, this one grabs you!  On tap at Local Option in Chicago.  Dark ruby/brown with off-white head.  Aroma is very sour and strong vinegar.  Taste is more of the same, some bready malt and funky yeast, but mostly sour vinegar that puckers the mouth and hits you in the back of the tongue.  Crisp medium mouthfeel.  Not bad!

Pours dark brown with thick tan head, aroma is full of tart cherries and apple.  Taste up front is some sweet apples and vanilla working into a nice tart and sour apple finish.  Not experienced with sour ale, but this one was good!

Pours dark brown to black with a tan head. The aroma is strong oak and vanilla with some tart citrus and tart dark fruit. You also get some chocolate. The flavor is tart fruit. Lots of sour cherries. You also get oak and vanilla. As the beer warms, it becomes a more lactic sourness as opposed to the sour fruit that was in the beer earlier. Thin-medium mouthfeel and low to medium carbonation. A truly outstanding beer.

22 oz. bottle- Pours reddish black with small thin head, aroma is tart  and pleasant. the flavor is tart like a Granny Smith apple, and mellows out after it sits in the glass. I am fairly new to sour ales, my only other experience is 2008 vintage of The Dissident, but seems pretty good to me.

Bomber: brownish red colour with a quick head
aroma is vinegary sourness, woody. some cherry
flavour is very tart funky, green apple, cherry. read someone mention rhubarb and I can totally get that as well. Woody finish.

UPDATED: MAR 20, 2010 Bomber pours a deep reddish brown with minimal retaining off white head (nice lacing) into a tulip.  Typical oak aged sour lactose aroma, wet wood; also cherries, currents.  Wow this is funky, sour lactose and wood flavor are the most prevalent tastes in the beginning, but fades into exceptionally tart lemons, cherries, raspberries, currents.  Finishes dry with cherries, lemon, and most interesting and powerful of all: rhubarb.  Becomes less harsh and smoother as it warms.  Fuzzy mouthfeel, medium carbonation level, medium-full body.  My favorite sour so far.  Unique, interesting, and delicious.

Bottle. Pours a dark reddish-brown with a small bubbly head that fades to a ring. Tart, sour aroma, of citrus, yeast, malt and a nice note of sugar. Taste is sour with a bit of sugar on top, of yeast, lemon, malt, and under-ripe fruits. Lingering clean sourness. Very nice.

Bottled 1/9, uncorked 1/10. Bottle #519. just enough pressure to push thr cork out, but no pop! Scent out of the bottle post-cork reminds me of a bottle of wine. Fine yet fastly fading off white head. Deep ruby red color, cloudy and murky but clean. No carbonation. Sour, oak aroma. Flat mouthfeel, on first sip it¬ís a punch in the mouth... Pretty darned sour and lightly oaky with a sweet tartness in the finish near the lips. Wet and dense when cold, I suspected this got thinner and tastier when warmer, but not really. Definitely a sour brown... Not the best I¬íve had, but definitely unique.

A beer that I¬íve heard so much about over the years. So it was a real pleasure to finally try this at the Map Room this past weekend. On draught, this beer pours a dark amber with a two finger sized white head. Aroma is really fantastic. Sour, lambic characteristics with that cherry, yeasty, floral grapey like flavors. It was an impressive beer but a little more sour then most of the flemish sours ive had. Tastey beer for sure.

UPDATED: MAY 7, 2012 Pours an opaque dark chocolate brown with a fine-bubbled tan head. Aroma is strong, rich and fruity. Pleasantly sour flavor is strongly of sour apple and quite fierce - those who love sour ales should flip over this one! Texture is fairly smooth and nicely tingly.

Adding my observations for the 2012 version: Strong aroma is mainly sour apple, not for the faint of heart! It pours a deep, clear mahogany with a rather thick and persistent pale tan head. Flavor is fiercely tart, with apple dominating but letting through hints of malt and hop bitterness. Texture has average body and plenty of tingle. Why is the 2012 considered an alias? IMHO it should be listed as a separate brew, but in the end it¬ís Rate Beer¬ís call.

Bottle.  Pours reddish brown with virtually no head.  Aroma is woody with nice funkiness in the nose.  Taste is sweet and sour.  Nice sour cherry flavor.  Medium body, lively with a long finish.  Was not expecting much and was pleasantly surprised.

On tap @ The Stable - 12.23.09.  Brownish red with very thin tan head.  Aroma of sour fruit, raisins.  Tastes sour, tart, pungent, musky, dark dried fruits.  Very dry mouth feel.  "Good like Robitussin" said my friend Steve.

Pours dark reddish brown, medium khaki head. Crazy good aroma. Sweet/tart cherries, high quality balsamic vinegar. Very sour flavor, prickly palate. Lip-smackingly delicious. Dude, this stuff is the shit. Like gueuzes, good Flemish sours taste pretty similar. Just that some are better than others. Remarkably drinkable. Despite being familiar with this beer¬ís reputation, I¬ím still taken by surprise to find a Flemish sour of such impecable quality in America. Superb stuff.

Reviewed 11/7/2009 (Bottle):

Pours a rich red brown color body with a small light tan head, quickly diminishing. Aroma, very strong sour. Some sweetness like green apples. Effervescent, sweet aftertaste. Light green apple, but mostly sour, little sweetness. Very tart.
This is puckery.  Made three other people wince.  Once you get used to that initial punch though this calms down and is really good.  The fruit really grows on you and the sour dies down (a bit)

Red-tinged brown, pretty well clear w/ a short-lived head of off-white bubbles. Nose is tart and fruity w/ lots of complex spice nose--absolutely the best quality this beer has. Taste is tart but conservatively so for something that says "seriously sour" on the label. The overall effect is quite like some of the tarter pure fruit juices, cranberry or cherry, only w/ added depth and complexity from some tannic overtones. My only gripe is mouthfeel which I felt lacked the necessary effervescence to make this a truly lively experience. Overall, a wonderfully complex beer though.

Large taste at the ORF tasting.  Holy shit this is like sucking down 10 sour apple warheads at the same time.  I took the first sip of this and was pretty sure my eyes started to water a bit.  Huge sour, vinegar, and apple tastes.   If you like sour, you¬íll love this.  It took me a second to figure out if it was just insanely sour, but there¬ís a lot more to it than that.  I think this was the first beer that  made my mouth water profusely craving more. Awesome in-your-face sour

UPDATED: MAY 11, 2011 Big sample at the ORF pre-release tasting. From a 22oz bomber with Lips of Faith in huge font. Woah buddy. This is the closest thing to drink straight up malt vinegar. Pours a cloudy brown with little head formation. Aroma is intense apple cider vinegar and malt vinegar. Taste is ultra sour, vinegary, salty, sour green apples. It makes your mouth water instantly and you beg for more. It is completely insane and really fun to drink- a ridiculous version of Duchess and other Flanders reds. Really a treat to savor.12/13/2009 8/4/8/5/15=4.0651mL 2011 ed  thanks to ericandersnavy. The pour is a clear, deep amber to brown with a lively, tan head. Nice retention and small lace. Aroma on this one is really not so hot- almost 100% identical to Short¬ís PB&J infected version minus the dead raccoon. Here there is a quick whiff of peanuts and peanut butter flavored by mild vinegar and salty grape with soggy bread. Taste is sharply tart and mildly sour with grape juice and white zinfandel tannic. Palate is highly carbonated and effervescent, lemon tart, tea tannic, finishing with massive lime juice. Really lacking complexity. 5/11/2011 6/4/6/3/12=3.1

Pours dark rusty brown with an ephemeral brown head.  Almost fizzy carbonation. The aroma is mostly raspberry with hints of some spice I can¬ít place.  The flavor is definitely sour, little or no funk, but lots of berry fruitiness.  Oak flavor is apparent as is a bit of astringency, which actually improves the balance.  Medium body with a nice puckeringly sour finish.  Highly drinkable and worth the hefty price.

Bottle. The "Lips of Faith" version of this beer. Reddish brown color, with little head. Smells alot like wine. With it¬ís grape, raisin flavor, tastes like wine too! Actually one of the better sour ales I have had.
