Deep chestnut colour. Aroma is fruity and very nutty. The flavour is very oaky and nutty to start and then transforms into a very sour fruity flavour. The finish is very dry with notes of plum. A very unique beer.
Dark Brown with plum edges.  Vinous aroma, Golden Raisin, and a flutter of vinegar and plum.  Tart fruitiness, sour apple, plum.  Puckering yet sweet.  Very nice, earthy flemish.

UPDATED: APR 23, 2010 Bomber on 4/23/10 served in a New Belgium snifter... pours a deep lively red with a quarter inch off white head which recedes quickly... La Folie settles into a semi-translucent red / light brown with a thin clear lacing around the edge of the glass... The tart apple notes fill the nose upon the first few sips... after warming a bit the French Oak barrels come through and create a wonderful blend of sour and wood aromas... There is a generous level of sourness throughout the mouth which is predominantly sour apple notes, lemon and a touch of barnyard... La Folie delivers the perfect amount of sourness from start to finish... it starts off light across the nose and builds throughout the mouth into a lip puckering, eyebrow raising blast of sour on the finish.  A medium to full body carries the deep level of tartness well with a nice rounded soft feel.  La Folie finishes so well with a dry, tart and almost tear jerking grasp... that begs you to take another sip.  A world class Flanders Red style Sour Ale. 

Lips of Faith bomber... poured into a snifter.  Pours a deep red / light brown color with a small off white head which quickly disappears... leaving tiny bubbles and a clear lacing.  really nice carbonation throughout... big sour aromas burst out of the bottle.   the nose is full of tart cherries, rustic barnyard notes and some lingering oak.  wonderfully sour - the perfect level of sourness throughout.  as soon as the beer hits the tongue the tart apple notes come forward... some more oak throughout the mouth as well as other sweet fruit notes... big tart lip puckering dry finish.  La Folie is an excellent Sour Ale... so glad they have started sending this to GA!

Deep auburn body was topped with a thin and fleeting head.  The smell was very sour and oaky, with notes of vanilla, cherry, and smoke.  The taste was sour from the first sip, with cidery, green apple flavor dominating all.  In fact had I been subjected to a blind taste, I might have been fooled into thinking I actually was drinking fermented cider.  A woody dryness followed the sourness imparting some vanilla finish.  The alcohol was a non-factor in the taste.  The body was medium thick and nondescript, but the lightness added to the refreshing and quenching appeal.  A well made beer, that I can now thankfully get locally.

Pours a brown hazy amber color with a soft tan head that dissappates almost immediately.  Smells mostly of some sour cherries and a touch of sweet fruits.  There seems to a bit of a barn yard quality as well.  Some rich caramel coming through too.  mmmmmm...sour!!  The sourness is felt right from the very beginning of the sip leading to some of the rich fruits.

Dark garnet pour with a minimal white head that dissipates rather quickly. Aroma is caramel, grape, cherry, golden raisin, apple cider, acetic acid, and a good deal of sweet-balanced funk. Flavor is a tart, slightly vinegary sweet funk-tastic quaff. Sweet black cherry, raspberry, caramel, toffee, oak, and apples. Palate is smooth, thoroughly effervescent, dry and acidic. Quite the quaff.

Plum colored pour with minimal head. Aroma holds lots of vinous notes, raisin, plum, cider, vinegar, and a touch of brown sugar and caramel. Flavor is excellent- there¬ís a beautiful balance of sour and sweet. Dark fruit, raspberry, and cherry are presented nicely, but that bitter vinegar quality is such a welcome contrast. Palate has that sticky sweetness, but it¬ís not cloying. Really an impressive venture into the world of Flemish brown, and I¬ím really enjoying my first beer from New Belgium.

Many pours at Taps Petaluma opening in October; pours ruby brown with some tan foam. Aroma leads with sour cherries,  plush malt flavors including cherries, dark fruit and some aceto notes, plus the oak, with drying finish. Each sip is the full, fresh experience.

Reddish-brown pour with a tan head. Aroma is sour and woody. Taste is lip smacking, mouth puckering sour, vinegar, and wood. The taste of it affects different parts of the tongue, the flavor lingers, and then you get the dryness. Each sip is as tasteful as the first. Worth the price.

I¬íve wanted to try this one so I was happy to be able to bring back a bottle while traveling.  The aroma is of wild berries, some vinegar with toasty caramel sneaking in there.  Dark reddish-brown pour with a thin tan head that doesn¬ít stick around too long.  This is very puckery tasting up front with sour berries and some apple and vinegar notes.  The flavor is long-lasting into the finish which is a touch dry.  There¬ís a sour burn in the senses while drinking this.  This is good but it didn¬ít overly excite me as despite being really puckery and tart it seems a bit straight forward and not all that complex.  Perhaps the intense sourness masks some of the other stuff going on.
This is a very sour beer with a multitude of carbonated flavors. These include grapes, dark cherries, and sour apples. The aftertaste lingers on the tongue and in the back of the throat.

Bottle from Icecody69, thanks! Reddish dark brown color. 1/2009 version. Cherry, grapes, oak and lemon in the aroma. Very sour, oaky flavor with notes of apple vinegar, grapes, cherry and hints of marzipan. Without knowing the brewer you can tell that there are strong family ties between this beer and Rodenbach Grand Cru. However, the sourness of this beer is just within the limits of the acceptable. Almost totally dry, maybe hints of caramel. Long sweet apple aftertaste. Absolutely delicious Flemish brown, born in the USA.

Thanks to dear Pablo B. for this sample bottle. No doubt at all that it¬ís a sour ale. Poured with a nice light tan head and good lace. Color is a lovely clear mahoganey. Aroma is very clean, tart, refreshing. Flavor is a giant sour Belgian ale, more like a geuze than a Flemish. Good body and great carbonation. Finish is so tart to say anything other than that. Not a session.
Poured  dark amber brown, tart fruit, malty, caramel, wood, little dark fruits in the finish.

bottle.  deep, dark, purple, garnet.  this is the most sour thing ever.  immediate heartburn sets in as the stomach acids eat away my throat.  vinegar, tart berries, citrus acid, and maybe caramel.  painful to drink.  not sure if this needs to age...but i just can¬ít handle this stuff as sour as it is right now.

22oz bomber. Pours a deep amber brown with a medium-sized short-lived head. The aroma has some toffee malt sweetness, some funky fruitiness (rhubarb, sour cherry), and a strong dose of sourness with an acetic bite. The flavor is such a mesmerizing dichotomy: acidic through and through with some funky and earthy sourness, but also quite malty with notes of chocolate malts and other dark malts. Unfortunately, the sourness begins to take over after several sips, which makes the beer a little more one-dimensional, unfortunately softening/hiding the beautiful nuanced maltiness. The finish is sour and earthy with strengthening notes of vinegar, but also some sour fruit characteristics. There are pleasant notes of dark malts and toast in the finish, too - just barely fighting their way through the sour. The mouthfeel is acidic and crisp, like a tart sparkling cider - but with a little more vinegar-acetic quality. Overall, a very pleasant sour ale. The sourness is quite intense at times, but the beautiful malt character layered underneath saves it from being too sour or unpalatable. Funky and interesting for sure.

Perhaps it was just the right time for this to be the right beer, but I truly think this is just one remarkable sour that would never let me down. Dark caramel, amber-brown colored body with a filmy head and minor spots of lacing. Amazing acidic aroma of tart cherries, red wine and comforting vinegar. Medium bodied and the sourness attacks the taste buds, it¬ís a full on assault, very zesty feeling. Sips wonderfully and makes the mouth water wishing for more. Prominent sour cherry flavor with a sour mash and woody taste. Port wine that has started to turn perhaps. This is a wonderful creation, one of the richest and all around pleasing sour ales I¬íve tried to date.

Bomber from Binny¬ís River Grove. Pours dark ruby brown with tan head. Aroma is tart cherries and wood. Flavor is sour cherries, wood, and some dark fruit. Mouthfeel is medium with good carbonation. This is sour but not over powering.  This is pretty damn solid but not quite on the level of supplication in my opinion.

This beer pours a very dark rusty copper with a nice head that quickly fades. The nose is of a smokey tamarind with a hint of a chilli spice.Flavor is spicy,dark plum ,very intresting and unique.Body is medium and all in all this is a must try.

Welcome to Atlanta! Holy shit, this beer was at Mac¬ís liquor store on West Peachtree; last one too! Nice dark color. Dark brown with a slight ruby hue. The head fades away quickly. Sharp sour ale, without the fruity sour aroma. Very acute sour aroma. Wood is not a very big factor in this one at all, but I can slightly smell it. Mild cherry aroma, as others have said. Very sharp sour flavor that dies out rather quickly. Doesn¬ít have that nuanced fruity, yeast, sour flavors as other sours do. Wood is really not a big factor at all. Sour going down, but again short-lived. Decent sour beer, but not the best.
Dark dark brown with a slight beige cover.  Aroma is woody light tartness, black cherries.  Taste is better, tart cherries, oakiness, light vinegar, wood.

Bomber.  Poured dark amber with red highlights.  A thin bit of off-white bubbles settled into a small ring around the edges of the glass.  The aroma was sour apple, cherry and light wood.  The flavor was lots of sour cherry and apple over some sweet malts and a touch of wood.  Thin body with a dry mouthfeel.  OK.  Honestly I thought it lacked personality.

2005 bottle shared by JB/customercopy. Pours a deep amber with a thin beige skin and patchy lace. The nose is beautiful: a sour cherry-strawberry blend. Beyond that it¬ís difficult to describe any other definable notes, but it¬ís very nice. Light to medium-bodied and tart with a drying finish. The flavor: tart strawberries and happiness. This is a very good beer, but it is one of the most difficult to describe of all those I¬íve ever tried.Thanks again John for sharing this treat with us. This year put to the 2007 bottle I had to shame.

Bottle as shown. Pours a clear dark amber with a small frothy light tan that leaves decent spotty lacing along the glass. The aroma is a sour fruit with cherry and apple. Thin mouthfeel with a tarty fruit taste with cherry and sour apple. Easy to drink, very refreshing, an impressive sour ale from New Belgium.  700th Rating!

A friend offered this and urged me to considered sour beers again.  I did, and regretted it.  Oaky aroma, almost like a good cape pinotage.  Brown with frothy head.  Unbelieveably foul taste.  Tastes like that vomit in your mouth when you have your first ride in a Puma before going into combat.  Beastly finish.
user_location: Munchen an der Willamette, Oregon, USA

text: (bottle - 22 oz) Dark brown pour with a fluffy tan head. Aroma is lots and lots of sour funk, earthy and barnyard notes, and a good amount of sour and tart apples. Flavor is incredibly sour. I¬ím talking lip puckeringly sour. Lots of wood and sour apple notes with a nice and smooth malt backbone. Finishes with a dry and very sour note. Loved it.

UPDATED: MAR 1, 2017 Original Rating 10/9/09 - 1.5 Dark brown pour that edges on ruby. Intense nose. Nail polish remover, wow that¬ís all I smell! Vinager and worcestershire sour. Wow incredibly sour taste. Has some other flavors that are trampled by the overt sourness. Has a chemical aftertaste. I know I should like this but I¬ím not feeling it. At all.  I poured it.
RE-RATE 3/1/17  Tasting this again 7.5 years later. I am more knowledgeable and open minded than the first time....I think. Hazy appearance, large bubbles. Reddish brown. Nice aroma. Sour notes, darker malts, dark fruit, raisin. Flavor is quite sour, dark cherries, chocolate notes. Medium body. I like this.

Bottle courtesy of Cavie.  Dark reddish brown pour.  Smells like grapes, vomit, and paint thinner.  Purple Atomic Warhead at about 25% strength.  Puckered my asshole a little bit.  Thick, sticky mouthfeel like a bad blush wine.  I¬ím not gonna pour it.  I¬ím not gonna pour it.  I¬ím not gonna pour it.  I¬ím not gonna pour it.  I¬ím not gonna pour it.  I¬ím not gonna pour it.  I¬ím not gonna pour it.  I¬ím not gonna pour it.  I¬ím not gonna pour it.  I¬ím not gonna pour it.
Spent ~$15 for this.  I¬ím a fan of sours, and a new belgian sour (forget the name) was great.  Tried this.  Ick.

22oz bottle purchased earlier this summer down in Orange County.   Dark red-brown with a medium beige head.   The aroma has a lot of rich tobacco, with tart green apple, pear, and toasted oak as well.   The flavor is firmly sour, but has a nice malt balance that provides an earthy chocolate flavor without being too sweet.   Lemon and cherry come to mind when thinking of fruit tartness present.   Medium thickness on the tongue with ample carbonation.   Seems pretty similar to Rodenbach GC, which I should have figured I guess.   Great beer with a nice complexity to the sourness.

Bomber. Aroma of alcohol similar to Southern Comfort, notes of sweet malts faint fruit. Flavor is obviously sour, enough to make you salivate and fein for more. Malt complexity tries to balance wild sourness. Whatever it does it works.

aroma of paas easter egg kits and an element of wood that is extremely rich and roast like, very inviting. appearance is nearly opaque though edges admit this beer is actually brown and not black, but intense cloudiness obscures the hue. dark and sometimes pit fruits set this apart from some of the other vinegar bombs ive sampled. puckering sourness is there but devoid of the intense lemon rind and replaced with black cherry and like stone fruits that emulate the deep color of the brew. nose begins to open, and tasting educates the aroma¬ís detection to deduce more of the same sugary yet caramelized fruits found elsewhere. this makes duchesse look one dimensional!

UPDATED: OCT 9, 2009 22 oz. bottle poured a brown in color with a ring of light tan froth and a fairly still appearance in the glass. aroma has big sourness, dark cherry, light toasted barrel wood, dark fruit, and light sweetness. initial flavor blast is really sour and tart, medium acidity, dark fermented fruit, and dry red grapes. finish is fairly dry and has a bit of saltiness.
Draught at Map Room, Chicago. Red/brown pour with a medium head. Sour fruit aroma. Taste is obviously sour, raspberries, cherries. Never really been a fan of anything sour but still worth tasting.

Well, it took me two weeks but I finally found the beer that hooked by brother-in-law from Colombia on beer (they have very few choices down there) and he certainly picked a good one.  An incredibly sour cherry aroma. Almost completely headless, the flavor is just like aroma, very cherry sour, but with a hint of whiskey as well. Great flavor.

750ml bottle - handbottled 9/2007, bottle number 8702, served in a tulip glass

Pours a hazy deep ruby red color with a medium to large tan head that dissipates fairly quickly but leaves some lacing. Aroma has tart cherry and apple notes up front, wet stone, toasted french oak, light honey, subtle caramel, hints of lemon peel, mint, and anise. Flavor is fairly tart, with caramelized apples, red grapes, dry oak, red wine vinegar. Finish is tart and nicely dry, with fairly high carbonation. Really very nice, and the closest replica to Rodenbach that I¬íve tasted. Although I think I like Rodenbach better, this is really very good.

On tap at Stone. Pours deep brown with reddish edge. Has a strong sour/lambic nose with raspberries and cherries abundant. Very strong sour bite with the nose fruit and a dark malt/coffee hint in the finish. Excellent sour!

10 year anniversary bottle from the First Annual Chicago Sour Tasting, thanks to Kan. Beautiful red cola-ish color with lasting off white head.  Rich caramally fruitty sweet tart aroma.  Nice elements of earthy/tobacco notes round out a wonderful aroma. Deep purple grapey sourness dominates the flavor followed by more earthy tones. Grape bubblegum flavor lingers. Mouthfeel is almost creamy. Wonderful stuff.

Well, I finally rate this beer. Bottle from the Boise Co-op, I¬íve had a 750 of this for some time, but I didn¬ít want to crack it since the 750s are apparently a thing of the past. Anyway, pours a deep red-brown color with a medium off-white head. The aroma is great; rich fruits, vinous as it warms, barrel and sour grapes. A tingly rush of initial sourness, some fruit and barrel. Very tart and yet drinkable. Lovely.

On tap at The Bier Stein in Eugene, OR. Poured a brown color with a tan head. Not usually a big fan of sour ales this one had just the right amount of sour for me. Sour apple flavor with the right mouthfeel on the palate makes this beer great.
Ive never really tried too many sour ales, but this was was pretty damn good. Dark brown with a medium head. Small pucker and delicious with every sip. Would definitely try again!

2009 "Lips of Faith" bottle.  Pours a cola dark brown with a finger and a half of solid tan foam, a minute or two in lacing out and dissipating to a thin film.  Aroma is pleasantly of sour fruit and malt, yeast, etc.  Flavor is solidly sour, very pleasant and smooth.  Lots of green apple, very dry crisp body, lots of good vinegar undertones, and some slightly milder sharp cheddar flavor, as previously noted by other raters.  Really a delicious sour.  Overpriced, in my opinion, but a very worthy ale nonetheless.

2009 Lips of Faith bottle shared with JMerritt.  Pours a red-brown color with a very small off-white head that quickly dissipates.Aroma is very tangy with a tart sourness, cheesy notes and a slightly sweet overall profile. Flavor is in your face sour, very tart and leaves your mouth dry. Cheesy, barnyard note with a sour Granny Smith apple "sweetness" and slightly acidic at the end. Density of the brew is awesome and holds the flavors very well with a very highly carbonation rate which makes the flavors "pop" in your mouth and seemingly emphasizes the sour/tartness of the beer perfectly. Overall a great brew and well worth the higher than average purchase price ($13.99 where I found it).  Fantastic sour that hits the spot!

Best sour I¬íve ever had... 2009 Lips of faith 22oz bottle... Pours dark brown with a pretty good head that lasts for a few seconds... aroma is funky with some sugary sweetness... flavor is sour but not over the top... palate isn¬ít too drying either which is nice

Pours brown into the glass with a small head and ruby highlights.  Aroma is out of this world with a lot of sour fruit and wild yeast notes.  Anticipation of the first sip is overwhelming!  Flavor is intensely sour.  Tons of tart apple and cherry notes with just a hint of caramel/chocolate malt.  One of the best beer experiences I¬íve ever had!

This bottled brew from a bottle shop poured a large sized head of foamy finely sized bubbles that were mostly diminishing and left behind a hazy typically carbonated brown colored body and a good lacing. The strong aroma was brown malt and sour. crisp with a bubbly aftertaste. It foams in the mouth.  The flavor contained notes of sweet brown malt alcohol and sour. Delicious and one I would certainly buy again.

Bottled. the aroma has winey vinegar, some dried fruits and berries. Brown coloured  beer with an off-white head. The taste is sour, has some sweetness, is quite fruity and has a little wine character. Quite good. Medium bodied and refreshing. Balance is good.

UPDATED: SEP 21, 2009 Shared a 22 with DrJay. Pour is a reddish brown with sharp sour nose. Tasking it reminds my of strong lemon and limeade some cherry. Feel is light and refreshing would be great on a very hot summer day. As it warms soy and vanilla comes though. You can really  taste the wood. A slight dryness which lingers. A hard cider like quality with a great deal more character.

22 oz. bottle. Shared with Gabe. Pours a thin lasting head, with some lacing, over a clear dar reddish brown (SRM 25) body....nose initially is heavy acetic acid, then lighter dried fruits, a bit of barnyard funk with some soy sauce....taste is  initially sour, then citrus fruits, dried cherry, plum, pleasant sourness lingers long, dry throughout.....mouth feel is light, carbonation low. A most unusual brew entirely different in style from most. It meets the style almost perfectly.

UPDATED: APR 1, 2011 Thanks to ucusty for bringing this 06 bottle.  Pours amber-brown with an off-white head.  Nose is tart cherry, vinegar, dark fruit, and some funk.  Fruity and slight vinegar come through most.  Flavor is a sour blast with a definitive exploration of the areas of the tongue that sense sour.  Next comes vinegar, more brett, barrel, tart vinuous notes, and some fruit.  Some fruit is there, but the brett and vinegar guard it.  Interesting beer, but the nose is much better than the flavor.  Medium-bodied and not bad.

75cl courtesy of markwise. Pours generally clear cola brown with reddish highlights with a thin bubbly head. Aroma is sweet and fruity with overripe cherries, light vinegar, overripe apples, light oak, hints of vanilla and smoke. Flavor is very tart with notes of vinegar, boozy cherries, oak, vanilla, hints of vinegar. Generally medium body with a vinegar sour cherry finish. Interesting.

UPDATED: FEB 26, 2010 Lips of Faith. A red-brown beer with little head. Aroma was was very sour like sour cherries & apples. The taste was you guessed it sour. In fact this is very sour, mouth puckering sour like the label says & gets more sour as you drink it. This reminds me of sour apple candy you would eat as a kid. Had a fair amount of carbonation & was very different but likable.  One of the only available sours where I live & my go to to fix my sour craving. Simply lovely puckeriness.

On Tap at the Falling Rock Tap House, Denver 12/10/2008
Sour fruit aroma. Red coloured and strong in alcohol with a sour fruit flavour. Crisp and slightly dry lasting finish.
750ml. Deep amber color, not much lacing.Aromas of wood and sour cherries. Lots of oak and tart cherries on the palate. The tartness doesn¬ít seem to fade. Very well done.

This was not hand bottled and corked and caged as in the description here, but was a 22 oz bomber with a conventional cap in the Lips of Faith series.   It poured a deep garnet red with a tan head with red tinges.  Nose is powerfully sour, with cherry and berry aromas. Mouthfeel is puckering and takes getting used to.  The flavor is full of sour cherry and other nuances. Finish is very dry.  You either like this or you do not. My brother did not and I got to finish his glass. I loved it.

Lips of Faith Bomber, not the corked 750. Poured a deep, dark brown, with a tan head. Nose is intensely sour, vinous, with a hint of mustiness. Very tart flavor, cherry, red wine, oak, grape Jolly Ranchers. Finish is acidy and dry. Nicely carbonated mouthfeel.

Thanks to STLWill for sending an 07 and 09 of this tastiness!!! The 09¬í pours surprisingly darker than the 07¬í. The nose on the 09¬í is of tart cherries, berries, melon, Chardonay, buttercream, vanilla and oak. It¬ís surprisingly mellow in sourness department, but the flavour is still complex and full of brett charater. The nose on the 07¬í is more subdued and has stronger impressions of melon/honeydew and much less acetic acid coming through. The flavour though...is more acetic and tart than the 09¬í. The buttercream character is completely diminished in the 07¬í. Both are amazing. The carbonation is spritzy and soft in both, but more effervescent in the 07¬í.

Much thanks to the RB crew in Queens! Pours a vibrant red with a brown tint, almost the shade of raspberry iced tea, headless. Awesome funky aroma of sherry, balsamic vinegar, sour cherry, raspberry. Flavor of wonderfully tart red fruits with a lemony quality and loads of funk. Definitely acetic. Lovely sour stickiness with a red wine vinegar finish. A phenomenal brew.

1 pt. 6 oz. bottle served in tumbler- a sour brown ale?  Really?  Well let¬ís crack this puppy open- poured a non transparent very dark brown with heavy tints of black- when held to a light source.  Medium carbonation, no head.  Aroma of more funk than James Brown and Stevie Wonder in their respective heydays combined, white vinegar, soft green apples, hardened cherries, and-malt.  Hits the mouth with a high-medium body, malt is there but HARD sourness makes it very easy to mistake it, middle is ho-hum, finish is a vinegar/sour bomb. Frankly (why do I feel like Gordon Ramsey?)- this is crap.  Absolute crap.  For the cash I spent on this, I could have bought a case of macrobrew, added some white vinegar, and I would have recieved the same effect-and would have a much better time!!!  I do enjoy a good sour de temps en temps, but  F*(&ING B*(&H PLEASE, this one was a waste.  The nipple twisters love it becuase it¬ís rested in old French wine barrels (quality?) but I got one word everyone- avoid.

This one has been eluding me for a while.  Since I began trading, for some reason it fell into the category of never important enough to seek out specifically, but too important to ever be a throw in for a trade.  Finally tonight, i get to try this one, and expectations are high.  The scent meets those expectations with a blast of sour cherry and tarty goodness.  A hint of apples there as well.  Appearance doesn¬ít fare quite as well as in spite of my attempts to create some, there is not much in the way of head retention.  Otherewise a very dark red liquid, looks like a glass of wine.  Taste is very good.  I have had quite a few in the flanders category and what is great is how different they can be.  This one first hits with the wood, then the sour love.  A sour lover¬ís sour, but I wouldn¬ít recommend breaking in a sour novice on this one.  Just an excellent beer.  Palate is perfect for the style, a relatively thin and relatively high carbonated brew.  Amazing, and I will specifically seek out more of this.

On tap at brewery.  Pours a hazy purplish deep brown color with a one finger off white head.  The head recedes into a wispy layer on top leaving just a little lacing.   Smells of tart cherries, fruity vinegar, mild oak, and mild funk that becomes more apparent as the beer warms.  The taste has a moderately intense sourness that hits the sides of the palate, giving way to flavors of bready, slightly sweet malts and oak barrel. The finish is dry and leaves a nice woody flavor lingering on the back of the tongue.  Overall, a fantastic beer.  A perfect representation of the style.

Bottle @ SDBF¬í09 thanks to {puzzl?; not sure who picked this up} for sharing. Brown pour with sour aroma. Flavor is full of cherry esters, malt, and dominated by sour flavor. Nice sour thoroughly enjoyed it.

UPDATED: JAN 17, 2010 (750ml corked and caged bottle) Pours a deep reddish-brown, nice bubbly head that fades quickly with little lacing. Nose of sour and funky cherries and oak. Taste of sour patch kids, vinegar, sour fruit, plum skin. Great linger and complex all around. Some vinous tastes here too. A great woody, oaky sour beer with tons of flavor. This one puckers the cheeks.
Reddish/brown witha good amount of off white head. sour cherry vinegar makes your mouth water. oaky  flavor is all tart cherry and sour lemons wood flavor in the finish

Pours a dark mahogany color with a tannish head. Nose of balsamic vinaigrette, cherries, and super sour...love it. Tastes like balsamic vinaigrette, sour cherry that stings the tongue, sour apples, oak, and...well that¬ís about it...I really enjoy this. Very dry finish...just burped it up...very carbonated but not overly so...this beer is simply heaven after a long ass day.
Bottled, tasting session. Reddish color, short head. Bit sourish aroma, some cherry. Sour taste as well, again bit fruity, some wood. Nice stuff.

Pours reddish brown like it says. No head at all. Sour on the nose. Light to medium body with ample residual effers. It¬ís all sour cherries, cured meat, sour bratten like my aunt used to make, citrus rind. Not a hint of sweet fruit rather dry as a bony carcass weathered by the hot desert floor. Drinks better as it warms.Earlier Rating: 7/27/2007 Total Score: 3.3This brew pours a beautifull iridescent brownish amber color w/ a full, rather shortlived froth. The spritzy head reduces to a thing ring of lace and a partial canopy. Aromas are like red Rhone wines with it¬ís acidic, earthy tones yet also hits you in the face with a stinging sourness. Light to medium nectar w/ expansive residual effers on the palate. The texture is a little unrefined and gritty rather than soft and pillowy. My first impression is..let me take another sip, and another. Fnally I am ready to take this one head on. An earthy specimen w/ nuances of musty olive meat and aged leather. Extremely soured w/ a pungent acidity that could desolve that fat off the most decadent of meals. Bracingly dry, not a drop of sweetness. Minute describables like sulpher, lime, sodium, cured meat, wood, underripened grapes, cherries, and after you pour in the lees a defined Herdez Jelapano essence appears. Tastes like a cave. The finish is sour yet shortlived and bittered from the acid spectrum. Overall: this brew is very complex. It just seems to be lacking a bit in certan areas as you will see in my component breakdown. If you like the Sour beers though, add this one to you must have list.

Bottle pours very dark red color with light tan head.  Aroma is nail polish, wood, is very acidic.  Earthy mouthfeel.  Flavor is sour apple, tart, very aggressive, acidic, and finishes dry.  This is a real pleasure and is real hard to drink at the same time.  I like it!
Black, ruby red colored brew. Sour aroma. Sour, apple, very intense sourness, and very longlasting. Enjoyable, but hard to drink.

22 oz, wish i could of tried the original 750ml version.  This was Ok, a bit expensive for what it was.  Dark cola color with some cola flavors.  sourness was light with medium to light texture and complexity.  Could see improvement with 6 months of bottle age but not much.  Fun to try and was similar to the draft version sampled a month or so prior at downtown johnny browns in SD.

On tap at Bailey¬ís in Portland.  Pours a nice light burgundy brown with cream head that lasts.  Wonderful sour cherry, vanilla, raisin, and caramel aroma.  Sharp cherry tartness up front, then a touch of sweetness, then an incredibly sour grapefruit finish.  Medium bodied with silky smooth mouthfeel.  Simply one of the best beers I¬íve every tasted.

22oz. Pour is a ruby/brown with a fizzy off white head. Aromas of tart funk, citrus fruit, and vinegar acidity. Flavor is puckering with sour funk, tart cherries, and a nice oak finish. This was so damn good I wanted to drink the bottle by myself.
user_location: back in NJ!, New Jersey, USA

text: On tap at Bigelo¬ís.  Rarely is this a favored style of mine.  Pours a dark brown with a half finger tan head.  Aroma is vinegar and it was difficult to get past that.  Flavor began with that vinegar but soon added some very nice complex fruit notes.  Dark cherry, plum, apricot.  Quite nice, really.

750 mL bottle shared at Immy¬ís Backyard Throwdown and originally purchased at Liquor Mart in Boulder, CO (July 2008 vintage, bottle 4822).  Reddish-brown pour with a thin head.  Wonderful sour aroma.  Sour vinegar and cherry taste balanced with a nice oak character.  This is fantastic.  One of the best sours I have ever tried.

Bottle at the Cuvee de Castleton release at Captain Lawrence. This one was from the Lips of Faith version.  Pours a clear brown with a thin beige head.  Touch of brett, acid, and a little bit of lemon.  Huge sour acidity.  Most sour thing I had all day out of over 30 beers (though probably only 6-7 sours.)  Finish is tangy, with some wood and fruit¬Ö and almost an aftertaste of PEZ.  Very well done.
Tap. Brown look.  Aroma smells like red wine with vinegar and fruity notes.  Bittersweet taste.

Bottle. Pours deep brown coloured with a thin light brown head. Citric and fruity aroma with notes of balsamic vinegar, sour cherries, plums and wood. Dry and tart flavour with notes of cherries, sour fruit, vinegar and citrus fruit. The finish is actually a bit sweet. Great sour.

I am always dubious of American Sour Ales but this is the best American Flanders Style Brown. It pours a dark Brown with a reddish hue.  The sour flavor permated the toungue immediately. Vinegar flavors dominate but citrus and brown malt are present int he finish.  It does not have the creamyness of a Roden Bach grand Cru but the best American interpretation.

UPDATED: MAR 6, 2011 Pours a fading beige head and a copper-brown body.  Smells of vanilla, cherry, and brown sugar.  Flavor is a little sour, brown sugar, and cherry.  Finish has vanilla and sour notes.

Bottle from the Lips Of Faith series. Aroma of cherries, green apples, musty oak, and cider vinegar. Taste is sour and tart, with cherry skins, oak, and green apples. Tannic and acidic, but enough malt sweetness to balance. Very clean palate. I prefer the hand bottled, corked and caged version of this I had a few years ago, but this one is still an excellent sour.
Bottle that I took to Ian¬ís house. Poured a dark brown with a thin head. Sour/sweet vinegar aroma. Flavor is tart with cherries, apples, oak. Very good after taste. Nice carbonation. Very good sour.

Original review date 3/1/2009...

750, corked and caged...hand-bottled 10/2008...#9945. Took it from the fridge for about 20-30 minutes to warm a bit. Into the Ommegang chalice it goes with a solidly strong pop of the cork...letting it breathe for about 10-15 minutes after opening...

Pours a murky dark sofa-leather (distressed leather) brown...a little hazy and cloudy topped by almost a finger of tight buttery ginger-maple head. Leaves moderately quickly but leaves strong bready wisps of yeast up top.

Beautiful leathery (power of suggestion) horse blanket and saddle notes (now I get what the wine community means by saddle notes - it only took 7 years and a very special beer to figure it out). Mild clove and ginger spice cut the thick sour funk...a little cinnamon, dates and stewed prunes. The oak character is mildly husky and reduces the poignancy of it all...acting as a moderator or liaison...or maybe a mediator...to bring this all together.

I enjoy the hell outta this at virtually room temperature...Leathery body with slight vinegary sour warmth envelops and warms the soul. Mild ginger/clove spice blends like a Christmas fruit cake (I mean a good one) for an even backbone. The oakiness of it all provides an even keel and really mellows this and calms it down incredibly well.

Powerful yet soothing sourness meld with dark fruits to create Beautiful Chemistry. On the palate presence the oak is key in providing a creamy vanilla feel while working with the carbonation to put it all together. Even-keeled for the style and the most creamy and soothing example I¬íve come across.

Under normal circumstances a 750 in the style would be a daunting task in and of itself to enjoy in one setting. But, this is not normal - a tremendous effort that yes, drinks rather slowly but warms the body with every sip and is consistent from start to finish - only enhancing itself slowly with warmth. Very even quality and superb construction.

On tap at Bailey¬ís in a snifter. Dark brown pour with a thin tan head. Aroma is musty and tart red wine vinegar. Flavor is tart apples and cherries, fresh lime juice, a tinge of sweetness. Very drinkable and by far the best New Belgium beer I¬íve had.

On tap at the Maproom, served in a tulip.  Dark mahogany brown pour.  Hazy with a thin head of tan foam that left some slippery lace.  The aroma had vinegar, sour cherries, and wet wood.  The flavor displayed strong pitted fruits, sour cherries, wood, and also some dry vinegar notes.  Finished dry with a building sourness.  Medium-bodied with a moderate amount of prickly carbonation.  Quite delicious and drinkable.  A really nice sour brown ale.

UPDATED: FEB 12, 2012 Pours dark hazy brown with a decent beige head. Aroma is cherry, vinegar, honeysuckle, and tart fruit. Taste is lemon, cherry, lime, and generally sour but not too much. I couldn¬ít wait to try this one and it did not dissappoint....................Lips of Faith bottle-  Dark ruby brown. Aroma- vinegar, lemon, floral honey, slight caramel and nut. Taste is deliciously sour. Medium thin body, low carbonation. Clean crisp finish. 9 4 9 4 17...... Had a draft sample tonight of the newest batch, I feel like emphasizing that this beer is awesome

Tap at Hopleaf. Poured brown with a reddish tint and a off-white head. Aroma had notes of tart apples and a sweet note as well. Also reminded me a bit of a wine aroma. Nice sour flavor with notes of apples and cherries. Really enjoyed this beer.

Bottled on 1/09, number 663.  Pours clear chestnut, with a medium tan head, good lacing.  Aroma of plum, pineapple, caramel, banana, citrus and biscuit.  Medium body, very tart, well carbonated, lightly dry.  Lime, ripe cherry, raspberry and caramel, very sour, fading into a green apple, wood, and floral, grass finish.  Very tasty.

Pours a dark brown. Thick tan head, rich and creamy. Slight Lacing present. Unique aroma that is hard to place. Alcohol, brown sugar, oak. Oh man, this is delicious. Seriously sour. Cherries, woody. Alcohol is well hidden in the super sour finish. Medium mody. A little sparkly, but it balances this beer out perfectly. Wow, I enjoyed this!

On tap at the New Belgium tasting room - 
A dark reddish-brown with a smallish head.  This is a serious sour ale, fantastic.

750 bottle shared at SL by eaglefan538.. Caged and corked... 05 edition... Light red in color, nice little head. Good pop off the cork. Nice woody nose.Taste is tart and woody.... some serious sourness pulling through in the after-taste on this one. Texture is average... Overall a good sour that I enjoyed trying.. Thanks Brian!
Bottle @ kloneo. Dark amber colour, some lacings. Aroma has fruits, sweet malts, phenoles. Flavour has sour fruits, vinegar, phenoles. Nice one.

Source:22 oz bottle for my 1200th rating. 
Glass:New Belgium Stem Glass. 
Appearance:Dark red/brown pour with a one finger off white head.  
Aroma:Cherries, oak, vinegar and other vinous notes. 
Flavor:Sour cherries and oak, with a solid lingering sour finish. 
Palate:Medium body with solid carbonation.
Overall:Loved this one.  Sweet components balance the sour.  Wish I had more.

On tap at BIer Stein. Deep reddish brown, more red when held to the light. Light head and lacing. Aroma was full of cherries, vinous notes, light oak and some vinegar. Flavor was heavily full of cherries with a minor bit of oak and some light vinous notes. Very smooth and easy to drink and quite tasty.

UPDATED: MAR 19, 2012 On tap at The Bier Stein. First off, this is a great place to get beer. Second, the brew smelled of sour cherries and was very clean in palate. Excellent taste.

3/19/12:
Had this side-by-side with Cantillon...no comparison. Cantillon Iris ¬íbrought it.¬í
I loved this beer...nice malt backbone to balance the sourness....great beginner sour...I still prefer Rodenbach GC, but still fantastic.........................................

On tap at the Brick Store. Murky read appearance, not much head with my pour. Aroma is funky, dark cherries, tart and sour. Flavor is refreshingly sour, but not overwhelmingly so--dark cherries, some tartness, and an underlying wood/earthy tone, almost tasting of dirt. Very light bitter on the finish. For my tastes could have been a bit more sour and a bit drier, but nice nonetheless.

6/1/09 notes:  new batch and bottling, poured from bottle at Bruisin Ales in Asheville.  Pours dark red with a smoldering cream-colored head.  Aroma is rich of cherry, wood, vinegar, and rhubarb.  Flavors starts with dark cherry fruit, then negotiate terrain that includes orange peel, apple cider vinegar, mellow vanilla-oak, and a whole bunch more.  The tartness on the finish is so mellow and inviting that you almost forget how radically different this beer is.  Palate is smooth and softly effervescent throughout.  What a privilege to have tried this.

drat at maproom.  pours reddish brown with a nice beige head.  Aroma is fruit, wood, tart cherries, sour aple.  Flavor is tart cherries.  Nice dry finnish.  The beer is tart for sure, but very well balanced with some sweet malt undertones.  Awesome beer.  Very refreshing.

Bottled from trade, poured a nice reddish brown, little to no head, I loved the first sip, like a sweet vinager, I loved that, later the wood comes out, with earth, dark fruits, Very nice drinker, with a clean finish, great.

UPDATED: FEB 10, 2010 (bomber from Weber St Liquor in Colorado Springs; sampled 2/3/10). Clear brown/ruby color. Small off white head. Moderate sour/fruit aroma, with light vinegar. Moderate sour/tart flavor, with light sweetness. Avg duration. Light sour finish. Slick texture. Moderate carbonation. Spare lacing. 

-Original rating 6/17/09. Overall rating 2.6(on tap at Trinity in Colorado Springs). Pours a dark brown color. Small tan head. Sour/vinger aroma. Avg duration. No lacing. Thin texture. Soft carbonation.

Pours a copper brown color with an off-white head.  Aroma is wood, vinegar, malt, brown sugar, apple cider, some dark fruit too.  Flavor is intense, first sip was mouth puckering, but the complexity hiding underneath the sourness is what makes this beer.  Lots of wood, a little raisin, almost a red wine vinegar hint.  Super dry, very crisp, with that woody oak finish.  Great beer.

Trade from Bu11zeye, via Dollewaitor. Cloudy brown with a small white head. Complex aroma has lots of wood, much coconut from American oak, dark fruits, dark sugar, caramel and a little funk. Tart wooden and tannic flavour. The acidity is more lambik-like than Flemish red. There is a touch of caramel sweetness, and a lasting oak aftertaste.
On tap at Collins Pub.  Aromas of sour fruit; tastes more of the same with distinct tart apple tastes.  Very crisp and a light sweetness balances the sour.
on tap at Collins. dark pour, a mild sour aroma. Very nice taste but slightly muted compared to what I expected.

750 ml. bottle courtesy Buffalohead. Clear copper/bown pour produces a spare, off white head. Sour berries and lots of ruity esters over a layer of oak. Medium body with a squeaky clean palate. As expected, an acidic sour flavor dominates the flavor, although it is not assertively sour. Very pleasant and refreshing, and with the undercurrent of oak there is some nice complexity.

750 mL bottle. Pours a murky brown. Nose is a tart lactic sourness, some hints of wood, sweet malts. Flavor is a very sour punch in the face of sour. Flowery hops, sweet malts balance it out. Some wood, but not much. Dry with slight sweet finish and leaves hints of vinegar and unripe fruits. Love this beer.

750 ml bottle. Pours a hazy orangish brown color with an off white head. Aroma of cherries, sour apples, vanilla and wood. Taste is earthy with a tart cherry background. Nice sour flavor that is easy to drink and well balanced. Has a lasting semi dry finish.

75cl bottle. Thanks a lot to Bu11zeye. Pours dark brown with a cloudy reddish hew and a small creamy head on top. Vinous and heavy nose. Cherries, quite tart, oak and balsamic vinegar notes. Dry, salty and sticky. Very tart. This is what I would refer to as an imperial sour. Dope.

UPDATED: DEC 24, 2014 For my 1200 rating. Sampled at Barrios¬í house for during his memorial day party, courtesy of ScottyP.  Bottle #297.  Translucent brown pour with purple highlights with quick fading khaki head.  Malty, plum, tart cherries.  Acidic, but not stingingly so; and sour, but a good balanced sour.  Sampled on many more occasions afterwards. Multiple vintages. Very good for sure, but i¬íd rather spend a little more for a bon chien personally.
On tap at Sheffield¬ís.  Pours reddish brown with minimal off-white head.  Smells and tastes like sour oak, cherry, lemon.

750ml bottle.  Pours a dark brown with tan bubbles that dissipated quickly.  Nose is of sour cherries, oak and sour apples.  Taste is the same sour cherries, sour apples and oak.  Very tasty.  Mouthfeel was mouth-puckering sour with some sweetness.  This had previously been offered at a local tasting, but I passed then because I had this puppy at home.  Had this whole bottle myself and loved it very much. Will have to get again.  Best thing I¬íve had from New Belgium, by far.
Discovered this beaut on the NB tour. I had never tried a Sour, but now I¬ím hooked. A bit pricey and it¬ís getting trendy, but I still keep a bottle on hand at all times. Perfect tartness. Woodsy.
Light tan head, light, fizzy body, clear amber color.  Smell of cloves, slight sour smell.  Tart with aged barrel taste.
Pours a muddy brown with white head. Aroma of cherry, vinegar, oakyness, apple. Very sour taste, but a nice malty, woody finish that neutralizes the tartness. Unlike any sour I¬íve tried. Excellent

Poured a lucid brown, with a cola like head.
Medium carbonation, nose is strong of dark belgian candi sugar and tart cherries.
Taste is light, not big, cherries, nice vinegar and woodiness.

Draft at Downtown Johnny Browns. Pours a deep strawberry red. Noise is faint sour cherry. Flavors of sour cherry, oak, mild sour, and a nice earthy tone. Nicely carbonated. Very nice but I was expecting more intense flavor and complexity.

When I first tried this, and the second and the third time they were great. I get this on draught just about everytime I go in to the bar here in austin. The bottle I opened up last week was aged about 7 months. Damn it was very sour. I couldn¬ít finish it myself. Anyways, overall this is a fine beer. If you like sours then this is your bag. The taste was that of lemons, cherries, sour apples.  Good stuff
This beer is sour, as good appearance, aroma was good, but it was to the point of almost being un-drinkable.  For the price and quantity I cannot recommend it.

Cork and cage bottle marked 1/9 141. Appearance of hazy ruby brown body with a nice head. Aroma of sour, funk, cherries and oak sweetess. Flavor of extreme sour, tartness, cherries and leather. Excellent brew!

UPDATED: AUG 25, 2009 Tap at Boonville Beer Fest.  A real nice sour brown ale.  Ruddy medium brown appearance with a small off-white head.  Aroma is funk and brett, sour apples, oak, and sour cherries.  Flavor is funky with lots of fruity notes, especially apple and cherry.  Soft carbonation and a dry, tart finish.

750ml. Pours a muddy brown with a small head. Nose is tons of wood with some sourness and cherry. Flavor is wonderfully tart and hugely acidic. Tart up front with a nice woody malty finish and some lingering sourness. Cherry and apple notes in the middle. Truly great sour ale. Legendary stuff.
Bottle at post DLD ... hazy copper ... barnyeard funk ... light lemon nose ... tart tart tart ... sour and funky ... quite dry ... little woody ...

UPDATED: MAY 12, 2009 Ya know, you¬íd think this shit might as well be Denise Richard¬ís pussy juice judging by the way people talk about it on this site. I dunno. I¬ím not seeing it. It¬ís good, sorta funky, drinkable, aplley and plenty sour if you take a big enough sip but 100? Wow. Not worth $18.49 if you ask me. One and done unless it¬ís free.

On tap at Jerry¬ís Sandwich Shop. Dark brown w/ amber hues, like very thick honey. Minimal, bubbly cream ring. Aroma of Granny Smiths, cherries, some Stilton/blue cheese, tart cherry juice. Flavrs are sour dark cherries, apples, grapes, oak, woody smoke aftertaste. Medium bodied, finished tart. Beautiful as always.

UPDATED: MAY 9, 2009 Bottle. Pours a clear dark copper color with a small tan head. Aroma of wood and cherries. Flavor of sour cherries and oak. A nice tartness from start to finish and then some. Not overly powerful in any area, but instead the flavors seem to blend really well. Fantastic sour!

Bouteille verte de 750 ml, avec bouchon de li√®ge, partag√©e lors d¬íune d√©gustation Ratebeer Montr√©al chez moi. Ar√¥me: Odeur de cerises s√ªrettes avec une pointe de pomme. Apparence: La couleur est brune opaque. Pr√©sence d¬íun mince col mousseux et d¬íune fine dentelle sur le verre. Saveur: Go√ªt de cerises et de citron avec une pointe de vinaigre de cidre. Dur√©e moyenne de l¬íarri√®re go√ªt. Palette: Le corps est moyen avec une texture l√©g√®rement min√©rale. Forte effervescence en bouche. Arri√®re go√ªt l√©g√®rement acide. (Rating #2341)

Wow. Bottle from 2005. Rather pretty reddish color with a slight white head. Crazy blast of sour aroma. I smell bitter orange and lemon along with some light cherry notes. The flavor is crazy acidic with a big wood presence. Lemon peel, orange, cherry, spice, wood, some barnyard funk. Damn this is awesome.
Oh wow, is this one ever tasty!  Thanks to Jason for this bottle.  Great funkiness and some oak, yet still oh-so-drinkable.

Bottle 75cl.[ As my Ratebeer Rating #7500 ;o) ]. Unclear medium amber color with a average, fizzy, fair lacing, mostly diminishing, off-white head. Aroma is sour, tart, barnyard, wood, mega sour citrus. Flavor is moderate to heavy sweet, heavy acidic and bitter with a average to long duration, and a dry dry finish. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. [20081122]

Bottle (thanks jake65).  Pours a medium brown color with a thinnish off-white head.  Aroma is sour cherries, apple, oakiness, vinegar and some yeast.  This is definitely a sour ale.  Flavor of apples and some other sour fruits, vinegar, mustiness.  Sour.  Dry and refreshing.

round of applause .. . sour,acid,nial polish, grape notes .. . tart is the word!! .. . dry and refreshing .. . shocking really, but good in a weird pleasure/pain way .. . mouth puckering .. . truly amazing! ..

Special thanks to JMFG and CMillward both for giving me tastes of this exceptional brew.  One of my new favorites.  Pours a brownish color with a red tint.  Aroma is dusty and fruity, with a nice berry sourness.  Flavors continue, with a mustiness and extreme sourness of sweet berries and apples and a little oak.  This beer is fantastic.

2008 bottle shared by a great guy named Brent at Brother Tuckers.  pours a nice brown color with a good off white head.  Aroma is very complex and quite nice.  I got some tart apples, cherries, some yeast, lemons, red wine vinegar, funk and some wet wood.  Flavor is sour as hell, like a really good cabernet vinegar.  I taste some woody notes, chirries, raspberries and nice earthy tones.  For a beer this sour I actually enjoyed it more than I would have imagined.  Yikes.  What am I saying???

batch 109- 1946 This poured a gorgeous red brown with a towering whitish head. Tons of bubbles. The head gently subsided though leaving a thin layer that stuck around through most of the glass. Aroma of green apples, cherries, brett and wood. The flavor of this was just fantastic: sour, tart, smooth oakiness. It just wrapped itself around your mouth: bubbly, and dry enough not to be cloying at all. Glad for the advice to drink this fresh!

750 ml bottle courtesy of a trade with beastiefan2k and shared with my wife.  Pours a dark brown with hues of deep purple and red.  Moderate tan head that lasted through the first third of the glass.  Very pleasant aroma of tart apples and sour cherry along with some oak.  The flavor is very lovely with again tart apples and sour cherry along with very good red wine vinegar and some oak.  There is just a hint of caramel sweetness well hidden in the background that surfaces every now and again.  Bright and dry towards the finish.  A thoroughly enjoyable beer from start to finish.

Have enjoyed on several occasions but this is the first time i have had it on tap- Maproom.  I love this beer.  Color is deep ruby red, slighty cloudy.  Just a classic sour ale aroma-sour cherries, musty, vinegar, happiness.  The first sip is very sour - like carbonated vinegar; i love it.  Slight burning flavor lingers for a second then finishes raspberries, wood, pepper. Little bit of sweetness in finish too. Great beer.

On tap @ 1702 - Pours a brown color with a thin light tan head.  Flavor and aroma is sour fruit.  I don¬ít know what else to say.  I have a bottle (courtesy of FlacoAlto) I will drink it and re-rate it later when I can learn to appreciate sours.  For now, I will call it as I taste it.  Nasty.  However, I will give it a decent score so I won¬ít upset the La Folie Fan Boys.

On cask for Firkin Fest at the Happy Gnome in St. Paul 09. Wow.  Complex, amazing, and surprisingly drinkable.  Due to me having many tickets for beers, I must have had at least 7 samples of this one.  The sourness is strong but well blended with the light toasted malt and oak.  I¬ím a fan.  Big fan.

750ml 2007 vintage.  Pours a medium brown with a nice tan head.  Aromas of oak, tart and sour fruit and some malt.  Flavor is  sour fruit, cherries and apples, some wood, and some malt.  Fantastic beer that I would drink a lot more of if it was cheaper.

Thanks to Chris for bringing this bottle. Pours a deep clear brown with a little head. Big sour cherry, oak aroma with hints of malt. Tart sour cherry, acidic vinegar, oak taste. Very dry and sour, yet nicely balanced. Awesome.

On tap at the Draughthouse in Austin. Dark amber with a light tan head, no lacing. Aroma is nicely funky, sour, and a little sweet, with a little bit of sour cherries in there. Quite tart, with a tiny bit of malty sweetness hiding in the background. The beer is well carbonated, which complements and enhances the sourness. A very dry finish. Overall, very nice. Glad this one came to Texas.

UPDATED: MAR 9, 2014 On tap at Papago Scottsdale AZ. Dark no head. Nose is tart, sour. Taste comes off tart, cherries, dry. Mouth is very bitter, dry. I really like this beer and will try the bottle soon to compare.  2007 cork and caged bottle. Aged wonderfully with a mellow woody profile.
user_location: Seattle still not near Beersel., Washington, USA

text: On tap at Papago.  Very approachable for a brown sour.  Pours a deep shade of plum with a trim beige head.  Smells of tart cherries and oak.  Builds in flavor with notes of baker¬ís cocoa, caramel, cherry juice, figs, and lemons.  Well done.

Consumed at 50 degrees. Smells of oak and fruity sour notes. Then the first drink of lemony, citrus, with a slight hanging oakey bitterness. Unfortunately, I feel this is a little overhyped. It has a complex palate with quite a bit going on, but ultimately unbalanced. To each his own.

On tap at Papago. It pours far darker than I ever would have expected. Absolutely no head. Aroma is of a deep, nice sour reminiscent of Rodenbach with lots of figgy and chocolate notes. Taste is much less sour than I thought it would be, but really clean and nice, again much like Rodenbach, and with some of those chocolatey notes. A really nice sour beer, but I think I built it up in my mind more than I should have.
On tap at Firkin Fest.  Hazy red pour, pleasant tart aroma.  Flavor was excellent, tart cherry, woody and finished with a little good sour lingering funk.  Very good stuff.

2002 bottle courtesy of Hophead22 and also shared with DuffmanSW at Hangar 24.  Cloudy reddish copper color with a thin white film.  Aroma is very tart with layers of compllexity underneath.  Earthy and woody, tart fruits like green apple and sour cherries, Brown sugar and caramel.  Flavor reflects all of this and the age creates a touch of oxidation which actually makes it better I think.  Medium bodied with lower than expected carbonation.  A really great sour

Lots of pressure behind the cork when opening. Big well formed foamy head that doesn¬ít diminish at all. Fantastic aroma that leaves no doubt as to what type of ale this is. Nice dark amber body with fair amount of carbonation. Fantastically sour flavor of green apples and citrus, with a more subdued earth flavor that¬ís noticeable and perhaps a rounded finish of a hint of wood. There is an ever so slight sourness that lingers on the palate after drinking. Just enough to remind you of what you had been drinking. I could get used to drinking this on a regular basis, which may be a bad thing considering that I know I can pick this up in the SF Bay Area at several locales.  It lost appearence points due to the head being a little too volatile upon pouring into the glass.

C&PLYFOTD: 2008 bottle. Dark brass copper pour, thin sheets of lacing and a nice head. Nose is tart, with dark fruits, caramel, some oats, and a dry smooth base. Flavor has thick tart notes, with cherries, rich brown sugar, heavy notes of plum. Rich, balanced, very good.

On tap at Papago Brewing.

Pours a nice reddish brown color with a small off white head. Aroma is sour, acidic, vinegary, cherries and oak. Flavor is a very acidic sour cherry taste with hints of oak and a little funk. Very drinkable and the sourness is mouth watering, I love this stuff it¬ís great. Really impressed.

Pours a fine dark ruby red with a short white head.  Aromas of dried cherries and port wine.  The flavor is a fine balance of sour and dark fruit, with a controlled brett backdrop.  For minutes after drinking this I enjoyed a sour cherry finish that refused to end.  Well balanced and interesting - an outstanding effort.
Great reddish brown color.  Superb tart oak aroma.  Tart cherry flavor with hints of the oak rounding out the sharp edges.  Great beer.

Crushed with CaryTheDude and JakeBra. Finally got to try this, thanks for hooking me up dudes! Brown pour. Big tart, sour cherry aroma. Vinegar taste with lots of sour fruits, brett, and awesomeness. Great beer. Why doesn¬ít New Belgium distribute this everywhere?
Crushed with Jakebra and Honkeybra.  Smells like a tart cherry pie and awesomeness.  Just a great, funky, tart, awesome brew.  Impressed by New Belgium for this one.  Mouth watering.

I had a local brewer tell me this was his favorite beer so I grabbed a bottle to share with him. The bottle spit between 4 of us into tulip glasses it was a murky reddish brown in color almost no head but a wisp of off white lace.

Aromas of old wet horse blankets yup it¬ís a sour, vinegar and sour cherries filled my nose as well 

Flavors sour cherries and more sour comes to mind. Very tart but I like Flanders so I know what to expect I couldn¬ít find any oak quality¬ís to it the sourness just overpowered those. Medium in the mouth not to much carbonation 

It is a sipper it warmed up very good as I enjoyed the conversation it is nothing you would want to pound a ton of but it is very drinkable if you are into sours

UPDATED: MAR 20, 2009 Bottle thanks to lumpy.Pours a murky reddish brown color yet it appears to be filtered. Medium to large sized canvas colored head Great lacing and persistent head. Nose: tart cherries, oak yet not much vanilla, mold, rubber, red wine, wet clay, and vinegar. Taste is tannic, sweet, balsamic vinegar like, meaty, woody. Finish is acidic, tart, and sort of burns as it slides down your throat but the balance is remarkable. Long last finish. Big fan, I love balsamic vinegar.

UPDATED: MAR 7, 2011 [Feb 20, 2009]

Bottled in October 2008. Pours a deep brown, very cloudy, with a massively tall white head. Wow, what a true, sour aroma. I¬ím really impressed with this. This is aromatic and authentic not just by New Belgium standards, but by any standards for a sour ale. The aroma is delightful with hints at Balsamic vinegar, cherries, and complex, semi sweet wooden notes. The flavor is surprisingly tart and clean. Ral authentic sourness is noticed throughout with a woody, vanilla finish. La Folie is wild and zesty. I¬ím most impressed.

[March 7, 2011]

Bomber from Bearden Beer Market. I am still blown away by this brew. This is every bit as good as any classic European example of the style I have tried. The sourness is clean and cuts like a knife and dominates the palate. Underneath the tasty vinaigrette complexity is a tasty backdrop of fruits, oak, and perhaps something like anise. This is such a full bodied sour and so well balanced. I can¬ít sing the praises enough of this. Who would think New Belgium is capable of this kind of greatness with this exotic of a style? props.

On tap at Binnys South Loop. Poured light brown with a frothy off-white head. Aroma is of tart fruit, raisins, wood, and grape. Taste is of very tart fruit, especially cherries, with wood, raisins, and grapes. Mouthfeel is very dry and crisp at the same time. Not nearly as complex as I had anticipated, yet very refreshing. 6oz for $6?..You can S my D for the price, but it is tasty.

UPDATED: MAR 20, 2009 Bottle thanks to lumpy. Brown with a large frothy beige head. Aroma is tart with berries, apple, raisin, and oak. Taste has a tart zing to it followed by tons of fruit and a dry oak finish.

On tap @ La Bella¬ís: Thanks to Joey for mentioning this to me otherwise I would have never suspected this to be locally on tap. Poured in a pint glass which I though was a bit weird since it was sour ale but hey it was a local spot that actually carried this, so I was hyped. Color was light shade of brown and not that easily visible through accompanied by a small fizzy short lived head. My nose detected a strange combination of spiced yeast and sweetened malts that genuinely smelt appetizing. The flavor was over bearing with sourness which sent my taste buds into shock and intensified the drink even further which was what I was completely expecting. Slight similarities to a medium red wine recent in vintage years but also beer like and more up my alley in the category of wood barrels and alcohol. In summary, I enjoyed this offering from New Belgium and only wish I could of furthered my experience with this drink by possession of a bottle instead of a pour in an improper glass in a rowdy and loud pizza bar.

bottled 07/08 Dark, red-brown color with a minimal head. Smells sticky-sweet and bready,glue and sour and certainly tastes that way, delicious with a slight hint of lemon zest. This is a really good sour and on par with supplication but slightly sweeter and thicker. Le Terroir is still my favorite NB but this is a very close second.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 09-15-2008 00:17:42

Sharp nose of tart cherries, currants, lemon and light caramel.  Body light to thin, orange to light amber in color.  Strong cherries flavor, dried fruit, light toast, tart raspberries, very light toast and apple.  Light to medium acidity.  Incredibly dry finish, tart, very lingering
Tasting.  Dark copper color with a small head. Intial sour smell  into fruit aromas. Tastes immediatly of sour cherry and a nice oak flavor.  My first sour.

Bottle shared at the sexual chocolate release!  Thanks!  Dark brown pour, with thin off white to beige head.  Acetic, oak and fruity nose.  Flavor is complex with green apples,  cherries, and oak.  Very sour!  Bone dry finish

A- Pours a deep dark red hue with brown highlights, thin layer of sparse white bubbles, minimal lacing
S- Farmhouse funk, yeast, dark fruits, molasses, apples, vanilla, oak
T- Initial taste is tart and tangy fruits, cranberries and green apples followed by hints of dark fruits, mild malts, and oak, finishes sour and dry. . . absolutely delicious
M- Medium-bodied, watery texture, mild carbonation
D- This is one sharp Flanders Red Ale that is best enjoyed sipping and in lower quantities, the flavor profile is smooth yet complex, and great example of the style complemented well by wood aging

bottle thanks to lumpy.  thanks for sharing this one!!  pour was reddish brown with an off-white beige head.  aroma was tart and raspberry.  flavor was tart as well with raspberry and seemed to have a touch of pepper.  very light and fizzy.  this was an awesome sour.  thanks again lumpy.

Bottle thanks to Lumpy.  The look is red hazy with a little white head.  Nice lacing.  The smell is cherry, fruit, oak, tart, wine, wood.  The taste is sour, tart, fruit, great.  Nice and dry.  Awesome beer.

Bottle thanks to Lumpy. All I can say is WoW!!! Aroma of strong brett, tangy, makes your nose hairs stand up. Flavor is great, sour, very sour, grapes, brett. Mouthfeel wise, this stuff almost evaporates on your tongue, very interesting, very fizzy. Overall, one of my new fav¬ís. Great stuff!
bottle thanks to lumpy, dark almond in color with strong oaky mercurichrome aromas, flavor is leathery, sour cherries with a light refreshing finish, very nice

Bottle -C&C- from Bottle Barn. Ruby amber color with a tan head that fizzed away at once. Aromas of sour over oak. Flavor is sour cherry with astringent oak. It¬ís not acidic sour. It¬ís lightly funky sour. There¬ís a lot of fruit mixed in with the sour. Tartly refreshing. I have no idea what other ale this resembles. I could say Flemish sour, but it¬ís not really exactly. Goes down quite a treat. Yum!

UPDATED: MAY 31, 2009 bottle at Ft Wayne locals tasting - Pours reddish-brown and it definitely smells like brett along with some tart cherry notes.  The sour flavor balances the fruit notes well with the brett characteristics.  It¬ís not overpowering in any aspect.  It¬ís very good though it didn¬ít blow me away.  I¬íd love to get another chance to try it and take some more time.

Rerate at the latest Ft Wayne tasting - My notes are very similar to my first rating.  Really tart beer.  Very good.  7/4/8/4/16
This beer was interesting to say the least.  on tap at Jerry¬ís in Chicago.  Probably the Sourest beer I have ever tasted.

750ml bottle:2008 vintage. Tart fruity aroma, tan head, brown color. Thanks Sean. Sours are my favorites and this is at the top of the list. The age really shows well as no one element over powers another.the complex fruit profile seems different with each taste. Awesome beer!

UPDATED: JUN 9, 2012 Re-rate 6/5/12: Bottle shared at a sour tasting at Noam¬ís office. 2011 bottle. Hazy brown color with a nice beige head. Sourish aroma, a bit funky, with some lactic notes, malt, cherries, other dark fruits, teriyaki sauce hints and caramel. Sour flavor with malt, caramel, cherries, berries, oak, lactic notes and some pedio. Rounded-mouthfeel. Really good stuff. 7/4/8/5/16=4 

(11/4/08) Draught at Hamilton¬ís in San Diego. Dark reddish-brown color. Aroma of barnyard, citrus, some sour cherries, a bit of other fruits and sweaty notes. Sour flavor with brett, some cherries notes, lemon and a bit of malt. Rounded mouthfeel. Wonderful stuff. 8/4/9/4/17=4.2

UPDATED: JUL 12, 2009 On tap at Father¬ís office in LA.  To sum it up, this is Rodenbach Grand Cru but better -- thanks to the head brewer being originally from Rodenbach!  Great stuff.  Probably better bottle conditioned with some age, but still great on tap none-the-less.

2009 Batch.  Bomber into snifter.  THANKS SKINNYGUY!!  Pours a really really dark reddish brown.  Not sure if its muddy or not because it is so dark.  Descent off-white -- very light brown) head that fades to a ring without leaving much lace.  (Appearance down from 4 to 3.)  Aroma is beautiful!  Sour cherries and oak and vinegar, and funk.  Very pungent and aggressive.  I like! (Aroma up from 8 to 9).  The flavor is great with an awesome barnyard funky finish that is truly outstanding, However, there is a weird momentary wateryness that shines through in both the flavor and the palate almost as if this were gravity brewed to at a higher abv and diluted down.  Still outstanding though. The waternyness is beginning to subside the more I drink.  Very spicy with acidity with a dry long finish. (flavor staying at 8).  Meidum to full body with minimal carbonation, but enough fine bubbles to tickle the tongue.  (palate up from 4 to 5, and Overall up from 17 to 18).  A classic for sour lovers, no doubt.

Big thanks to my neighbor Matt. Pours a lovely dark ruby-brown with tall and lasting tan head. Nose is something like a blend of tart fruit, vanilla and flowers. Really damned interesting. Tastes intensely tart but never harsh... Faint bitterness. Backdrop notes of sour cherry, balsamic, and that vanilla wood. Far exceeded my expectations.
Poures a coppery brown. Aroma or sour fruit, and apples. Flavor is bitter, sour, apple and cherry, somewhat  light and refreshing. Interestingly complex.

Courtesy of a wonderful  MrBunn. Nose of caramel apples and apple cider. WHA! rather sour at first sip! gooooood stuff though. strong flavor of apples. Palate is crisp with white grape juice on the backside. Winner.

C&C 750, #07-3171. Clear copper red with a small tan head. Very woody nose, sweet but tart malt, black cherry notes. Flavor follows, and adds some light funk. SO drinkable, which is a quality more of this style could use. Excellent.

Draft at Jerry¬ís. Amber with good, creamy tan head / Sweet, malty, smokey nose / LIght to medium body, tart, with good finish / Sour flavors of dark cherries, apples, grapes, oak, and a touch of brett / Very good, not on a par with Jolly Pumpkin, though.

Bottle obtained from the local Safeway, of all places. Distinct "wine" aroma upon uncorking. Cloudy dark amber in color. Thin mouth feel with a distinct sour bite at first. Lots of fruit flavors. This would rock with a serious ploughman‚Äôs cheese board.

Bottle thanks to golubj in San Francisco.  Color of copper with an off white head.  Aroma of fruit, cherries, oak, with hints of earth and vinegar.  Flavor was pretty solid, and probably my favorite of these three sours.  Palate was perhaps better, for some reason.  Has alot of lemon, oak and cherries in it.

Bottle. Pours a slightly hazy amber with a small off-white head that leaves good lacing. Aroma of sour cherries, oak, spicy brett, vinegar, and some earthy notes. Taste is the same as aroma. Medium thin mouthfeel with a mild amount of bitterness and moderate to stong amount of acidity. Very good.

Courtesy of Juart.  Pours a deep slightly hazy copper color with a fluffy white head.  Aroma is a sour medicinal cherry.  The flavor is a little earthy and it seems like it will start sweet, but the sour cuts through quickly.  Very mineraly with some fruity funk.  The body is thin and it is sort of strangely refreshing.  Leaves a very sour flavor on the palate.
Bottle 3 years old enjoyed in 2008.  Pours an amber beer with an off white head.  Sour fruity esters, a light woodiness with a salty berry flavor.   awesome beer with a light mouthwatering acidity.

Bottle was a gift from Hank and Mary for my 41st bday. The aroma is very woody, though not as much oak as I expected. Also smell sour apples, a bit of cherry, and yeast. Pours very carbonated with medium thickness and a thin, tan head. There is a little lace, but it diminishes quickly. It definitely hits the tongue sour. It is not as sour as other guezes that I have had. The taste has sour apples, vinegar, and the oak. I appreciate one other reviewers note that this the sour is not balanced by fruit but by malts. A very nice beer!

bottle thanks to aplusbreaks.  deep ruby pour with a cream head that dissipates quite fast.  nose of wood, apple, brett, cherries and yeast.  awesome on the palate with a great flavor of sour cherries, oak, brett and apples with some other fruits.  smooth finish with a great sour bite.

Very sour, not really funky. Very woody, lemony, tart, a little astringent. Not over done in any area. Had it by itself, but would love to pair it with cheese. The lemon qualities I found could also be compared to tart raspberries.

Im very impressed. In a blind tasting, I might have thought this was something from Cantillon. Pours a beautiful ruby brown, with a head that disappears quickly. Aroma has tart cherries, grapefruit, a bit of dusty funk and lots of acidity - theres a bit of straight vinegar in there. What Im not used to is the sweet malt undertone. Im so used to sours being countered with sweet fruit (raspberry, etc) - while this one has fruit in it, the balance comes from malts. The oak comes through in the flavor - nice touch. Makes you pucker, but totally in-bounds, and I think my favorite part was in the aftertaste - theres just a bit of toasted hazelnut that shows up several seconds after the other notes fade. Very good - an entirely successful interpretation.

Hazy brown with medium beige head. Sourish aroma with roasted malt, caramel, woody and lacto notes. Sour flavour with note of grapefruits, vinegar, barnyard and woody notes. Sour finish wich reminded me of a solid gueuze. Like that one very much.

Word to Andrew for bringing this back from Colorado. This is the most sour beer I have ever had. Lip puckering sour and not something you use to introduce people to sours. The aroma is slightly funky and musty but the flavor is where it gets you.  There is a hint of red fruit in the back ground.  Ultimately though this is all about the sour/bitter part of the palate.  Very interesting, intense, and enjoyable.

Thanks to weearetombstone for sharing this 2005 bottle 05-3166.  Been on my wants list for a while, thanks Mike. Pours a hazy brownish amber with a medium creamy off white head.  Aroma was sourt, tart, acidic, cherries, vanilla, floral and oaky.  Flavor was very acidic, tart cranberries, cherries, very intense, strips the tongue clean. This bottle was on.

Draft at Stone Bistro. Poured into a snifter. Dark brown hazy pour with a small head. Big, sour aroma. slight woodiness. Pop, big sour taste as well, my mouth felt like when a cartoon character has something sour and the face just completely inverts with puckering, but I like it.
user_location: Redlands, by way of Wisconsin,, California, USA

text: On tap at The Falling Rock Tap House in Denver, nice dark reddish color, with a beige head, good winey, woody, fruity sour cherry nose, with a good balsamic vinegar accent, with some tannic oakiness, tart berry accents in the aroma follows through on a medium-bodied palate with a nice sweet-sour, tart cherryish character, with a fruity acidic, wet, woody, balsamic vinegar flavor, with some winey tannic accents, with a light malty sweetness, with a hint of dark chocolate, leading towards woody, oaky, fruity, sour, tart cherry finish.

Bottle, thanks to Eugene.  Deep brown pour with red tint.  Foamy beige head.  Nose of cherries and wood. A little must and dust in a good way. Sour lemon notes as well and some metallic aromas.  Bright, with a tingly mouthfeel. Crisp dry finish. Great beer.
Bottle, 6%. Good citric aroma, some acidic fruitiness. Cloudy red colour. Very citric flavour, good and vinegary. Sharp and cutting. Sweet with some good berry notes.

Bottle 75 cl. Courtesy of KimJohansen. Pours a hazy amber golden with a tiny off-white head. Piquant sweet and sour aroma with a distinct woodiness. Medium body, tart, fruity sour berry notes with some wood and salt. Lightly tart finish. 221108

UPDATED: AUG 7, 2009 Pours very cloudy brown with a pretty tan head. The head disappears after a minute. Aroma is a little funky with some floral notes along with some cherries. Flavor is very good, a little bit of cherry flavor prevails through a thin roastedness and a beautiful sour tart flavor. This is slightly sweet but the sour certainly overwhelms this. 
The first time tasting this a few years back was probably one of the biggest turning points in my love of beer.

Wonderful green apple and sour cherry aroma starts this beer off.  It pours a bright red, with a dusting of off-white head.  Very tart flavor, green apple, sour cherries, and a touch of funk.  If you like sour beers... this is one to try.

UPDATED: MAR 15, 2009 Tap at the Hop Leaf.  Stunning dark color.  Aroma of yeast, oak, citrus.  Additional flavors that come through are moss and faint hints of vanilla.  Reminiscent of Rodenbach Grand Cru.

75 cL bottle, courtesy of KimJohansen. Pours hazy deep brown with a diminished white head. Dense acetone yet smooth milky aroma. Dry acetone and dark malty flavoured with a light acidic touch. Dry and acidic finish.
FoBAB 08.  Pours a hazy brown/red.  Aroma of funk and sour cherries.  Flavor had the sour cherries, a touch of wine, oak,  yeast, and some tart flavors.  Great sour.

UPDATED: JAN 11, 2009 [On tap at Hopleaf] This is a great beer! Dark ruby red with a creamy tan thick head.  Aroma of tart and sweet cherries, dusty yeast and barrel. Near perfect flavor, tart and sour without being undrinkable, right on the edge, fantastic balance of barrel, cherries, and acid.  The finish is really nice and nonabrasive.  Medium body with fine carbonation.  Fantastic! [On tap at MapRoom] Still fantastic and ever so quaffable!

750 ml, #71084856, thanks CMUbeerman.  Red pour with a tan head.  Oak, vinegar and cherry in the aroma.  Rocky flavor, but smooth finish.  Tannic.  Enjoyable but the astringency of the finish is intense.  A more in your face Rodenbach.

FoBAB 2008 offering: #812 - My first go at La Folie. Was very excited for it. Brownish auburn hazed hue, tiny offwhite head. A touch of funk in the nose, tart up front, deeper red wine characteristics with sour cherries and oak making some prominent displays within. Finishes tart and dry, reminiscent of the oak. Sour on the whole. Very very nice.

Pours brownish-red with a pinkish head.  Aroma of cherry cobbler and wood.  Taste is super-sour cherries, which is accentuated by the carbonation.  The sweetness of the brown ale base comes through in the end, cleaning the palate before the next sip unleashes on your tongue.  The oak appears towards the end of the glass as the beer warms.  Very nice.

Sour cherry smell rolls of this one.  When held to the light it looks like 2 unmixed liquids.  Extremely tart, especially on the first sip.  Surprisingly fizzy. Shockingly, the malt actually makes it through all that and is delicious.  Lucky enough to try this a week after Russian River‚Äôs Consecration, and that was the better of the two.  A fine beer.

Opaque brown pour with a fluffy white head.  Very fruity aroma with grape and apple.  Some vinegar and sourness.  Very sour flavor, just the right amount for me.  Creamy and oaky with hints of wood and chocolate.  Love the sours!

Draft at Map Room. Poured into Cantillon tumbler. Murky red-bBrown with a thin offwhite head. Nose is super sour, minimal stone fruit. On the taste, it is all sour, all the time. Very clean with some nice grain backing up the slight bitterness and prunes. Damn fine!

On tap @ The Maproom! Lucky to find this one on the website and rush over there before the weekend, I know this one won‚Äôt be around after tonight. What a unique beer. This pours a dark brown with light hints of red, with a thin quickly disappearing tan head. Aroma of wine, sourness, cherries and wood.  the taste is of sourness, cherries, a distinctive tart taste. Quite a complex mix of flavors leading to a dry finish. The aftertaste a sourness and dryness linger in the mouth for 5-10  seconds, this is what good brews should do!  Well worth the drive to taste this and well worth the $6. I just wish this was around more often. By far the best of New Belgium.
